alphabetical letter Z c
The seventeenth letter of the alphabet: called ZaMCN [and ZaA]. (TA.) It is a letter peculiar to the Arabic language; and is one of the letters termed majohuwrap [or vocal, i. e. pronounced with the voice, not with the breath only]; and of the letters termed livawiyRap [or gingival], like v and c. (TA.) As it does not exist in the language of the Nabathæans, they change it into T. (IF, TA.) [It is substituted for the t in the measure AifotaEala and the forms inflected therefrom when immediately following Z; as in AiZRalama, for AiZoZalama, for AiZotalama:] and it is substituted for c; as in tarakotuhu waqiycFA and waqiyZFA; as is related on the authorities of ISk and Kr; and as in OaroDN jilocaMCN and jiloZaMCN, as is mentioned in the Nawádir el-Aaráb. (TA.) ＝ -A2- [As a numeral, it denotes Nine hundred.]

R. Q. 1 ZaOoZaOa c
R. Q. 1. ZaOoZaOa, inf. n. ZaOoZaOapN (L, K) and ZaOoZaMCN, (K, TA, [in the CK ZaOowAC,]) the latter allowable in the case of a R. Q. verb, as in the instances of wasowaAsN and the like, (MF, TA,) [accord. to some, but wswAs and the like are generally held to be inf. ns. if with kesr, and simple substs. if with fet-h,] He (a goat) made a [rattling] sound, or cry, when excited by lust, or at rutting-time; syn. nabRa. (AA, L, K.) ― -b2- And ZOZO, (M, K,) inf. n. ZaOoZaOapN, (M,) He (a person whose upper lip was slit, M, K, and one whose fore teeth were broken at the roots, K, * TA) spoke unintelligible speech, and with a nasal sound. (M, K.)

1 ZaOarahaA c
1. ZaOarahaA, (S, Mgh, K,) or ZaOarahaA EalaI waladi gayorihaA, (M,) aor.
ZaAa^a
, (M, K,) inf. n. ZaOorN (S, M, K) and ZiYoArN, (M, K,) He made her (a camel, S, Mgh) to incline to, or to affect, a young one not her own, (S, M, Mgh, K,) and to suckle it; (M, K;) as also OaZoOarahaA↓, and ZaMCarahaA↓: (K:) and [it is also said that] ZiYaArN signifies the making a she-camel to incline to, or to affect, and suckle, the young one of another, by the application of a gimaAmap in her nose, (S, * K, * TA,) i. e. by stopping her nose, and also her eyes, (TA,) and by the insertion of a durojap [q. v.] composed of rags into her vulva, (raHim, T, TA, or HayaMC, S), and closing its [i. e. the vulva's] edges by means of two pointed pieces of wood stuck through, and putting upon her a gimaAmap covering her head, and leaving her in this state until it distresses her, (T, TA,) and she imagines herself to be in labour; (TA;) when the drjp is pulled out from her vulva (HayaMC), and the young one of another is brought near to her, having its head and skin bedaubed with what has come forth with the drjp from the lower part of the vulva; (T, * TA;) then they open her nose and her eyes; (TA;) and when she sees and smells the young one, she imagines that she has brought it forth, and yields it milk: moreover, when the drjp is inserted, the space between the two edges of her vulva is closed by a thong [passed round the extremities of the two pointed pieces of wood]. (T, TA.) It is said in a trad., of 'Omar, (T,) or Ibn-'Omar, (S, TA,) that he purchased a she-camel, and, seeing in her the laceration on the occasion of ZiYoAr, returned her. (T, S, * TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ZaOarahu EalaI Oamori kacaA, and OaZaOarahu↓, and ZaMCarahu↓, (tropical:) He made him to incline to such a thing: (Lth, T, TA:) and ZaOaraniI EalaI AlOamori, (so in the CK,) or ZaMCaraniI↓ Ealayohi, (M, TA, and so in some copies of the K,) inf. n. muZaMCarapN, (TA,) he endeavoured to turn me, or to entice me, to do the thing; (M, K, TA;) it not being in my mind: (TA:) or he compelled me to do the thing, against my will; (K, TA;) I having refused to do it. (TA.) It is said in a prov., AlTRaEonu yaZoOaru, meaning, Thrusting, or piercing, with the spear inclines [one's enemies] to peace: (As, T, A, K:) J says yaZoOaruhu, as also IKtt, which F disapproves; but others approve it: or the reading of the S is yuZoYiruhu↓. (TA.) The Arabs also said, AlTRaEonu ZiYaAru qawomK (M, K) Thrusting, or piercing, with the spear is a means of inclining a people to peace; (K;) meaning, make people to fear, that they may love thee. (M, K.) It is also said, in a trad. of 'Alee, OaZoOarukumo UilaI AlHaqRi waOanotumo tafirRuwna minohu, [perhaps a mistake for ElI AlHqR,] I incline you [or I endeavour to turn you] to the truth, and ye flee from it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ZaOarato, (S, K,) [of which ZuWuwrapN, q. v., appears to be an inf. n.; or you say ZaOarato EalaI waladi gayorihaA, and EalaI bawRK;] and AiZRaOarato↓; (T, M, K; in one copy of the K AiZoMrRato;) She (a camel, T, S, M) inclined to, or affected, a young one not her own, (T, M, K,) and suckled it: (K:) or inclined to, or affected, the stuffed skin of a young camel. (S.) ― -b2- [Hence,] ZaOara EalaI EaduwRihi (tropical:) He returned against his enemy. (A, TA.) ＝ -A3- And ZaOara, aor.
ZaAa^a
; (Msb;) or ZaMCara↓, inf. n. muZaMCarapN. (AZ, S;) He took to himself a ZiYor [or nurse]. (AZ, S, Msb.) [See also 8.]

3 ZaARa^a
3: see 1, in four places. ― -b2- One says also, ZaMCarato, (inf. n. muZaMCarapN, T, A,) She took to herself a child to suckle. (T, M, A, K.) ― -b3- And bayonahumaA muZaMCarapN There is between them two that relation which consists in each one's being the ZiYor [or rather the fosterer of the child] of the other. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- ZaAwiro occurs in a trad. for ZaAYiro. (TA.) [But in what sense is not explained.]

4 OaZoAa^a
4: see 1, in three places.

8 UiZotaAa^a
8: see 1, near the end. ― -b2- AiZRaOara liwaladihi ZiYorFA, (S, and so in some copies of the K,) or AiZoTaOara, (M, and so in some copies of the K,) the former being similar to AiZRalama, (S,) means He took a nurse for his child. (S, M, K.)

10 AstZOrt c
10. AstZOrt She (a bitch) desired the male: (K:) mentioned by AM; but he says, “ I hesitate respecting it. ” (TA.) [I think it is probably a mistake for AstTArt, mentioned in art. Tyr. See also ZuWoraI.]

ZaOorN c
ZaOorN Anything accompanied by the like thereof: thus applied to a run (EadowN): (As, T, TA:) in the K, and in the Tekmileh, EaduwRN is erroneously put for EadowN: (TA:) and EadowN ZaOorN is used by the poet El-Arkat, in describing [wild] asses, as meaning a run not unsparingly performed. (T, TA.)

ZuWorapN c
ZuWorapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

ZiYirapN c
ZiYirapN: see the next preceding paragraph.

ZuWoraI c
ZuWoraI A cow desiring the male: (K:) mentioned by Az, on the authority of AHát; and said to have no verb. (TA. [But see 10, above.])

ZuWaArN c
ZuWaArN: see ZiYorN, in four places.

ZiYaArN c
ZiYaArN A gimaAmap [q. v.] that is put into the nose of a she-camel to make her to incline to, or affect, the young one of another, in order that she may not perceive the smell of her young one. (A.) [See also 1.]

ZaWuwrN c
ZaWuwrN: see ZiYorN, in two places.

ZuWuwrapN c
ZuWuwrapN Inclination to, or affection for, the young one of another: (M, K:) it may be an inf. n., as well as a pl. [of ZiYorN]. (M.) ― -b2- Also [The relation in which one stands by being a ZiYor, or nurse:] like EumuwmapN and xuWuwlapN &c. (TA.) ― -b3- See also ZiYorN, latter half.

maZoWuwrapN c
maZoWuwrapN: see ZiYorN, latter half.

huwa muZaAYirN lahaA c
huwa muZaAYirN lahaA He is the father of the child which she is nursing. (T, TA. *)

ZubapN c
ZubapN The HadR, (T, M, Msb, K,) or Taraf, (S,) [both of which mean the end, or extremity, but the former means also the edge,] of a sword, (T, S, M, Msb, K,) or of a spear-head and the like, (K,) or also of a spear-head and of an arrowhead and of a dagger and the like; (M;) or the part next to the Taraf [or extremity] of the sword; also called its cubaAb: (T:) or the ZubataAni are the parts of the two edges that are on either side of the cubaAb [by which last word is here app. meant the point] of the sword: (AZ, T and TA voce cubaAbN, q. v.:) [for the swords of the Arabs, in the older times, were generally straight, twoedged, and tapering to a point:] or, accord. to Aboo-Riyásh, the Zubap of the sword is the part that is four digits' measure below, or within, (duwna,) the cubaAb thereof; and is the strikingplace thereof: and it is also its HadR; and the Zubap of the spear-head is likewise its HadR: (Ham p. 48:) the p in ZubapN is a substitute for w, which is the final radical, (S, M, Msb, K,) the word being originally ZubawN: (S, TA:) the pl. is OaZobK, (S, K,) a pl. of pauc., (S,) and ZubaAtN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ZubaApN [which is originally ZubawapN] (S, * TA) and Zubuwna (T, S, M, Msb, K) and Zibuwna and ZubFA or ZubFI. (M, K.) In the saying of EsSemow-al Ibn-'Ádiyà,
tasiylu EalaI HadRi AlZRubaAti nufuwsunaA
walayosato EalaI gayori AlZRubaAti tasiylu
[Our bloods flow upon the edge of the ZbAt, and upon other than the edge of the ZbAt they flow not], by the ZbAt may be meant the swords, altogether, or the striking-places of the swords. (Ham p. 52. [See also a similar ex. in p. 48 of the same.]) ＝ -A2- Also A kind of mazaAd [or leathern water-bag]. (M.) ＝ -A3- And A place of bending, or turning, of a valley; like ZaboyapN [which belongs to art. ZbI]: pl. of the former ZubaMCN, a pl. of a rare form. (M in art. ZbI.)

5 tZbRI c
5. tZbRI, if used, means He acted like the ZaboI, or gazelle; being similar to tacaORaba and tanamRara &c.: its part. n. is mentioned in the first paragraph of art. rbD.]

ZaboIN c
ZaboIN A certain animal, (TA,) well known; (S, Msb, K, TA;) the gazaAl [or gazelle; to which the former word is applied when used unrestrictedly, and which is app. here meant by the latter word, though this seems properly to signify “ a young gazelle ”]; (M;) [it is the gazella dorcas, also called antilope dorcas, of which the ariel, or antilope Arabica, is said to be a variety; or, accord. to some, each is a distinct species of gazelle: the name seems to be properly, but not always (as is shown by an explanation of riYomN), applied only to the true antelope of Arabia and adjacent countries, as distinguished from the cervine and bovine antelopes:] it is a name for the male; which is also called tayosN, when he has become what is termed a vaniIR [q. v.], which he continues to be termed until he dies: (AHát, Msb, TA:) the female is called ZaboyapN, (AHát, T, M, Msb, K, TA,) and EanozN and maAEizapN: (AHát, Msb, TA:) the dual is ZaboyaAni: (Msb, TA:) and the pl. is OaZobK, (S, M, Msb, K,) originally OaZobuIN, (S, Msb,) a pl. of pauc., (S,) and ZubiIRN and ZibaMCu, (S, M, Msb, K,) which last is of the masc. and fem., (M, Msb,) and ZabayaAtN, (S, M, Msb, K,) which is of the fem. (M, Msb.) One says, bihi daMCu ZaboIK [lit. In him is the disease of a gazelle]; meaning in him is no disease; as there is [said to be] no disease in the ZbI. (AA, T.) And laka EinodiI miAYapN sinRa AlZRaboIi [To thee I owe a hundred camels of the age of the gazelle], i. e., all of them vunoyaAn [pl. of vaniIRN, q. v.], because the ZbI does not exceed what is termed UivonaMCN. (M.) [See also a verse cited voce sinRN; in which the phrase fajaMCato kasinRi AlZRaboIi means And they came; like the age of the gazelle was the age of every one of them.] It is said in a prov., laOatorukanRahu taroka ZubaIRK↓ ZilRahu [I will assuredly forsake him as a little gazelle forsakes the place of its shade]; because the ZbI, when it leaves its covert, does not return to it: it is said in confirming the relinquishing of anything. (T. [See ZilRN, where other relations of this prov. are mentioned.]) And in another prov., AlZRibaMCa EalaI Albaqari, said when the tie of relationship and friendship between two men is severed, and it was used in the Time of Ignorance as a form of divorce: AlZbAC is in the accus. case by reason of Aixotarotu, or AixotaAra, understood, [so that the meaning is I have preferred, or he has preferred, the gazelles to the wild cows,] by the bqr being meant the women: whence the saying, jaMCa yajurRu baqarahu [expl. in art. bqr]. (Meyd. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 61.]) And one says, Oatayotuhu Hiyna XadRa AlZRaboIa ZilRuhu i. e. [I came to him when its shade] confined the ZbI [or gazelle] by reason of the vehemence of the heat: or, as some relate it, Hiyno naXada AlZRaboIu ZilRahu, meaning Talabahu [i. e., when the gazelle sought its shade]. (TA.) And it is said in a trad., UicaA Oatayotahumo faQrobiDo fiI daArihimo ZaboyFA [expl. voce rabaDa]. (T, TA.) bihi laA biZaboIK, (S, TA,) or bihi laA biZaboIK OaEofara, a prov., meaning May this accident befall him, (liyanozilo bihi hecihi AlHaAdivapu,) not a white antelope, (Meyd,) is said on an occasion of rejoicing at another's affliction, (S, Meyd, TA,) by way of imprecation, i. e. may God make that which has befallen him to cleave to him. (S, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. i. 148.]) ― -b2- [AlZRibaMCu and OawolaAdu AlZRibaMCi are mentioned by Freytag as names of Certain stars: in relation to the former of which he refers to Ideler's “ Unters. ” pp. 20-21; and in relation to the latter, to the same work p. 21.] ― -b3- And AlZRaboIu is the name of A brand, or mark made with a hot iron, peculiar to some of the Arabs. (T, K.)

ZaboyapN c
ZaboyapN fem. of ZaboIN [q. v.]. (AHát, T, &c.) ― -b2- Also a name for (assumed tropical:) A woman; [or, app. a young
woman;] and so OumRu ZaboyapK. (Msb, TA.) ― -b3- And (assumed tropical:) A man who is stupid, dull, wanting in intel-ligence, inert, or wanting in vigour. (K, TA: but not in the CK.) ― -b4- And accord. to the K, i. q. XaApN: and baqarapN: but this is a great mistake, caused by a misunderstanding of what is cited in the passage here next following from the M. (TA.) ― -b5- Also The vulva of a woman: (Lth, T, S, M, K:) and, (M,) accord. to As, (T, S,) of any solid-hoofed beast: (T, S, M:) accord. to some, (M,) or accord. to Fr, (T, S,) of the bitch: (T, S, M:) and accord. to Lth, of the she-camel: (T:) IAar makes it to be peculiarly of the she-ass, and of the ewe or she-goat, and of the cow; (M;) meaning that it signifies the vulva of these: (TA:) and it signifies also the vagina of the mare. (M.) ― -b6- Also 1 [bag for travellingprovisions &c., such as is called] jiraAb: (M, K:) or peculiarly a small jiraAb: (M, K: *) or one made of the skin of the ZaboI [or gazelle]: (M:) or a thing [i. e. a pouch] like the xariyTap and the kiys: dim. ZubayRapN↓: and pl. ZibaMCN. (T.) ― -b7- And A [tent such as is called] xibaMC. (TA.) ― -b8- And A place of bending, or turning, of a valley; (M, K;) as also ZubapN [mentioned in art. Zbw]: pl. of the former ZibaMCN. (M.) ＝ -A2- Zaboyapu is one of the names of The well Zemzem. (TA.)

ZubaIRN c
ZubaIRN: see ZaboIN [of which it is the dim.].

ZubayRapN c
ZubayRapN dim. of ZaboyapN, q. v.

OaroDN maZobaApN c
OaroDN maZobaApN A land abounding with ZibaMC [or gazelles]. (M.)

1 ZarRa c
1. ZarRa He cut [or split off] a miZarRap [i. e. a fragment of hard stone, with a sharp edge, to be used as a knife]. (Lth, T, M, K. [In some copies of the K, maZrRp; and in one place, in a copy of the M, maZirRp: but correctly miZarRap, as is said in the TA.]) This the pastor does for the purpose of cutting off therewith a thing resembling a wart within the belly of a she-camel, (Lth, T, M,) at the orifice of the womb, when she is affected by a disease occasioned by lusting for the male. (Lth, TA.) ― -b2- And He slaughtered a she-camel, (K, TA,) or, as in the “ Tekmileh, ” an animal, with the [stone called] Zurar. (TA.)

4 OaZirRiI faUinRaki naAEilapu c
4. OaZirRiI faUinRaki naAEilapu (M, K) is a prov., meaning Tread thou upon the Zurar [for thou art furnished with leathern shoes or sandals]: (M:) but the phrase commonly known is with the unpointed T [i. e. OaTirRiI: see 4 in art. Tr]. (M, K.)

ZirRN c
ZirRN: see the next paragraph.

ZurarN c
ZurarN A sharp-edged hard stone: (As, T, Mgh, TA:) a stone having an edge like that of the knife: (S:) or a [kind of] smooth and broad stone which a man breaks and with which he slaughters a camel; (ISh, T, Mgh, * TA;) and it is of any colour; and is also thus called before it is broken: (ISh, T, TA:) and the n. un. is ZurarapN↓: (T:) or, as also ZurarapN↓ and ZirRN↓, a stone, (M, K,) in a general sense: (M:) or a round stone: (TA:) or a round sharp-edged stone: (M, K:) or a piece of stone having a sharp edge: (M:) the pl. is ZiraArN and ZirRaAnN; (As, T, S, Mgh;) or the pl. is ZirRaAnN and ZurRaAnN; (Th, M, and so in the K accord. to the TA; [in the CK ZiraArN and ZirRaArN;]) and Th says that the former of these is pl. of ZurarN, or both may be pls. of ZirRN; (M;) and another pl. is OaZirRapN, (T, TA,) [a pl. of pauc.,] occurring in a trad.; (TA;) or, accord. to ISh, ZiraArN↓ [mentioned above as a pl.] is a sing., and OaZirRapN is its pl.: (Mgh:) and OuZoruwrN↓ and ZuroZuwrN↓ and muZoruwrN↓, of which last the pl. is maZaAriyru, (Sgh, K, TA,) and all of which are with damm, thus in the handwriting of Sgh, (TA,) signify the same [as ZurarN &c.]. (Sgh, K, TA.)

ZurarapN c
ZurarapN: see the next preceding paragraph, in two places.

ZiraArN c
ZiraArN: see ZurarN: and see also miZarRapN.

ZariyrN c
ZariyrN: see maZarRapN. ― -b2- Also A sign set up whereby one is guided to the right way: pl. OaZirRapN (M, K) and ZurRaAnN: (TA, and so in the CK: [in some copies of the K ZiraArN, which is said in the TA to be wrong:]) OaZirRapN signifies signs set up whereby one is guided to the right way, like the AmrRp [thus in a copy of the T, a mistranscription for Oamarap]; some of which are extended and hard, and millstones are made from them. (T.)

ZiraArapN c
ZiraArapN: see miZarRapN.

ZuroZuwrN c
ZuroZuwrN: see ZurarN.

OuZoruwrN c
OuZoruwrN: see ZurarN.

OaroDN maZarRapN c
OaroDN maZarRapN, (S, M, K,) thought to be thus by AAF; (M;) or maZirRapN, (T, M,) with kesr to the Z, accord. to Th; (M;) Land containing, (T, S,) or abounding with, (K,) stones of the kind called Zurar: (T, S, K:) or stony land: (Th, M:) and ZariyrN↓ also has the former meaning: (K:) or this latter is an epithet applied to a place as meaning rugged, or rugged and hard: (S:) or meaning a place abounding with stones: (M:) and its pl. is OaZirRapN and ZurRaAnN. (S.) ― -b2- See also the next paragraph.

miZarRapN c
miZarRapN A stone with which one strikes fire. (TS, K.) ― -b2- And also, (TS, TA,) or, accord. to the K, with fet-h, [i. e. maZarRapN↓,] but this requires consideration, (TA,) Fragments [or a fragment, agreeably with an explanation in the Mgh, in my copy of which maZirRapN is erroneously put for miZarRapN,] of sharp-edged stone: (TS, K, TA:) pl. maZaArRN: (TS, TA:) or miZarRapN signifies a piece split off from ZirRaAn [pl. of ZurarN or ZirRN], (Sh, TA,) or [simply] a stone, (M, TA,) with which one cuts: (Sh, M, TA:) as also ZiraArN↓, (M,) or ZiraArapN↓. (TA.)

muZoruwrN c
muZoruwrN: see ZurarN.

1 Zariba bihi c
1. Zariba bihi, aor.
Zaraba
, He, or it, stuck, adhered, or clave, to him, or it. (K.)

2 ZurRibati AlHawaAfiru c
2. ZurRibati AlHawaAfiru, inf. n. taZoriybN, The solid hoofs became hard and strong. (T, K.)

ZaribN c
ZaribN A stone projecting (Lth, T, M, Msb, K) from a mountain or from rugged ground (Lth, T) and having a sharp point: (Lth, T, M, K:) or an expanded mountain, (M, K, TA,) accord. to some, that is not high: (TA:) or a small mountain: (M, K:) or a small hill: (T, S, Msb:) pl. ZiraAbN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and OaZorubN, (Nh, TA,) [the latter a pl. of pauc.,] the former pl. of a rare kind, for by rule it should be OaZoraAbN, and it seems as though they had imagined the sing. to be ZarobN, and so made the pl. like sihaAmN, pl. of sahomN: (Msb, TA:) or, accord. to En-Nadr, ZaribN signifies the smallest of [hills such as are termed] MkaAm, and the sharpest in stones, all its stones being sharp like knives, the white thereof and the black and of every colour: and the pl. is OaZoraAbN. (T.) [See also this pl. below.]

ZurubRN c
ZurubRN Short, and thick, (M, K, TA,) and fleshy: (Lh, TA:) or a short and fleshy man. (S.)

ZarobaI c
ZarobaI and ZirobaI: see ZaribaAnN, in three places.

ZirobaMC c
ZirobaMC and ZiaribaMC: see the next paragraph, in four places.

ZaribaAnN c
ZaribaAnN (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and ZirobaAnN (AA, AZ, Msb, TA) and ZarobaAnN (IJ, TA) and ZirabaMCu↓ (M, CK, TA, or ZirobaMC↓ or ZiribaMC↓ accord. to two different copies of the K) A small, stinking beast, (AZ, S, M, Msb, K,) resembling a cat, (AZ, S, M, K,) or resembling a short Chinese dog, (Msb,) or resembling an ape or a monkey, (AA, T, M, TA,) or above the whelp of a dog, (El-Mustaksee, TA,) that often emits a noiseless wind from the anus; (M, Msb, * TA;) said by Az, on the authority of the handwriting of AHeyth, to be a beast that has small legs, their length being that of half a finger, but which is broad, its breadth being equal to the space measured by the extension of the thumb and the little finger, or of the thumb and the fore finger, and its length being a cubit, having a compact head, and its ears [for AdnAh, in my original, I read OucunaAhu] being like the cat's; (TA;) it is small and short in the ears, (OaSolamu AlOucunayoni, M, Msb,) or having a stoppage of the ears, (OaSamRu AlAcnyn, TA,) its earholes [only] hearing a confused, or humming, or ringing, sound; (M, TA;) long in the snout, [but El-Farezdak speaks of it as having a short nose, as is shown in the S,] black in the back, white in the belly; (M, Msb, TA;) it is said that its back is [or rather contains] one single bone, without any qafaS
[or cage-formed structure of ribs, &c.], and that the sword has no effect upon it by reason of the hardness of its skin, unless striking its nose: (TA:) the pl. is ZaraAbiynu, (M, K,) or ZaraAbiIRu, (AZ, T, S, Msb,) sometimes, (S,) or this latter also, (M, K,) as though it were pl. of ZirobaMC, (S,) or the first I is a substitute for the A [of the sing. ZaribaAnN] and the second for the n, (M,) and (quasi-pl. ns., M, K) ZirobaI↓ (AZ, T, M, Msb, K) and ZirobaMCu↓, (M, K,) or ZirobaI↓, is a pl. like HijolaI pl. of HajalN, (S, TA,) and these two are [said to be] the only pls. of this measure, (AHei, TA,) and Lth and AHeyth say that ZirobaMCu is incorrect, and is rightly ZirobaI↓. (T, TA.) A poet says, (namely, 'Abd-Allah Ibn-Hajjáj Ez-Zebeedee, M, TA,)
OalaA OaboligaA qayosFA waxinodifa OanRaniI
Darabotu kaviyrFA maDoriba AlZRaribaAni
[Now tell ye Keys and Khindif that I have struck Ketheer in the place of striking of the ZrbAn], meaning that he had struck Ketheer Ibn-Shiháb (S, M, TA) El-Medh-hijee upon his face; for the ZrbAn has a line, or long mark, upon his face; and he likens the blow that he inflicted upon his face to that mark: [see maDoribN:] and the same words of the latter hemistich, except that EubayodFA is substituted in them for kaviyrFA, occur in a verse of Asad Ibn-Nághisah, who slew 'Obeyd by order of En-Noamán. (TA.) One says, fasaA bayonanaA AlZRaribaAnu, (S,) or bayonahum, (Msb, K,) [lit. The ZrbAn emitted a noiseless wind from its anus among us, or among them,] a prov., (S,) meaning that we, or they, became disunited, and alienated, one from another: [for] when this animal emits a noiseless wind from its anus in the garment of a man, the stink does not go away until the garment wears out: (S, Msb, K:) the Arabs of the desert assert that it does so in the garment of him who hunts it: (S:) and it is said to do so in the hole of the [lizard called] DabR, which, being stupified by the foulness of the stink, is taken and eaten by it. (M, K, TA.) One says also, taXaAtamaA fakaOanRamaA jazaraA bayonahumaA ZaribaAnFA [They reviled each other, and it was as though they slaughtered between them a ZrbAn]: the foulness of their reviling being likened to the stink of that animal. (M, TA.) And yatanaAzaEaAni jiloda AlZRaribaAni They two contend in pulling at the skin of the ZrbAn, meaning (assumed tropical:) they revile each other: (M, TA:) and yatamaAXanaAni jiloda AlZRaribaAni They wipe their hands together upon the skin of the ZrbAn, [likewise] meaning (assumed tropical:) they revile each other. (IAar, T, TA.)

AlOaZoraAbu c
AlOaZoraAbu [accord. to some] signifies Four teeth behind the nawaAjic [or other grinders; app. meaning, of a horse]: (K:) or the sockets (OasonaAx) of the teeth: (S, K:) [and it is said that] OaZoraAbu AllRijaAmi signifies the knots that are at the extremities of the bit. (M, TA.) J cites the following verse, ascribing it to 'Ámir Ibn-Et-Tufeyl,
wamuqaTRiEK Halaqa AlrRiHaAlapi saAbiHK
baAdK nawaAjicuhu Eani AlOaZoraAbi
[thus in the S, (but in the M and TA EalaI AlOaZoraAbi,) as though meaning And breaking in pieces the rings of the girth of the saddle, running with the fore legs well stretched forth, his grinders appearing from the sockets]: but IB says, [following the reading in the M and TA,] the verse is by Lebeed; and the poet is describing a horse that breaks in pieces the rings of the saddle by his springing forward, and whose grinders (nawaAjicuhu) appear when he treads upon the [stones, or hills, called] ZiraAb: [see ZaribN, of which both ZiraAbN and OaZoraAbN are said to be pls.:] also that the right reading is wamuqaTRiEN [and saAbiHN]: and by the nwAjc are meant the DawaAHik [or teeth next behind the canine teeth], accord. to Hr. (TA.)

HawaAfiru muZarRabapN c
HawaAfiru muZarRabapN [accord. to the TA muZarRibapN, but this is evidently a mistake (see 2),] means [Solid hoofs] that have become hard and strong: (K, TA:) [but] accord. to El-Mufaddal, AlmuZarRabu, like muEaZRam [in measure], signifies QlRaciI qado lawRaHatohu AlZRiraAbu [app. meaning that which the stones, or hills, called ZiraAb have altered, or, perhaps, heated, in its treading upon them]. (TA.)

1 Zarufa c
1. Zarufa, (T, S, M, &c.,) inf. n. ZaraAfapN, (S, Msb,) or ZarofN and ZaraAfapN, (T, M, Mgh, * O, K,) but the latter is rare, (K,) allowable in poetry, (T, M,) or, as some say, is of frequent occurrence, and confirmed by analogy, (MF, TA,) said of a man, (S, O,) [or only of a young man, and Zarufat of a young woman,] He possessed the quality, or qualities, termed Zarof meaning as expl. below [i. e. excellence, or elegance, in mind, manners, and address or speech; and in person, countenance, or garb, guise, or external appearance; or all of these qualities combined: he was, or became, clever, ingenious, intelligent, or acute in intellect; well-mannered, well-bred, accomplished, or polite; beautiful in person or countenance; elegant, or graceful; or elegant in garb, guise, or external appearance]. (T, S, O, Msb, K.) ＝ -A2- See also what here follows.

3 ZaAorafa
3: ZaArafaniI faZarafotuhu↓ [He vied, or contended, with me in Zarof] and I was more Zariyf (kunotu OaZorafa↓) than he. (IKtt, TA.)

4 AZrf c
4. AZrf He (a man) had many [Zuruwf, or] receptacles [of any kind]. (TA.) ― -b2- And He begat, (S, Mgh, O, K,) or had born to him, (M,) children that were ZurafaMC (S, M, O, K) or ZiraAf [pls. of Zariyf, q. v.]. Mgh.) ― -b3- AZrf biAlrRajuli He mentioned the man as possessing Zarof. (M, TA.) ― -b4- And AZrf fiI AlEibaArapi is explainable [as meaning He was elegant, or eloquent, in the expression, or phrase, or speech], if the saying be received from those who are trustworthy: if not, it is correctly OaTorafa, with the unpointed T; meaning “ he said what was novel and pleasing. ” (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- AZrf AlmataAEa, (O,) in the K, erroneously, fulaAnFA, (TA,) He put, or assigned, or made, a Zarof [or receptacle] for the goods. (O, TA.)

5 tZrRf c
5. tZrRf He affected Zarof; (S, O, K;) as also tZArf↓. (TA.) One says, fulaAnN yataZarRafu walayosa biZariyfK [Such a one affects Zarof and he is not Zariyf]. (TA.)

6 taZaAorafa
6: see the next preceding paragraph.

10 AstZrfhu c
10. AstZrfhu He found him [or held him] to be Zariyf. (O, * TA.)

ZarofN c
ZarofN A receptacle (Lth, T, S, M, Mgh, O, Msb, K) of anything; (Lth, T, M;) [a vessel, or vase;] an Uiboriyq is thus termed as being a Zrf for what is in it: (Lth, T, TA:) and AHn applies it to a seed-vessel, or pericarp, or a cell of a pericarp: (M, TA:) [and it is also applied to a case, or cover, for a book or the like:] the pl. is ZuruwfN: (T, S, * M, Mgh, O, Msb, K:) OaZoraAfN is a mistake. (Mgh.) [Applying it to a vessel of silver,] Har uses it as meaning “ silver. ” (P. 614 [referring to a phrase in p. 213].) One says, Oaxacotu AlmataAEa biZarofihi [I took the goods with the receptacle thereof]. (A, TA.) And hence, (A, TA,) raOayotuhu biZarofihi (tropical:) I saw him himself. (A, O, K, TA.) And huwa naqiIRu AlZRarofi (tropical:) He is faithful, (O, K, TA,) not treacherous. (M, O, K, TA.) ― -b2- And hence (assumed tropical:) [An adverbial noun of place or of time, implying the meaning of the preposition fI; and also by some applied to a noun of place or of time together with that preposition; i. e.] what are termed Zarofu AlmakaAni and AlzRamaAni, (O,) pl. Zuruwfu AlzRamaAni and AlmakaAni: (S, M: *) the descriptive terms that denote the places [or times] of things are called ZuruwfN: (Lth, T:) they are thus termed by Kh; and by Ks, maHaAlRu; and by Fr, SifaAtN. (T.) ― -b3- Also [Excellence, or elegance, in mind, manners, and address or speech; and in person, countenance, or garb, guise, or external appearance; or all of these qualities combined:] a term denoting a condition that combines the generality of mental and bodily and extrinsic excellences; likened [by reason of its comprehensiveness] to the receptacle thus called: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or cleverness, ingeniousness, intelligence, or acuteness in intellect; syn. kiyaAsapN, (S, O, K,) or kayosN, (Mgh, Msb,) and cakaMCN: (Mgh:) or i. q. baraAEapN, and cakaMCu qalobK; [the former meaning excellence in knowledge, or other qualities; or accomplishment, or perfection, in every excellence, and in goodliness;] ('Eyn, M, O, Msb, K; *) thus accord. to most of the copies of the K [as well as the 'Eyn and M and O and Msb], but correctly bazaAEap, with the letter zAI: (TA:) [if so, these two explanations (bazaAEapN and cakaMCu qalobK) add nothing to others here given:] or
skilfulness (M, K, TA) in a thing (M, TA) is thus termed by the people of El-Yemen: (TA:) or it is in the tongue, (IAar, T, K,) only; (K;) meaning beauty of expression, (M, L, TA,) and eloquence; (L, TA;) and HalaAwapN is in the eyes, and malaAHapN is in the mouth, and jamaAlN is in the nose: (IAar, T:) or beauty of garb, guise, or external appearance: (M:) or beauty of face, and of garb, guise, or external appearance: (O, K:) or it is in the face and in the tongue: (Ks, O, K:) or goodliness, or beauty; and Oadab [as having the meaning first assigned to ZarofN in this sentence, i. e. excellence, or elegance, in mind, manners, or address or speech; or as meaning good breeding, good manners, politeness, or polite accomplishments]: (Msb:) or, as an inf. n., the being elegant, graceful, or beautiful: and the being intelligent, sagacious, or acute in intellect: (KL:) accord. to the author of the 'Eyn, (O,) it is only an attribute of young men and young women (M, O, Msb, * K) that are acute in intellect, clever, or skilful; (M, O, K;) not of elders, nor of lords, or chiefs: (M, K:) but as meaning kiyosN, it is common to young persons and elders: (Msb:) some of those who affect distinctness of speech by twisting the sides of the mouth say that the word is ZurofN↓, with damm, to distinguish it from ZarofN meaning “ a receptacle; ” but this is a sheer mistake. (MF, TA.)

ZurofN c
ZurofN: see what immediately precedes.

ZarofiyRapN c
[ZarofiyRapN, a term of grammar, The quality of denoting place, or time, adverbially, by a noun implying the meaning of the preposition fiI; and also, accord. to some, by a noun together with that preposition. One says manoSuwbN EalaI AlZRarofiyRapi, meaning Put in the accusative case as denoting place, or time, adverbially.]

ZuraAfN c
ZuraAfN: see ZariyfN, near the beginning and near the end.

ZaruwfN c
[ZaruwfN perhaps signifies Possessing the quality, or qualities, termed Zarof, in a great, or an extraordinary degree: used alike as masc. and fem.: for I find it stated that] one says qayonapN ZaruwfN [A female slave, or slave-songstress, that is very intelligent or skilful or elegant &c.]. (TA. [But I think it most probable that this is a mistranscripfor qitoyapN ZuruwfN, a phrase which I find in the T, and there expl. as meaning ZurafaMCu.])

ZariyfN c
ZariyfN Possessing the quality, or qualities, termed Zarof; (T, S, M, O, Msb, K;) as also ZuraAfN↓, (Lh, M, O, K,) the two being like TawiylN and TuwaAlN, (O,) [or the latter has an intensive signification, (see TuwaAlN, and see also the “ Durrat el-Ghowwás, ” in De Sacy's Anthol. Gramm. Arabe, p. 48 of the Ar. text,)] and ZurRaAfN↓, (M, K,) or this last, which is like TuwRaAlN, denotes more than ZuraAfN without teshdeed: (O:) accord. to Mbr, it is derived from Zarof signifying “ a receptacle, ” as though meaning a receptacle for excellence, or elegance, in mind, manners, or address or speech: (TA:) [it may be rendered, agreeably with explanations of ZarofN, excellent, or elegant, in mind, manners, and address or speech; and in person, countenance or garb, guise, or external appearance: or clever, ingenious, intelligent, or acute in intellect; well-mannered, well-bred, accomplished, or polite; beautiful in person or countenance; elegant, or graceful; &c.:] and is expl. as meaning eloquent; thus by As and IAar: and possessing knowledge and courage: and goodly, or beautiful, in clothing, and in outer apparel: (TA:) and is used by the people of El-Yemen as meaning skilful: (O:) and, as Ks says, it is applied as an epithet to a tongue, and to a face: (TA:) the pl. of ZariyfN is ZiraAfN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and ZurafaMCu (T, S, O, Msb, K) and Zariyfuwna (O, K) and ZurufN, (S, M, IB, K,) a form sometimes used, (IB, TA,) and ZuruwfN, (T, S, M, O, K,) also a form sometimes used, (S, O,) approvable in poetry, (T,) as though formed from ZarofN, or [anomalous] like macaAkiyru (S, O, K) accord. to Kh (S, O) and Sb: (TA:) the pl. of ZuraAfN↓ is ZurafaMCu: (Lh, M, K:) and the pl. of ZurRaAfN↓ is ZurRaAfuwna: (M, K:) the fem. of ZariyfN is ZariyfapN; and the pl. of this is ZiraAfN, (Sb, T, M, Msb, TA,) like a pl. of the masc., (Sb, M, TA,) and ZaraAYifu. (T, M, TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Omar, mentioned by IAar, (Mgh, O, TA,) and by As, (TA,) UicaA kaAna AllRiSRu ZariyfFA laA yuqoTaEu, (Mgh,) or lamo yuqoTaEo, (O, TA,) meaning When the thief is eloquent (Mgh, O, TA) and intelligent, (Mgh,) he averts from himself the prescribed punishment by his pleading [so that he will not be, or is not, mutilated by amputation of the hand]. (Mgh, O, TA.)

ZariyfapN c
[ZariyfapN, as a subst., A thing, and a saying, that is Zariyf, meaning elegant, &c.: pl. ZaraAYifu.]

ZurRaAfN c
ZurRaAfN: see ZariyfN, near the beginning and near the end.

ZaArifN c
ZaArifN [is distinguished from ZariyfN like as XaArifN is from XariyfN, q. v.]. Lh mentions the saying AuZorufo Uino kunota ZaArifFA [Possess thou Zarof if thou be one who will possess it]: in meaning the actual state, they said UinRahu laZariyfN [Verily he is one who possesses Zarof]. (M.)

OaZorafu c
OaZorafu: see 3. Ks allows the saying, interrogatively, maA OaZorafu zayodK OalisaAnuhu OaZorafu OamN wajohuhu [What is the part that is the more excellent in Zarof (or elegance, &c.), of Zeyd? is his tongue the more so, or his face?]. (TA.)

yaA maZorafaAnu c
yaA maZorafaAnu is an expression similar to yaA malokaEaAnu [and makocabaAnu &c.; meaning O thou who possessest the quality, or qualities, of Zarof in a great, or an extraordinary degree]. (A, TA.)

1 ZaEana c
1. ZaEana, (S, Msb, K,) aor.
ZaEana
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. ZaEonN (S, Msb, K) and ZaEanN↓, (S, K,) or the latter is a simple subst., (Msb,) and ZuEuwnN (TA) [and maZoEanN, occurring in a verse of Zuheyr cited in art. blw, conj. 3], He journeyed, went away, departed, (S, * Msb, K, * TA,) or removed; (Msb;) he journeyed to seek after herbage, or to water; or he removed from water to water, or from one country, or tract of land, to another. (TA. [See also the part. n., ZaAEinN.]) ― -b2- ZaEana bihi: see what next follows.

4 AZEnhu c
4. AZEnhu He made him to journey, go away, depart, (S, Msb, K,) or remove; and bihi ZaEana↓ signifies the same [or he journeyed, &c., with him]. (Msb.)

8 AiZRaEanatohu c
8. AiZRaEanatohu She rode him, (S, K, TA,) namely, a camel: you say, hecaA baEiyrN taZRaEinuhu AlmaroOapu This is a camel that the woman rides (S, TA) in her journeying, and in the day of her departure. (TA.)

ZaEanN c
ZaEanN: see 1: ＝ -A2- and see also ZaAEinN.

ZuEonapN c
ZuEonapN A short journey. (TA.)

ZiEonapN c
ZiEonapN A state or condition, or a mode or manner, of journeying or departing. (TA.)

ZiEaAnN c
ZiEaAnN A rope with which a hawodaj [or woman's camel-vehicle] is bound; (S, K;) or with which a load is bound, accord. to the T: and ZaEuwnN↓ signifies the same. (TA.)

ZaEuwnN c
ZaEuwnN A camel used for work and for bearing burdens: (S, K, TA:) or, as some say, peculiarly, [like ZaEiynapN,] a camel that is ridden by a woman. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ZiEaAnN.

ZaEiynapN c
ZaEiynapN A hawodaj [or woman's camel-vehicle] (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA) in which is a woman, (TA,) or whether there be in it a woman or not: (S, Msb, K, TA:) this is [said to be] the primary signification: (Mgh:) pl. ZaEaAYinu and ZuEunN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and ZuEonN (S, K) and [pl. of pauc.] OaZoEaAnN (S, Mgh, K) and pl. pl. ZuEunaAtN. (TA. [But see, in what follows, an assertion of AZ respecting the pl. ZuEunN.]) ― -b2- And A woman, (ISk, Mgh, Msb, TA;) whether in a hawodaj or elsewhere; (ISk, TA;) the word being used in the sense of maZoEuwnapN [for maZoEuwnN bihaA]; because her husband journeys (yaZoEanu) with her: (Msb:) or a man's wife; because she journeys with her husband: (TA:) or a woman as long as she is in the hwdj; (S, Msb, K;) when not in it she is not thus called: (S:) or this is the primary meaning: then it was applied to her though in her tent, because she might become maZoEuwnap [i. e. maZoEuwn bihaA]: (Msb:) it is mostly applied to a woman riding [in a hwdj]: then, to a hwdj without a woman: and to a woman without a hwdj. (TA.) 'Amr Ibn-Kulthoom says,
qifiI qabola AltRafarRuqi yaA ZaEiynaA
nuxabRiroki Alyaqiyna watuxobiriynaA
[Pause thou before separation, O woman in the
camel-vehicle: we will inform thee of the real truth respecting our case, and thou shalt inform us respecting thy case]: (S:) yaA ZaEiynaA is for yaA ZaEiynapu. (EM p. 185.) ― -b3- And, accord. to Lth, A camel that is ridden by women: [like ZaEuwnN:] and applied to signify a woman because she rides it: or, accord. to IAmb, a camel upon which one journeys: and hence the trad., layosa fiI jamalK ZaEiynapK SadaqapN i. e. [There is no poor-rate in the case of] the camel upon which one journeys; if the phrase be thus: but if it be fiI jamali ZaEiynapK, by the last word is meant a woman: (TA:) AZ says, one should not say HumuwlN nor ZuEunN except as meaning the camels upon which are hawaAdij, whether there be in them women or not. (S.)

ZaAEinN c
ZaAEinN Journeying, going away, departing, or removing: (Msb:) [a traveller:] any one going forth on a journey, on pilgrimage, or on a warring and plundering expedition, or journeying from one city [or town &c.] to another: contr. of xaAfiDN [and of muqiymN]: one says, OaZaAEinN Oanota Oamo muqiymN [Art thou journeying or abiding?]: the pl. is ZaAEinuwna and ZuEunN, and ZaEanN↓ is a quasipl. n. syn. with ZaAEinuwna. (TA.)

miZoEaAnN c
miZoEaAnN, applied to a horse or mare, and to a she-camel, Easy in pace. (TA.)

maZoEuwnN c
maZoEuwnN Made to journey, go away, depart, or remove; originally maZoEuwnN bihi; the complement being suppressed because of frequency of usage. (Msb.)

1 Zafarahu c
1. Zafarahu: see 2. ＝ -A2- [See also ZafarN. ― -b2- ] Zafirato Eayonuhu, (T, S, O, K,) aor.
Zafara
, inf. n. ZafarN (S, O) and ZafaArapN; (O;) and, as some say, Zufirat; (T;) His eye had what is termed a Zafarap or Zufor. (T, S, O, K.) ― -b3- And Zufira He (a man) had upon his eye what is termed a Zafarap or Zufor. (T, O, K.) ＝ -A3- Zafira, aor.
Zafara
, (Msb,) inf. n. ZafarN, He attained, got, got possession of, or acquired, what he desired, or sough: (Lth, * S, * M, * A, * Msb, K: *) he succeeded, or was successful: (Msb:) he won, was victorious, or gained the victory: (Lth, T:) and AiZRafara↓ [originally AiZotafara] signifies the same as Zafira. (S.) You say, Zafira bihi and Ealayohi, and Zafirahu, He attained it, got it, got possession of it, or acquired it; (M, K;) and in like manner AiZRafara↓, of the measure AifotaEala. (K.) And Zafirotu biAlDRaAlRapi I found the stray, or lost beast. (Msb.) And Zafira biEaduwRihi (S, A, Msb) and Ealayohi, (Akh, S, A,) and Zafirahu, (S,) He gained the victory, or mastery, over his enemy; he overcame him. (S, * A, Msb. *) ― -b2- [Hence,] Zafirati AlnRaAqapu laqaHFA (tropical:) The she-camel took, or received, impregnation. (A, TA.) And maA Zafiratoka EayoniI (AZ, T, S, A, K) munocu HiynK (AZ, T) or munocu zamaAnKi (S, A) (tropical:) My eye hath not seen thee [for some time]: (AZ, T, S, A, K:) like maA Oaxacatoka. (AZ, T.) ＝ -A4- [Zafara in the dial. of Himyer is said by Freytag, on the authority of the Kitáb el-Addád, to signify He sat.]

2 ZfRr fiyhi c
2. ZfRr fiyhi, (A, K,) inf. n. taZofiyrN, (S,) He inserted his nail into it; (S, A, K;) namely, an apple, and the like, (S, K,) a cucumber, and a melon: (A:) and [in like manner] AiZRafara↓, of the measure AifotaEala, he stuck, or fixed, his nail [into a thing]; (S, K, TA;) and so AiTRafara, with the unpointed T. (TA.) You say, ZfRr fulaAnN fiI wajohi fulaAnK Such a one stuck his nail into the flesh of the face of such a one, and wounded it. (TA.) And nayRaba fiI laHomihi waZafRara He stuck his dog-tooth and his nail into his flesh, and wounded it. (A.) And ZfRr fulaAnN fiI kacaA wanayRaba (tropical:) Such a one clung to, caught to, or took fast hold upon, such a thing. (A in art. nyb.) Also ZfRrhu; and Zafarahu↓, aor.
Zafira
; (M, K;) and AiZRafarahu↓, in the K erroneously written OaZofarahu; (TA;) He stuck his nail into his face; (M, K;) and so AiTRafarahu, with T. (TA.) And ZfRrhu [He clawed it;] he stuck his nail into it, (namely, anything,) and broke it, or made a mark [or scratch] upon it. (M.) And AiZRafara↓ AlSRaqoru AlTRaAYira The hawk seized the bird with his talons. (K.) ― -b2- ZfRr said of baqol [or herbs, or leguminous plants,] (tropical:) They put forth what resembled the OaZofaAr [or talons] of the bird. (M, TA.) And said of the Earofaj, (K, TA,) and of the OaroTaI, (TA,) (tropical:) It put forth what resembled OaZofaAr, (K, TA,) when it put forth its [leaves termed] xuwS. (TA.) (M, TA.) [Or,] said of a plant, (Ks, T, S,) inf. n. as above, (Ks, T,) (assumed tropical:) It came forth; (Ks, T;) from AlOaZofaAr: (T:) or it came forth of the measure of the Zufor [or nail]. (S.) And ZfRrt AlOaroDu (assumed tropical:) The land put forth plants, or herbage, that might be uprooted (yumokinu QHotifaAWuhu, so in the M, in the K QHotifaAruhu,) with the nail, (M,) or with the fingers. (K.) ― -b3- ZfRr vawobahu, (M, and so in a copy of the K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) (assumed tropical:) He perfumed his garment (M, and thus in that copy of the K) with what is termed Zufor: (M:) or ZfRr vawobahu biAlOaZofaAri he perfumed his garment with what are termed OaZofaAr. (So accord. to other copies of the K.) ― -b4- And ZfRr Aljiloda, (K,) or ZafRarotu Aljiloda, (M,) (assumed tropical:) He, (K,) or I, (M,) rubbed the skin in order that its OaZofaAr (M, K) which means its creased parts (M) might become smooth. (M, K.) ＝ -A2- ZfRrhu also signifies, and so AZfrhu↓, [He caused him to attain, get, get possession of, or acquire, what he desired, or sought: he caused him to succeed, or to be successful: and] He (God) caused him to be victorious, to gain the victory, or to overcome. (A.) You say, ZfRrhu bihi (S, M) and Ealayohi, (M, TA,) inf. n. as above; (S;) and bh AZfrhu↓ (S, M, Msb) and Elyh; (M, Msb;) He (God, S, M, or a man, Msb) caused him to gain the victory over him, or to overcome him, (M, Msb,) namely, his enemy. (T.) ― -b3- And ZfRrhu, (M, K,) inf. n. as above, (K,) He prayed for him that he might attain what he desired, or sought; or that he might be successful, or victorious. (M, K.)

Zlf:) or to a beast, or bird, that does not prey; [as well as to man;] that of such as preys being termed mixolabN: (M:) [and in the present day applied also to the spur of a cock:] it is of the masc. gender: (Lh, M, Msb:) the pl. (of ZuforN, S, M, Msb, &c.) is OaZofaArN (S, M, Msb, K, &c.) and sometimes OaZofurN, (Msb,) [both of which are pls. of pauc., but the former is used as a pl. of mult. also,]. and (of OuZofuwrN, M, Msb, or
of OaZofaArN, and therefore a pl. pl., M) OaZaAfiyru: (M, Msb, K:) that OuZofuwrN↓ is a sing. [and not like OuboquwrN which is a quasi-pl. n.] is shown by the saying of a poet,
maA bayona luqomatihaA AlOuwlaI UicaA QnoHadarato
wabayona OuxoraI taliyhaA qiysu OuZofuwri
(K) or qiydu OuZofuwri (Msb) [i. e. What is between her first morsel, when it descends into her throat, and another that follows it, is the measure of a finger-nail]: or, as some relate it, UicaA Qzodaradato [when she swallows]; and it is thus cited [in the T and] in the “ Basáïr ” of the author of the K. (TA.) The phrase kulRa ciI ZufurK in the Kur vi. 147 comprises camels and ostriches; (so in the T and TS and L; but in the K, AlOanoEaAm is erroneously put for AlnRaEaAm; TA;) because their manaAsim are like OaZofaAr to them: (T, K, TA:) I'Ab says that it comprises camels; and also ostriches, because they have nails like camels: or any bird that has a mixolab, and any beast that has a solid hoof: or, accord. to Mujáhid and Katádeh, every beast and bird that has not divided toes; as the camel and ostrich and goose and duck. (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AlOaZofaAru is the name of (assumed tropical:) Certain small stars; (S;) certain stars before AlnRasor [meaning AlnRasor AlwaAqiE i. e. the star a of Lyra: app. because regarded as the talons of the nsr]: (K:) or a certain dim star in AlXRaloyaAq [q. v., i. e. the constellation Lyra]. (Kzw.) ― -b3- [Hence also,] UinRahu lakaliylu AlZRufori, (T,) or UinRahu lamaqoluwmu AlZRufori, (TA,) (tropical:) Verily he is one who does not slay or wound an enemy: (T, TA:) and UinRahu maqoluwmu AlZRufori Eano OacaI AlnRaAsi (tropical:) Verily he is one who does little hurt to mankind. (T, A, TA.) And huwa kaliylu AlZRufori (tropical:) He is weak, or abject, or despicable; (T, S, K, TA;) said of a man; (K, TA;) or so muqalRamu AlZRufori: (K: [in the TA, as from the K, muqalRamu AlOaZofaAri:]) or (tropical:) he is sick, or diseased. (A.) And bihi ZuforN mino maraDK (tropical:) [app. meaning In him is an evil result of a disease, that has clung to him]. (A, TA. [In the A, this immediately follows what here next precedes it; and is immediately followed by the words wacubaAbN Zafira minohu, which seem to be added by way of explanation; thus in my copy; but I think that Zafira minohu here is a mistake for ZafRara fiyhi, and have assumed this to be the case in rendering the phrase.]) ― -b4- And qarRaHotuhu mino Zuforihi UilaI Xuforihi (tropical:) [lit. I wounded him much, from his nail to the edge of his eyelid; but mentioned as tropical; app. meaning from toe to head]; like as one says, mino qaronihi. (A.) ― -b5- And maA baAldRaAri ZuforN, (K,) or mA bAldAr ZuforN walaA XuforN, (A, O,) (tropical:) There is not in the house any one. (A, O, K.) And maA tarakati AlsRanapu ZuforFA walaA XuforFA (tropical:) The year of drought left not anything: and sometimes they said XaforFA, with fet-h, and in this case they said ZaforFA↓, for assimilation. (A in art. Xfr.) And raOayotuhu biZuforihi (tropical:) I saw him himself. (O, K, TA.) ― -b6- Zuforu AlnRasori is the name of (assumed tropical:) A certain plant, (K, TA,) resembling what is [properly] thus termed [i. e. the talon of the vulture]. (TA.) And Zuforu AlqiTRi is the name of (assumed tropical:) Another plant. (K, TA.) ― -b7- And AlZRuforu, (M,) or AlOaZofaAru, (T, M, A, Mgh, O, K, &c.,) for this word in the sense here following has no sing. (T, M, O, K) accord. to the author of the 'Eyn, (M,) but sometimes one said waAHidapN OaZofaArapN↓, which is not allowable by rule, and made the pl. of this to be OaZaAfiyru, (T, O, K, * [mentioned in the M as a pl. of AlZRuforu,]) though, if they formed a sing. from it, it should be ZuforN, (T, O, K,) signifies (tropical:) A certain odoriferous substance, (T, Mgh, O, K,) or a sort thereof, (M,) [i. e. unguis odoratus, (called in the present day Zuforu AlTRiybi and Zuforu AlEiforiyti,) or ungues odorati,] black, (T, M, O,) resembling a Zufor [or nail] (T, M, Mgh, O, K) of a man (M) pulled out (in the M and O and K muqotulaf, and in the T muqalRaf,) from the root thereof, (T, M, O, K, [but in the M, the words which I have rendered “ pulled out ” &c. immediately follow the words DarobN mina AlEiTori Oasowadu,]) or resembling the OaZofaAr [or finger-nails], (A,) and put into duxotap [or incense]: (T, M, O:) and, accord. to the K, ZafaArN↓, sometimes imperfectly decl., i. e. ZafaAru↓, signifies the same; but this is very strange, for [SM says] I have referred to the M and T and O and other lexicons without finding them to have mentioned in this sense any term but AlOaZofaAru or AlZRuforu: accord. to the “ Minháj, ” OaZofaAru AlTRiybi are pieces of an odoriferous substance resembling the OaZofaAr [properly so called]; they are said by [the Arabic translator of] Dioscorides to be of the nature of the shards of shells, [so I render mino jinosi OaxozaAfi AlSRadafi, supposing AxzAf to be here used tropically,] found in an island of the Sea of India where is the sunobul [or spikenard], a sort whereof is [called] qulozumiIR [i. e. of El-Kulzum], and another which is [called] baAbiliIR [i. e. of Bábil], black and small, and the best is that which inclines to whiteness, which drifts to El-Yemen and El-Bahreyn. (TA.) [Forskål, in his “ Descr. Animalium ” &c., mentions what here follows, among the animal substances of the materia medica of Cairo, in page 143: “ Unguis odoratus. (Opercula Cochl.) Dofr el afrît, Dfr AlEfryt i. e. unguis dæmonis. E Mochha per Sués. Arabes etiam afferunt. Nigritis fumigatorium est. ” (Dfr is here written, agreeably with the usual vulgar pronunciation, for Zufor.) See also qusoTN,] ― -b8- OaZofaArN signifies also (assumed tropical:) Large qirodaAn [or ticks]. (S, O, K.) ― -b9- And (assumed tropical:) The creased parts of a skin. (M, TA.) ― -b10- And the Zufor of a bow is (tropical:) The part in the curved end that is beyond the place where the string is tied, to the extremity: (As, T, S, M, * O, K: *) or the end of the bow: (K:) or each end of the bow, beyond the place where the string is tied: (A:) pl. ZifarapN. (M, TA.) ― -b11- See also ZafarapN.

1 ZalRa c
1. ZalRa, aor. yaZilRu, inf. n. ZilaAlapN: see 4. ＝ -A2- ZalRa, (T, M, Msb, K,) first pers. Zalilotu, (T, S, M, O, Msb, K,) [and accord. to SM Zalalotu also, for he says that] the verb is of the class of manaEa as well as of the class of taEiba, (TA,) and Zalotu, (T, S, * M, O, K,) likened to lasotu, (M, K, *) formed by rejecting the former l in Zalilotu, (T, O,) and Zilotu, which is [also] originally Zalilotu, (Sb, T, M, O, K,) formed by transferring to the Z the vowel of the rejected l, (Sb, T, M, O,) anomalously, (Sb, M,) the latter of the dial. of the people of El-Hijáz; (T;) aor. yaZalRu; (S, * M, O, * Msb, K;) imperative AiZolalo and Zalo (T) [and it is implied in the M voce qarRa that one says also AiZolilo and Zilo, which indicates that the aor. is also yaZilRu, but this requires confirmation, which I have not anywhere found]; inf. n. ZuluwlN (T, S, M, O, Msb, K) and ZalRN (M, K) and ZilRN; (thus also in a copy of the M; [but this I think doubtful;]) accord. to Lth, (T,) or Kh, (Msb,) [i. e. accord. to the author of the 'Eyn,] is said only of a thing that is done in the day, or daytimes; (T, S, M, O, Msb;) like as baAta, aor. yabiytu, is said only of a thing that is done in the night: (T:) it is an incomplete [i. e. a non-attributive] verb, relating to a time in which is a shade from the sun, from morning to evening, or from sunrise to sunset: (Esh-Shiháb, TA:) one says, ZalRa fulaAnN nahaArahu SaAYimFA [Such a one was during his day fasting; or he passed his day fasting]: (Lth, T:) and ZalRa nahaArahu yafoEalu kacaA [He was in, or during, his day doing such a thing; or he passed his day doing such a thing]: (M, K:) and Zalilotu OaEomalu kacaA [I was in the day or daytime, or I passed the day, doing such a thing; or] I did such a thing in the day or daytime. (S, O, Msb. *) In the saying of 'Antarah,
walaqado Oabiytu EalaI AlTRawaI waOaZalRuhu
HatRaI OanaAla bihi kariyma AlmaOokali
[app. meaning And verily I pass the night in hunger, and I pass the day in it, that I may attain thereby plentiful eating], OaZalRuhu is for OaZalRu Ealayohi. (S, O.) And accord. to some, (TA,) ZalRa layolahu occurs in poetry; (M, K, TA;) so that one says, ZalRa layolahu yafoEalu kacaA [He was in, or during, his night, or he passed his night, doing such a thing]: but it is said that in this case the verb has the meaning next following. (TA.) ― -b2- And it signifies also He, or it, became; syn. SaAra: (Er-Rághib, TA:) being in this sense likewise an incomplete [i. e. a non-attributive] verb, divested of that meaning of time which it radically denotes; as in the phrase in the Kur [xvi. 60 and xliii. 16], ZalRa wajohuhu musowadRFA [His face becomes black]: so says Ibn-Málik: (TA:) or this may mean his face continues all the day black: (Bd in xvi. 60:) and one says also, ZalRa yafoEalu kacaA meaning He continued doing such a thing: this too is mentioned by Ibn-Málik, and is of the dial. of the people of Syria. (TA.) ― -b3- It is also a complete [i. e. an attributive] verb as meaning He, or it, continued; as is said in the Expos. of the “ Shifè, ” and by Ibn-Málik; and, as Ibn-Málik likewise says, it was, or became, long. 2. ZllRehu Ealayohi [He made it to give shade over him, or it,] (M,) inf. n. taZoliylN. (O.) It is said in the Kur [vii. 160, and the like is said in ii. 54], waZalRalonaA Ealayohimu AlgamaAma And we made the clouds to give shade over them. (M.) ― -b2- [And ZllRehu signifies He shaded him, or it. See an ex. in a verse of Jereer in art. rdf, conj. 3.] lekino EalaI AlOavalaAti laHomN laA yuZalRalu [But at the tamarisk-trees is flesh that will not be shaded, or, accord. to the reading given by Meyd, biAlOavalaAti,] is a prov., said by Beyhes, in allusion to the flesh of his slain brothers, on the occasion of persons saying, ZalRiluwA laHoma jazuwrikumo [Shade ye the flesh of your slaughtered camel]. 4 AZlR c
4. AZlR, said of a day, It was, (S, O,) or became, (M, K,) shady, or a day having shade: (S, M, O, K:) or it was a day having clouds, or other [causes of shade]: (T:) or it was continually shady; as also ZalRa↓, aor. yaZilRu, inf. n. ZilaAlapN. (Msb.) ― -b2- And, said of a thing, [It extended its shade; or] its shade extended; as also ZlRl↓. (Msb.) ＝ -A2- OaZalRatoniI AlXRajarapu [The tree shaded me, or afforded me shade]: and in like manner one says of other things than trees. (S, O.) OaZalRaka said of a building, or of a mountain, or of a cloud, means It protected thee, and cast its shade upon thee. (Mgh.) ― -b2- [Hence,] AZlRhu (assumed tropical:) He took him into his shelter, or protection: (TA:) or he guarded, or protected, him, and placed him within the scope of his might, or power of resistance or defence. (Er-Rághib, TA.) ― -b3- And OaZalRaniI (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) covered me: (M, K:) or it approached me, or drew near to me, so as to cast its shade upon me: (K:) or it has both of these meanings: (M:) or OaZalRaka means he, (T, S,) or it, (O,) approached thee, or drew near to thee, as though he, or it, cast his, or its, shade upon thee. (T, S, O.) And hence one says, OaZalRaka OamorN (assumed tropical:) An event approached thee, or drew near to thee: (S, O:) and in like manner one says of a month. (T, S, O.) And AZlR [alone] (assumed tropical:) It (a thing) advanced: or approached, or drew near. (Msb.) And i. q. OaXorafa [app. as meaning (assumed tropical:) He, or it, became within sight, or view]. (Msb.)

5 taZalRaRa

10 AstZlR c
10. AstZlR, (T,) or AstZlR biAliZRilRi, (Msb, TA,) He (a man, T) sheltered, or protected, himself by means of the shade: (T, TA:) or the latter means he inclined to the shade and sat in it. (M, K.) And AstZlR mina AlXRaIoCi and bihi means taZalRala↓ [i. e. he shaded himself (tZlRl being quasi-pass. of ZalRalahu) from the thing and by means of it]. (M, K.) You say, AstZlR bihi mina AlXRamosi [He shaded himself with it, or by means of it, from the sun]. (T.) And AstZlR biAlXRajarapi He shaded and sheltered himself by means of the tree. (Ibn-'Abbád, S, O.) ― -b2- AstZlR AldRamu The blood was in the jawof [or belly, or interior of the belly, or the chest]. (T, O, K, TA. [In the CK, mn Aljawofi is put for fiI Aljawofi.]) ― -b3- AstZlRt AlEayonu,
(T, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or AlEuyuwnu, (K,) The eye, (T, Ibn-'Abbád, O,) meaning that of a she-camel, (Ibn-'Abbád, O,) or the eyes, (K,) sank, or became depressed, in the head. (T, Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b4- And AstZlR Alkaromu The grape-vine became luxuriant, or abundant and dense, in its branches whereon were the bunches. (M, K.)

ZilRN c
ZilRN properly signifies Shade; i. e. the light of the sun without the rays: when there is no light, it is ZulomapN, not ZilRN: (S, O:) contr. of DiHRN: (M, K:) or i. q. faIoCN: (K:) so some say: (M:) or so the [common] people say: (IKt, Msb:) or the former is [shade] in the morning; and the latter is in the evening: (M, K:) or, accord. to IKt, the former is in the morning and in the evening; but the latter is only after the declining of the sun from the meridian: ISk says that the former is from the rising of the sun to its declining; and the latter, from the declining to the setting: Th says that the ZilR of a tree &c. is in the morning; and the faIoC, in the evening: (Msb:) Ru-beh says, (M, Msb,) any place, (M,) or any thing, (Msb,) upon which the sun has been and which it has quitted is termed ZilRN and faIoCN; (M, Msb;) but a thing [or place] upon which the sun has not been is termed ZilRN [only]; and hence it is said that the sun annuls, or supersedes, the ZilR, and the faIoC annuls, or supersedes, the sun: (Msb:) AHeyth says, the ZilR is anything upon which the sun has not come; and the term faIoC is applied only after the declining of the sun; the faIoC being eastwards and the ZilR being westwards; and the ZilR being termed ZilR from the beginning of the day to the declining of the sun; after which it is termed faIoC until the night: (T, TA:) one says the ZilR of Paradise, but not its faIoC, because the sun will never replace its ZilR; but En-Nábighah El-Jaadee has assigned to Paradise faIoC having ZilaAl: (M, TA:) in a verse of Aboo-Sakhr ElHudhalee, ZilRN is made fem. as meaning maniyRap [i. e. death]: (Ham p. 161:) the pl. [of mult.] is ZilaAlN (S, M, O, K) and ZuluwlN and [of pauc.] OaZolaAlN. (M, O, K.) The saying of a rájiz,
kaOanRamaA wajohuka ZilRN mino Hajaro
[As though thy face were a shade of a stone] is said to mean hardness of face, and shamelessness: or the being black in the face: (T, TA:) for the Arabs say that there is nothing more dense in shade than a stone. (TA.) qado DaHaA ZilRuhu [His shade, or shadow, has become sun] is said of the dead. (TA.) marRa binaA kaOanRahu ZilRu ciYobK [He passed by us as though he were the shadow of a wolf] means swiftly, as does a wolf. (M.) AinotaEalato ZilaAlahaA (assumed tropical:) [They made their shadows to be as though they were sandals to them] is said of camels or other beasts when it is midday in summer and they have no shadow [but such as is beneath them]: a rájiz says,
qado waradato tamoXiI EalaI ZilaAlihaA
wacaAbati AlXRamosu EalaI qilaAlihaA
[They came to the water walking upon their shadows, and the sun was intensely hot upon the tops of their heads and humps]. (T.) And one says, huwa yatobaEu ZilRa nafosihi (tropical:) [He follows the shadow of himself; i. e. a thing that he will not overtake; for], as a poet says, the shadow that goes with thee thou wilt not overtake by following: and huwa yubaAriI ZilRa nafosihi (tropical:) [He strives to outstrip the shadow of himself], meaning that he walks with a proud and self-conceited gait: so in the A. (TA.) And Ainotaqalotu Eano ZilRiI (tropical:) I left my state, or condition. (TA.) And taraka AlZRaboIu ZilRahu: so in the T and S and O: (TA:) but [said to be] correctly, Oatorukuhu taroka AlZRaboIi ZilRahu, (K,) or laOatorukanRahu, (M, TA,) i. e. [I will forsake him, or I will assuredly forsake him, as the gazelle forsakes] the place of its shade: (O, TA:) [each, however, is app. right; and the former is the more agreeable with the following explanations:] a prov., (M,) applied to the man who is wont to take fright and flee; for the gazelle, when it takes fright and flees from a thing, never returns to it: (S, O, K:) by the ZilR is here meant the covert in which it shades and shelters itself in the vehemence of the heat; then the hunter comes to it and rouses it, and it will not return thither; and one says, taraka AlZRaboIu ZilRahu, meaning the place of its shade: it is applied to him who takes fright and flees from a thing, and forsakes it so as not to return to it; and to the case of a man's forsaking his companion. (Meyd.) [vaqiylu AlZRilRi as applied to a man, see expl. in art. vql: see also Har p. 250, where it is indicated that it may be rendered One whose shadow, even, is oppressive, and therefore much more so is his person.] In the phrase walaA QlZRilRu walaA QloHaruwru, (M, K) in the Kur [xxxv. 20], Th says, accord. to some, (M,) AlZRilRu means Paradise; (M, K;) and AlHaruwru, the fire [of Hell]: but he adds, I say that AlZRilRu is the ZilR itself [i. e. shade], and AlHaruwru is the HarR itself [i. e. heat]: (M: [see also HaruwrN:]) and Er-Rághib says that ZilRN is sometimes assigned to anything; whether it be approved, as in the phrase above mentioned; or disapproved, as in waZilRK mino yaHomuwmK in the Kur [lvi. 42, meaning And shade of smoke, or black smoke]. (TA.) And AlZRilaAlu means ZilaAlu AljanRapi [The shades of Paradise]: (Fr, T, O, K, TA:) in some copies of the K, waAlZRilaAlu AljanRapu, which is a mistake: (TA:) [but this requires consideration; for] El-'Abbás Ibn- 'Abd-El-Muttalib says,
mino qabolihaA Tibota fiI AlZRilaAli wafiI
musotawodaEK Hayovu yuxoSafu Alwaraqu
[Before it thou wast good in, or in the shades of, Paradise, and in a depositary in the part where leaves are sewed together to conceal the pudenda]; (T, O, TA;) i. e. before thy descent to the earth (to which the pronoun in qblhA relates), thou wast good in the loins of Adam when he was in Paradise. (TA.) AljanRapu taHota ZilaAli AlsRuyuwfi [Paradise is beneath the shades of the swords] is a trad., meaning that fighting against unbelievers is a way of attaining to Paradise. (Marg. note in a copy of the “ Jámi' es-Sagheer.) mulaAEibu ZilRihi is an appellation of A certain bird; [see art. lEb;] and one says mulaAEibaA ZilRihimaA; and mulaAEibaAtu ZilRihinRa: but when you make them indeterminate, you say mulaAEibaAtu OaZolaAlihinRa. (T, O, K. [But in the TA in art. lEb, it is said that one dualizes and pluralizes both nouns, because the appellation becomes determinate.]) ― -b2- ZilRu AllRayoli means (tropical:) The blackness of the night: (T, S, O, Msb;) metaphorically thus termed; (S;) as in the saying, OataAnaA fiI ZilRi AllRayoli [He came to us in the blackness of the night]: (S, O:) or it signifies junoHu AllRayoli [app. as meaning the darkness, and confusedness, of the night; see junoHN]; (M, TA;) or so AlZRilRu: (K:) or this means the night, (M, K, TA,) itself; (M, TA;) so the astronomers say: (TA:) all the night is ZilRN: and so is all the period from the shining of the dawn to the rising of the sun. (T.) ― -b3- ZilRu AlnRahaAri is The colour of the day when the sun predominates over it [app. meaning when the light of the sun predominates over that of the early dawn]. (K.) ― -b4- ZilRu AlsRaHaAbi means Such, of the clouds, as conceal the sun: or the blackness of the clouds. (M, K.) ― -b5- And ZilaAlu AlbaHori means The waves of the sea; (O, K, TA;) because they are raised so as to shade the ship and those that are in it. (TA.) ― -b6- ZilRN also signifies A xayaAl (M, O, K) that is seen, (M, K,) [i. e. an apparition, a phantom, or a thing that one sees like a shadow, i. e. what we term a shade,] of the jinn, or genii, and of others: (M, O, K:) or the like of a xayaAl of the jinn. (T.) ― -b7- Also Anything that shades one. (TA.) ― -b8- And it is the subst. from OaZalRaniI AlXRaIoCu meaning “ the thing covered me; ” (M, K;) [i. e. it means A covering;] in which sense Th explains it in the phrase UilaI ZilRK ciI valaAvi XuEabK [in the Kur lxxvii. 30, Unto a covering having three parts, or divisions]; saying, the meaning is that the fire will have covered them; not that its ZilR will be like that of the present world. (M. [See XuEobapN.]) And ZilRu AlXRaIoCi means (assumed tropical:) That which serves for the veiling, covering, or protecting, of the thing; syn. kinRuhu. (M.) [Hence] one says, fulaAnN yaEiyXu fiI ZilRi fulaAnK i. e. (assumed tropical:) [Such a one lives] in the shelter, or protection, of such a one. (T, * S, O, Msb, * K. *) And AlsRuloTaAnu ZilRu QllRehi fiI AlOaroDi, (O, TA,) a saying of the Prophet, (O,) [meaning (assumed tropical:) The sovereign, or ruling, power is God's means of defence in the earth,] because he wards off
harm from the people like as the ZilR [properly so called] wards off the harm of the heat of the sun: (TA:) or the meaning is, (assumed tropical:) God's means of protection: or God's xaASRap [or special servant]. (O, TA.) ― -b9- Also (assumed tropical:) Might; or power of resistance or defence: (M, K, TA:) whence [as some say] its usage in the Kur xiii. 35, and the usage of [the pl.] ZilaAl in xxxvi. 56 and in lxxvii. 41: [but the primary signification is more appropriate in these instances:] and so in the saying, jaEalaniI fiI ZilRihi [i. e. (assumed tropical:) He placed me within the scope of his might, or power of resistance or defence]: so says Er-Rághib. (TA.) ― -b10- And (assumed tropical:) A state of life ample in its means or circumstances, unstraitened, or plentiful, and easy, pleasant, soft, or delicate. (TA.) ― -b11- Also (assumed tropical:) The beginning of winter. (T, O. [Accord. to the copies of the K, of youthfulness: but I think that AlXRabaAb in this instance, in the K, is evidently a mistranscription for AlXRitaMC.]) And (assumed tropical:) The vehemence (T, O, K) of the heat (T, O) of summer. (T, O, K.) ― -b12- Also (assumed tropical:) The XaxoS [as meaning person of a human being, and as meaning the bodily or corporeal form or figure or substance which one sees from a distance, or the material substance,] of anything; (M, K, TA; [in the second and third of which is added, “ or its kinR, ” a signification which I have mentioned above on the authority of the M;]) because of its [apparent] blackness [or darkness, resembling that of a shade or shadow]: (M, TA:) whence the saying, laA yufaAriqu ZilRiI ZilRaka (assumed tropical:) [My person will not quit thy person]; like the saying, laA yufaAriqu sawaAdiI sawaAdaka: and the following exs. have been cited as instances of ZilR in the sense of XaxoS: the saying of a poet,
lamRaA nazalonaA rafaEonaA ZilRa OaxobiyapK
[as though meaning When we alighted, we raised the material fabric of tents], for it is said that they do not set up the ZilR which is the faIoC, but they only set up the tents; and the saying of another,
tatabRaEa OafoyaMCa AlZRilaAli EaXiyRapF
[as though meaning He followed the shadows of the material objects in the evening]: but Er-Rághib says that the former means, we raised the tents, and so raised the ZilR thereof; and in the other ex., AlZlAl is a general term, and AlfaIoC [or AfyMC] is a special term, so that it is an instance of the UiDaAfap of a thing to its kind [i. e. of prefixing a noun to one significant of its kind]. (TA.) [See also ZalaAlapN.] ― -b13- And accord. to Ibn- 'Abbád, (O,) it signifies also The nap, or villous substance, upon the surface of a garment, or piece of cloth; syn. ziYobirN. (O, K.)

ZalRapN c
ZalRapN i. q. UiqaAmapN [Continuance, residence, abode, &c.]. (K.) ― -b2- And i. q. SiHRapN: thus accord. to the copies of the K; but this may be a mistranscription; for Az and others mention, among the significations of ZlRp, [in a copy of the T, written in this case, as in others, ZulRap↓,] that of SayoHapN [q. v.]. (TA.)

ZulRapN c
ZulRapN A thing that covers, or protects, [or shades,] one, overhead: accord. to Lth, i. q. maZalRapN↓ or miZalRapN meaning a thing that shades one from the sun: (T:) see an ex. voce miZalRapN: a covering: and i. q. buroTulRapN: (M, K:) this latter word correctly signifies a miZalRap for the summer: (TA in art. brTl:) and a thing by which one is protected from the cold and the heat: (M:) anything that protects and shades one, as a building or a mountain or a cloud: (Mgh:) the first portion that shades (AZ, S, K) of a cloud (AZ, S) or of clouds; (K;) accord. to Er-Rághib, mostly said of that which is deemed unwholesome, and which is disliked; whence the use of the word in the Kur vii. 170: (TA:) and what shades one, of trees: (K:) or anything that forms a covering over one, (T, TA,) or shades one: (T:) and [particularly] a thing like the SufRap [q. v.], (S, M, O, K,) by which one protects himself from the heat and the cold: (K:) or, accord. to the lawyers, ZulRapu AldRaAri means the sudRap [or projecting roof] over the door of the house: or that of which the beams have one end upon the house and the other end upon the wall of the opposite neighbour: (Mgh:) pl. ZulalN (S, M, O, K) and ZilaAlN. (M, K.) [See also ZalaAlN.] One says also, daAmato ZulRapu AlZRilRi and AlZRilRi ZilaAlapu↓, meaning That whereby one shades himself, (K, TA,) of trees, or of stones, or of other things, (TA,) [continued.] EacaAbu yawomi AlZRulRapi, in the Kur. [xxvi. 189], is said to mean [The punishment of the day of] clouds beneath which was a hot wind (samuwm): (S, O, K:) or an overshadowing cloud, beneath which they collected themselves together, seeking protection thereby from the heat that came upon them, whereupon it covered them, (T, * K, TA,) and they perished beneath it: (T, TA:) or, accord. to some, i. q. EacaAbu yawomi AlSRufRapi. (T: see art. Sf.) And lahumo mino fawoqihimo ZulalN mina QlnRaAri wamino taHotihimo ZulalN, in the Kur [xxxix. 18], means To them shall be above them coverings of fire, and beneath them coverings to those below them; Hell consisting of stages, one beneath another. (T, TA.) Seditions, or conflicts and factions, are mentioned in a trad. as being like Zulal, by which are meant Mountains, and clouds: and El-Kumeyt likens waves of the sea to Zulal. (TA.) And [the pl.] ZulalN is used as meaning The chambers of a prison. (M, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ZalRapN.

ZilRapN c
ZilRapN i. q. ZilaAlN; (T, K, TA;) app. a pl. of ZaliylN, like as TilRapN is of TaliylN. (TA.)

ZalalN c
ZalalN Water that is beneath a tree, (O,) or beneath trees, (K,) upon which the sun does not come. (O, K.) [See also DalalN.]

ZalaAlN c
ZalaAlN, like saHaAbN, [so accord. to the K, but in my copies of the S, ZilaAl↓,] A thing that shades one, (IAar, S, O, K, TA,) such as a cloud, (IAar, S, TA,) and the like. (IAar, TA.) [See also ZulRapN.]

ZilaAlN c
ZilaAlN pl. of ZilRN: (S, M, O, K:) ― -b2- and of ZulRapN. (M, K.) ― -b3- [Also, app., pl. of ZaliylN: see ZilRapN. ― -b4- Freytag has app. understood it to be expl. in the K as syn. with maZalRapN; though it certainly is not.] ― -b5- See also ZalaAlN.

makaAnN ZaliylN c
makaAnN ZaliylN A place having shade: (M, K:) or having constant shade. (T, S, M, O, K.) And hence ZilRN ZaliylN (M, K) Constant shade: (S:) or extensive shade: (O:) or in this case the latter word denotes intensiveness [meaning dense]; (M, K, TA;) being like XaAEirN in the phrase XiEorN XaAEirN. (TA.) ZilRFA ZaliylFA in the Kur iv. 60 is said by Er-Rághib to be an allusion to ease and pleasantness of life. (TA.) One says also OayokapN ZaliylapN A collection of trees tangled, or luxuriant, or abundant and dense. (TA.) In the saying of Uheyhah Ibn-El-Juláh, describing palm-trees,
hiIa AlZRilRu fiI AlHarRi HaqRa AlZRali
li waAlmanoZaru AlOaHosanu AlOajomalu
The final character of line one and the initial character of line two are unclear. [ISd says] in my opinion, he means AlXRaIoCu AlZRaliylu HaqRa AlZRaliyli; [so that the verse should be rendered They are the shade in the heat, the shady thing, the extremely shady, and the most goodly, the most beautiful, thing at which one looks; (see the phrase hecaA AlEaAlimu HaqRa AlEaAlimi, voce HaqRN;)] the inf. n. being put in the place of the subst. (M.) laA ZaliylK in the Kur [lxxvii. 31] means Not profitable as the shade in protecting from the heat. (TA.)

ZalaAlapN c
ZalaAlapN, (M, TA,) with fet-h, (TA,) the subst. from the verb in the phrase ZalRalonaA Ealayohimu AlgamaAma [expl. above, see 2; as such app. meaning either The making to give shade, like the inf. n. taZoliylN, or a thing that gives shade, like ZilaAlapN]. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And i. q. XaxoSN [expl. above, see ZilRN, last quarter]: (O, K:) and so TalaAlapN, with T. (O.)

ZilaAlapN c
ZilaAlapN: see ZulRapN. ― -b2- Also A cloud that one sees by itself, and of which one sees the shadow upon the earth. (K.) ― -b3- And one says, raOayotu ZilaAlapF mina AlTRayori i. e. gayaAbapF [app. meaning I saw a covert, or place of concealment, of birds]. (TA.)

ZaliylapN c
ZaliylapN A place in which a little water collects and stagnates in a water-course and the like: (Lth, T:) or a place in which water collects and stagnates in the lower part of the torrent of a valley: (M, K:) or the like of an excavated hollow in the interior of a water-course, such that the water stops, and remains therein: (AA, O:) pl. ZalaAYilu. (Lth, AA, T, O.) And A meadow (rawoDap) abounding with collections of trees, or of dense and tangled trees: (AA, T, O, K:) pl. as above. (K.)

ZulRayolapN c
ZulRayolapN A thing which a man makes for himself,
of trees, or of a garment, or piece of cloth, by which to protect himself from the heat of the sun: a vulgar word. (TA.)

ZuloZulN c
ZuloZulN i. q. suEonN, i. e. A miZalRap↓ [q. v.; or as expl. in the L, in art. sEn, a ZulRap (q. v.), or a thing like the ZulRap, which is made upon the flat house-tops, for the purpose of guarding against the dew that comes from the direction of the sea in the time of the greatest heat]; on the authority of IAar. (T. [Accord. to the O and K, i. q. sufunN, which is evidently a mistranscription.])

OaZalRu c
OaZalRu [More, and most, dense in shade]. The Arabs say, layosa XaIoCN OaZalRa mino HajarK [There is not anything more dense in shade than a stone]. (TA.) ― -b2- And OaZalR, [as a subst., i. e. OaZalRN accord. to a general rule, or, if regarded as originally an epithet, it may be OaZalRu,] by poetic license OaZolal, (S, M, O, K,) signifies The under part, (S, O,) or the concealed part, (M, AHei, K,) of the manosim, (S, M, O, K,) or of the xufR, (AHei, TA,) [the former app. here used, as it is said be in other cases, in the same sense as the latter, meaning the foot,] of the camel; (S, M, O, AHei, K;) so called because of its being concealed: (AHei, TA:) and, (M, K,) in a human being, (M,) AlOaZalRu signifies baTonu AlUiSobaEi; (M, K;) and [ISd says] this is in my opinion the right explanation; but it is said that OaZalRu AlUinosaAni signifies buTuwnu OaSaAbiEihi, which means the portion, of what is next to the fore part [of the bottom] of the foot, from the root of the great toe to the root of the little toe, of the human being: (M:) the pl. is ZulRN, which is anomalous, (M, K,) or formed after the manner of the pl. of an epithet: (M:) or AlZRulRu fiI AlUinosaAni means the roots, or bases, (OuSuwl) of what are termed buTuwnu AlOaSaAbiEi, next to the fore part [of the bottom] of the foot. (Ibn-'Abbád, O.) Hence the prov., Uino yadoma OaZalRuka faqado naqiba xufRiI [If the fore part of the sole of thy foot be bleeding, the sole of my foot has become worn through, in holes: see naqiba]: said to the complainer to him who is in a worse condition than he. (AHei, TA.)

mZlR c
mZlR [app. maZilRN, being from ZalRa of which the aor. is yaZilRu; A place of shade, or of continual shade]. One says, hecaA munaAxiI wamaHalRiI wabayotiI wamZlRiI [This is my nightly resting-place for the camels, and my place of abode, and my tent, and my place of shade, or of continual shade]. (TA.)

muZilRN c
muZilRN A thing having shade; by means of which one shades himself; as also muZalRilN↓. (Msb.) And [A cloudy day;] a day having clouds: or having continual shade. (TA.)

miZalRapN c
miZalRapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and maZalRapN, (T, M, Msb, K,) the former with kesr to the m as an instrumental noun, (Msb,) [and the latter with fet-h as a noun of place,] A large tent of [goats'] hair; (S, O, Msb;) more ample than the xibaMC; so says El-Fárábee: (Msb:) one of the kinds of tents of the Arabs of the desert, the largest of the tents of [goats'] hair; next after which is the wasuwT; and then, the xibaMC, which is the smallest of the tents of [goats'] hair; so says AZ: but Aboo-Málik says that the mZlRp and the xbMC are small and large: IAar says that the xayomap is of poles roofed with [the panic grass called] vamaAm, and is not of cloths; but the mZlRp is of cloths: (T:) or it is of the tents called Oaxobiyap; (M;) such as is large, of the Oaxobiyap; (K;) and it is said to be only of cloths; and it is large, having a riwaAq [q. v.]; but sometimes it is of one oblong piece of cloth (XuqRap), and of two such pieces, and of three; and sometimes it has a kifaMC, which is its hinder part: or, accord. to Th, it is peculiarly of [goats'] hair: (M:) see also ZulRapN, and ZuloZulN: the pl. is maZaAlRu; (M, Msb;) and maZaAli or maZaAliI occurs at the end of a verse of Umeiyeh Ibn-Abee-'Áïdh El-Hudhalee, for maZaAlRi; the [latter] l being either elided, or changed into I. (M.) EilRapN maA EilRapu OawotaAdK waOaxilRapK waEamadi AlmiZalRapi AuboruzuwA liSihorikumo ZulRapN↓ [A pretext: what is the pretext of tentpegs, and of pins for fastening together the edges of the pieces of the tent-cloth, and of the poles of the large tent? go ye forth: he who has married among you has a tent for shade from the sun:] is a prov., and was said by a girl who had been married to a man, and whose family delayed to conduct her to her husband, urging in excuse that they had not the apparatus of the tent: she said this to urge them, and to put a stop to their excuse: (Meyd, TA: *) and the prov. is applied in attributing untruth to pretexts. (Meyd.) ― -b2- Hence, as being likened thereto, (assumed tropical:) A booth, or shed, made of palm-sticks, and covered with [the panic grass called] vumaAm. (Msb.) ― -b3- And The thing [i. e. umbrella] by means of which kings are shaded on the occasion of their riding; called in Pers. Jator. (TA.)

EaroXN muZalRalN c
EaroXN muZalRalN [A booth, or shed, shaded over] is from AlZRilRu. (S.)

muZalRilN c
muZalRilN: see muZilRN.

musotaZilRN c
musotaZilRN Blood that is in the jawof [or belly, or interior of the belly, or the chest]. (T, O.) ― -b2- And [Az says,] I heard a man of the tribe of Teiyi apply the term AlmusotaZilRaAtu [so accord. to a copy of the T, but in the TA AlmusotaZilRu,] to Certain thin flesh, adhering to the interior of the two fetlock-joints of the camel, than which there is in the flesh of the camel none thinner, nor any softer, but there is in it no grease. (T.)

1 ZalaEa c
1. ZalaEa, aor.
ZalaEa
, inf. n.
