ZaloEN, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) said of a camel, (S, O, Msb, K,) and of a man also, (Msb, TA,) and, by Aboo-Dhu-eyb, of a horse, (S, TA,) [and likewise said of a dog, (see ZaAliEN,)] He limped, or halted, syn. gamaza fiI maXoyihi, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) and Earija; (TA;) or was slightly lame: (Mgh:) what it signifies resembles EarajN [or natural lameness], and therefore it is said to be a slight Earaj. (Msb.) One says, Airoqa EalaI ZaloEika, (S, O, L, K,) a prov., (O, L,) meaning Ascend thou the mountain with knowledge [or because] of thy limping, or slight lameness, not jading thyself: (L:) or deal gently with thyself, and burden not thyself with more than thou art able to do: (S:) or impose upon thyself, of what is difficult, [only] what thou art able to do; for he who ascends a ladder or stair, or a mountain, when he is one who limps, or has a slight lameness, deals gently with himself; i. e. exceed not thy proper limit in thy threatening, but see thy deficiency, and thine impotence to execute it: (O, K: *) and some say AiroqaOo, with, meaning rectify thine affair first; (O, K;) or as meaning abstain, and restrain thyself; (O;) or, accord. to AZ, abstain thou, for I know thy vices, or faults: (TA:) or the meaning of both is, be silent, because, or in consideration, of the fault that is in thee. (Ks, O, K. *) One says also, Airoqi EalaI ZaloEika, with kesr to the q, [meaning Charm thou thy slight lameness, to cure it,] from AlrRuqoyapu: and it is said in another prov.,
Airoqi EalaI ZaloEika Oano yuhaADaA
[app. meaning Charm thou thy slight lameness, that it may become mitigated: see art. hyD: the final A in yhADA being what is termed Oalifu AlUiTolaAqi, not a radical]. (O, K.) And qi EalaI ZaloEika [Be cautious, because, or in consideration, of thy limping]: said when there is a vice, or fault, in a man, and you chide him in order that it may not be called to mind: (O, K: [for yacokura in the CK, I read yucokara, as in other copies of the K and in the O:]) and to this he replies, or may reply, waqayotu. (TA. [See also art. wqI.]) And AirobaEo EalaI ZaloEika [Act gently, or with deliberation, or restrain thyself, because of thy limping]; meaning thou art weak; therefore refrain from that which thou art not able to do. (O, K. [See also art. rbE.]) And laA yarobaEu EalaI ZaloEika mano layosa yaHozunuhu Oamoruka, meaning He will not mind thine affair (Hr, O, K) whom thy condition does not grieve: (Hr, O:) or, originally, he will not pause because of thy limping, when thou laggest behind thy companions on account of thy weakness, who does not care for thy case. (Hr, O, K. * [See, again, art. rbE.]) ― -b2- Also, said of a man, (tropical:) He stopped short, and lagged behind. (TA.) ― -b3- ZalaEati AlOaroDu biOaholihaA (tropical:) The land became straitened with its inhabitants, by reason of their multitude; (A 'Obeyd, S, O, K;) it would not bear them, by reason of their multitude, like the beast that limps with its load because of its heaviness. (Z, TA.)
― -b4- ZalaEat said of a bitch, (tropical:) She desired copulation. (As, O, K, TA.) And ZalaEa said of a dog, (assumed tropical:) He desired to copulate. (TA.) ＝ -A2- ZalaEato EayonahaA She (a woman) contracted and inclined her eye. (TA.)

4 AZlE c
4. AZlE He made his camel, or beast, that he rode, to limp, or become lame. (A, TA.)

5 taZalRaEa
5: In the following saying of a poet,
wamaA caAka mino juromK Oatayotuhumu bihi
walaA HasadK minRiI lahumo yataZalRaEu
ISd thinks the meaning to be, [And that was not a crime, or an offence, that I committed against them, nor envy on my part] arising in their minds, and occurring hastily to their understandings. (TA.)

ZalaEN c
ZalaEN, thus with fet-h to the l, A declining from the truth, or from that which is right; and a sin, crime, fault, or misdeed. (TA.)

ZulaAEN c
ZulaAEN A disease in the legs of a beast, not from journeying nor from fatigue, (Lth, K, TA, [in the O inadvertently written DulaAE,]) in consequence of which it limps. (Lth, TA.)

ZaAliEN c
ZaAliEN Limping, or halting; [or slightly lame;] applied to a camel, and a horse, [&c.,] (S,) [i. e.,] to a beast, (TA,) to the male and the female alike, (Lth, O, K, TA,) to the former as a part. n., and to the latter as a possessive noun, (TA,) like gaAmizN; (Lth, O, TA;) or the fem. of ZaAliEN is ZaAliEapN, (S, O, K, TA,) but one does not say gaAmizapN: (O, TA:) [pl. ZulRaEN.] One says, laA OanaAmu HatRaI yanaAma ZaAliEu AlkilaAbi [I will not sleep until the limping dog sleeps]; (O, K;) a prov., (O,) meaning, until the dogs become still; (O, K;) because the ZAlE, of dogs, waits until there remains none other, and then copulates, and sleeps: (As, O, K:) ― -b2- or the ZAlE is the dog that is lusting for the female; for such does not sleep; and the saying is applied to him who is mindful of his affair, who does not neglect it: ― -b3- or the bitch that is lusting for the male; because the dogs follow her, and will not let her sleep. (O, K.) ― -b4- Also Inclining, or declining: (O, K:) like DaAliEN. (TA.) ― -b5- And [Declining from the truth, or from that which is right; (see ZalaEN;)] committing a sin, crime, fault, or misdeed. (TA.) ― -b6- And Suspected. (S, O, K.) ＝ -A2- In the saying of Ru-beh,
faUino tuxaAlijona AlEuyuwna AlZRulRaEaA
[And if ye women vie with the contracted and inclined eyes], he means AlmaZoluwEapa, [see 1, last sentence,] using the word in the manner of a possessive noun. (TA.)

muZoliEN c
muZoliEN, applied to a load, i. q. muDoliEN [i. e. Heavily burdening, or overburdening, &c.; or causing to limp]. (TA.)

miZolaAEN c
miZolaAEN an epithet applied to a horse [and the like, as meaning That limps, or halts, much]. (TA.)

1 Zalafa AlSRayoda c
1. Zalafa AlSRayoda, (S, M, O,) or AlXRaApa, (K,) aor.
Zalifa
, inf. n. ZalofN, (M,) He hit in his Zilof [or cloven hoof] (S, M, O, K) the animal of the chase (S, M, O) at which he had shot or cast, (S, O,) or the XAp [a term including the antelope and the like]. (K.) ＝ -A2- Zalafa Oavarahu, (S, M, O, K,) aor.
Zalifa
and
Zalufa
, (M, K,) inf. n. ZalofN, (M, TA,) He made his foot-marks to be unapparent, in order that he might not be tracked: (K:) or he went, or walked, upon hard and rugged ground, in order that his foot-marks might not be visible (S, M, O, K) upon it; (S, O;) as also AZlfhu↓; (S, M, L, TA;) in the K, erroneously ZAlfh↓. (TA.) ― -b2- And Zulifa It (a herd of camels driven together) was taken along ground such as is termed Zalaf, (which means rugged ground, such as does not show foot-marks, M,) in order that the foot-marks thereof might not be followed. (S, O.) ― -b3- And Zalafahumo, (M, K,) aor.
Zalufa
, (M,) or
Zalifa
, (TA,) inf. n. ZalofN, (M, TA,) He followed their foot-marks. (M, K.) ＝ -A3- Zalafa nafosahu Eanohu, (T, S, M, O, K,) aor.
Zalifa
, (S, O, K,) inf. n. ZalofN, (S, O,) He withheld himself from doing it, or coming to it; (S, O, K;) namely, a thing: (S, O:) or he restrained himself from it; (T, K;) namely, a thing that would disgrace him: (T:) or he withheld himself from the love, or blamable love, of it; namely, a thing. (M.) And Zalafahu Eanohu, (T, M,) aor.
Zalifa
, inf. n. ZalofN, He withheld him from it; namely, an affair: (M:) or he made him to be, or become, far, or aloof, from it; or to avoid it; namely, a thing; as also AZlfhu↓. (T, TA.) And Zalafahu [alone] He withheld him from that in which was no good. (M.) ＝ -A4- Zalifati AlOaroDu, (M, K,) [aor.
Zalafa
,] inf. n. ZalafN, (S, * M, TA,) The ground was rugged, not showing a foot-mark. (S, * M, K.) And Zalifato maEiyXatuhu, inf. n. ZalafN, His means of subsistence became hard, strait, or difficult. (TK.) ＝ -A5- Zalifato nafosiI Eano kacaA, aor.
Zalafa
, inf. n. ZalafN, My mind, or soul, abstained, or refrained, from such a thing. (S.) ＝ -A6- [And accord. to the KL, ZalafN as an inf. n. signifies The being ineffectual (i. e. unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct, as expl. below); said of blood; and so ZalofN (which is also expl. below): ― -b2- and the being concealed].

2 ZlRf Ealayohi c
2. ZlRf Ealayohi, (IAar, T, O, K,) inf. n. taZoliyfN, (O,) He exceeded it; (IAar, T, O, K;) i. e. [a certain number of years in age, as, for instance,] AlsRitiyna [sixty], (T,) or Alxamosiyna [fifty]: (O:) and so TalRafa and TalRava and carRafa &c. (T, TA.)

3 ZAlfhu c
3. ZAlfhu: see 1, former half: it is a mistake, in the K, for AZlfhu. (TA.)

4 AZlf c
4. AZlf, said of a man, (IAar, T, O,) or of a company of men, (M,) He, or they, became, or came to be, (IAar, T, M, O, K,) in, or upon, a hard place, (IAar, T, O,) or in, or upon, what is termed OuZoluwfap (M, K) and Zalaf. (M.) ＝ -A2- AZlfhu: see 1, in two places.

ZalofN c
ZalofN, of ground, or land, Such as is rugged, that will not show any foot-mark; (M;) as also ZalafN↓: (S, * M:) or so ZalifapN↓ (S, K) and ZalufapN↓ and ZalafapN↓: (K:) and ZalafN↓ signifies ground such as horses like to run upon: (T:) or (i. e. the last) a place elevated above the water and the mud; and so ZalifN↓; (K;) this last thus expl. by Ibn-'Abbád: (O:) or this last and ZalifapN↓, accord. to ISh, (TA,) or ZalafN↓ and ZalafapN↓, (so accord. to a copy of the T, in which the authority is not mentioned,) signify ground, or land, in which the foot-mark will not appear, and which is high and rugged: and accord. to Fr, ZalifN↓ and ZalifapN↓ signify ground, or land, that will not show a foot-mark; as though it were prevented from doing so: (T, TA:) and ZilofN↓, (so in a copy of the T,) or ZalifN↓, (so in the TA,) accord. to Fr, signifies such as is soft, of ground, or land: but accord. to IAar, such as is hard, and does not show a foot-mark; in which is no softness, so as to be difficult to him who walks upon it; nor sand, so that the camels would have their feet burnt upon it; nor stones, so that they would be chafed, or abraded, in the soles of their feet, upon it: and it is also expl. (by IAar, TA) as meaning such as is rugged and hard, of ground, or land: (T, TA:) and ZalifapN↓ signifies high ground, or land, that will not show a foot-mark. (M.) [See also ZaliyfN.] ― -b2- [In the CK, AlZRalofu is erroneously put for AlZRalafu as relating to the means of subsistence.] ＝ -A2- ZalofN also signifies Ineffectual, null, or void: and allowable. (TK.) One says, cahaba damuhu ZalofFA, (AA, S, M, O, K,) and TalafFA↓, (AA, T, S, M, O, K,) and ZaliyfFA↓, (M,) as also TalofFA and TalafFA (AA, O) [and TaliyfFA], His blood went for nothing; as a thing of no account; ineffectually; or in vain; unretaliated, or uncompensated by a mulct. (AA, T, S, M, O, K.)

AlZRulofu c
[AlZRulofu in Har p. 312, there said to be used as meaning Continence, and disdain of base actions, is app. a mistake for AlZRalofu, inf. n. of 1 in the phrase Zalafa nafosahu.]

ZilofN c
ZilofN The Zufor [meaning cloven hoof] of any ruminant (T, M) of the bovine kind and the like; (T;) [i. e.] it is an appertenance of the bovine kind and of the sheep and goat (S, O, Msb, K) and of the gazelle or antelope (S, O, K) and the like, (O, Msb, K,) which is to them like the Zufor to man, (Msb,) or like the qadam to us: (K:) one says the rijol and qadam of a man, and the HaAfir of a horse, and the xufR of a camel and of an ostrich, and the Zilof of a bovine animal and of a sheep or goat [and the like]: (ISk, T, TA:) pl. OaZolaAfN (S, M, O, Msb, K) and ZuluwfN: (S, O, K:) and
OaZolaAf is applied, by 'Amr Ibn-Maadee-kerib, to the hoofs of horses, (S, M, O,) as is said by Lth and Az and IF, by poetic license, (O,) metaphorically: (S, O:) and by El-Akhtal, metaphorically, to the feet of men. (M, IB, TA.) [Its dual is used in the K, in explanations of the words XaEirapN and OaXoEaru, in the latter instance on the authority of Lh, as meaning The two halves of a cloven hoof.] And one says, maA jaXimotu Uilayoka ZilofFA [app. meaning I have not had the trouble of bringing to thee so much as the hoof of a gazelle or the like]. (AZ, TA in art. jXm, q. v.) And huwa yaOokuluhu biDirosK wayaTaWuhu biZilofK [He eats it with a lateral tooth, and treads it with a cloven hoof; app. meaning, vehemently]. (TA.) ― -b2- It is sometimes used as meaning (tropical:) Cloven-hoofed animals. (TA.) One says, maA lahu xufRN walaA HaAfirN walaA ZilofN (tropical:) [He possesses not camels, nor horses or asses or mules, nor sheep or goats or other cloven-hoofed beasts]. (TA in art. xf.) ― -b3- It also signifies [or implies] The making consecutive progressions in walking and in other actions, (T, K,) or, accord. to the L, in a thing. (TA.) One says, jaMCati AlUibilu EalaI ZilofK waAHidK (T, A, O, TA) i. e. The camels came following one another. (A, TA. [See also a similar phrase voce xufRN.]) And ganamu fulaAnK ZilofK waAHidK and waAHidK ZalafK↓ The sheep, or goats, of such a one, have all of them brought forth [app. one after another]. (M.) ― -b4- Also A thing that is suitable to the requirements of a man, and of a beast: (M:) and an object of desire: (M, O, K:) and an object of want. (T, K.) One says, OaSaAba fulaAnN Zilofahu Such a one attained what was suitable to his requirements, and what he desired: and sometimes one says the like of any beast that finds, or lights on, or meets with, that which he likes. (M.) wajadati AldRaAbRapu ZilofahaA is a prov., (M, O,) applied to him who finds the means of attaining that which he seeks; (Meyd;) meaning [The beast found what was suitable to its requirements; or,] what withheld it [from other things] and prevented its desire [thereof]. (A, TA. [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov., ii. 807.]) And one says, wajadati AlXRaApu ZilofahaA The sheep, or goat, found suitable pasturage, and therefore did not quit it: (K, TA:) a prov. mentioned by Fr; applied to him, of men and of beasts, that finds what is suitable to him. (TA.) And baladN mino Zilofi Alganami A country of such as are suitable to sheep or goats. (M.) And wajada Zilofahu He found what he loved, (O,) or what he desired, (K,) and what was suitable to him; (TA;) said of a man. (O.) And maA wajadotu Einodahu ZilofiI I did not find with him the object of my want. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ZalofN, near the middle of the paragraph. ― -b2- [In some copies of the K, AlZRilofu is erroneously put for AlZRalafu as relating to the means of subsistence. And in the CK ZilofuhaA is erroneously put for ZalifuhaA as meaning Zalifu AlnRafosi.]

ZalafN c
ZalafN [as an inf. n.: see 1, last quarter. ― -b2- Also] Hardness, or difficulty, (S, O, K,) or coarseness, (M,) in the means of subsistence: (S, M, O, K:) thus the word is correctly written: not Zilof, as we find it written in [copies of] the K: [nor Zalof, as in the CK:] and Zalafu AlEayoXi occurs in a trad., (O, TA,) meaning straitness, and hardness or difficulty, and coarseness, of the means of subsistence. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ZalofN, in three places, near the beginning of the paragraph. ＝ -A3- And see the last sentence of that paragraph. ― -b2- Also Anything that is easy, or of light estimation, paltry, or despicable; [as also TalafN;] syn. kulRu hayonK, (M,) or kulRu hayRinK. (TA.) ＝ -A4- See also ZilofN, latter half. ― -b2- And see Zaliyfap.

ZalifN c
ZalifN: see ZalofN, former half, in three places. ＝ -A2- Zalifu AlnRafosi, [accord. to the CK Zalofu AlnRafosi, but this is a mistranscription,] and AlnRafosi Zaliyfu↓, (M, O, K,) A man who withholds himself from the love, or blamable love, of a thing: (M:) or one who abstains from that which is indecorous; syn. nazihu AlnRafosi. (O, K.) And AimoraOapN Zalifapu AlnRafosi i. q. EaziyzapN Einoda nafosihaA [app. A woman strong to resist, in her own estimation; and therefore meaning one who abstains from that which is indecorous: Golius renders it mulier pudica, et de honore suo sollicita]. (S, TA.) ＝ -A3- See also ZalifapN.

AlZRulafu c
[AlZRulafu in Har p. 623, there said to mean The restraining the soul from its desire, or blamable inclination, is app. a mistranscription for AlZRalafu, inf. n. of Zalifati AlnRafosu.]

ZalofapN c
ZalofapN: see ZalofN. ＝ -A2- Also A certain brand, or mark made with a hot iron, upon a camel; and so ZalifapN↓. (O, K.)

ZalafapN c
ZalafapN: see ZalofN, in two places, near the beginning. ― -b2- [Hence, perhaps,] one says, OaqaAmahu QllRehu, EalaI AlZRalafaAti, (TA, [there said to be muHarRakap,]) or AlZlifAt, (so in a copy of the T, [i. e. AlZRalifaAti↓,]) meaning [God made him to keep to] a state of hardship and straitness. (T, TA.)

ZalifapN c
ZalifapN: see ZalofN, in four places: ― -b2- and see ZalafapN: ＝ -A2- and ZalofapN. ＝ -A3- Also The [lower] end of the [curved piece of wood called the] Hinow [that lies against the side, at the fore part and at the hinder part,] of the [kind of saddle called] qatab, and of the [kind called] UikaAf, and the like; being in what is next to the ground, of the sides thereof: (Lth, T, TA:) or its pl., which is ZalifaAtN (S, M, O, K) and ZalifN↓, (O, K, [or rather the latter is a coll. gen. n.,]) signifies the four pieces of wood, (S, M, O, K,) of the [saddle called the] raHol and of the [saddle called the] qatab, (S, O,) that are upon the two sides of the camel, (S, M, O, K,) the lower ends of which touch the ground when they are put down upon it; in the waAsiT [or fore part of the saddle] are two (i. e. ZalifataAni), and so in the muWaxRarap [or hinder part], and they are the lower portions of the HinowaAni; (S, O, K;) for the parts above them, next to the [pieces of wood called the] EaraAqiI, are [called] the EaDudaAni, and the elongated pieces of wood upon the sides of the camel are the OaHonaMC [pl. of HinowN]: (S, O:) AZ says that the upper portions of the ZalifataAni, [a mistake for the HinowaAni, as is shown by what follows,] next to the EaraAqiI, are [called] the EaDudaAni; below them being the ZalifataAni, which are the lower parts of the HinowaAni of the waAsiT and of the muWaxRarap. (T, TA.) ― -b2- [Hence] one says, qaAmuwA EalaI ZalifaAtihimo, meaning EalaI OaToraAfihimo (tropical:) [They stood upon their extremities, i. e. their feet]. (TA.) ― -b3- And naHonu EalaI ZalifaAti OamorK (tropical:) We are on the verge of an affair, or event. (TA.) ― -b4- See also Zaliyfap.

ZalofaMCu c
ZalofaMCu A smooth stone or rock, or a hard, smooth, large stone, (SafaApN,) even with the ground, (T, O, K,) round (mdwrp), (so in a copy of the T, [i. e. mudawRarap,]) or extended (mamoduwdap). (O, K.)

ZulRafN c
ZulRafN [a pl. of which the sing. is not mentioned: accord. to general analogy, the sing. should be ZaAlifN]. ZuluwfN ZulRafN means Hard Zuluwf [or divided hoofs]: (S, O, K:) the latter word being a corroborative. (S, O.)

ZaliyfN c
ZaliyfN A rough, or rugged, place, (S, M, O, K, TA,) in which is much sand. (M, TA. [See also ZalofN.]) ― -b2- And A man (S, O) evil in condition (T, S, M, K) in respect of his means of subsistence: (T:) and low, abject, or abased, and weak. (M, O, K.) ― -b3- And An affair that is hard, or difficult: (K:) anything difficult to one to seek: (IDrd. M, O:) and evil hard to be borne, or severe. (S, O.) ― -b4- See also ZalifN. ＝ -A2- Also Hardship, or difficulty. (O, K.) ＝ -A3- cahaba bihi ZaliyfFA He went away with it, or took it away, without compensation, or without price: (T, S, M, K:) and so TaliyfFA. (Yoo, TA in art. Tlf.) And cahaba bigulaAmiI ZaliyfFA He went away with, or took away, my young man, or slave, without price. (AZ, S, O.) ― -b2- See also ZalofN, last sentence. ＝ -A4- Oaxacahu biZaliyfi raqabatihi He took him by the base of his neck. (O, K, * TA.) ― -b2- See also what here follows.

Oaxacahu biZaliyfatihi c
Oaxacahu biZaliyfatihi, (S, M, O, L,) or biZaliyfihi↓, (K,) and biZalafihi↓, (S, O, K,) biZalifatihi↓, (T, M, L,) He took it altogether, or wholly, (T, * S, O, K,) or with its root, or base, and wholly, (M, L,) not leaving of it anything: (T, S, M, O, L, K:) so says AZ. (S.)

OuZoluwfapN c
OuZoluwfapN A piece of rugged, or rough, ground: (T:) or ground, (S, O, K,) or hard ground, (TA,) in which are sharp stones, as though its composition were that of a mountain: (S, O, K, TA:) pl. OaZaAliyfu. (T, S, &c.)

maZoluwfN c
maZoluwfN An animal of the chase, at which one
has shot or cast, hit in his Zilof [or cloven hoof]. (Yaakoob, S.)

1 Zalama c
1. Zalama, aor.
Zalima
, has for its inf. n. ZalomN, (M, Msb, K, and so in some copies of the S,) or ZulomN↓, (so in other copies of the S,) or both, (T,) or the latter is a simple subst., (T, M, Msb, TA,) which is put in the place of the inf. n., (TA, [and the same is indicated in the T and K by the saying that the proper inf. n. is with fet-h,]) and maZolimapN↓, (S, TA,) or this is likewise a simple subst., (Msb,) and maZolamapN↓, [or this also is a simple subst.,] and ZilaAmN↓ also is said to be an inf. n. like ZulomN, these two being like libaAsN and lubosN, [or it is a simple subst. like as ZulomN is said to be, or it is an inf. n. of 3, as such occurring in the middle of this paragraph,] or, accord. to Kr, it is pl. of ZulomN [like as rimaAHN is pl. of rumoHN]: (TA:) [Zalama when intrans. generally means He did wrong; or acted wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: and when trans., he wronged; or treated, or used, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically; or he misused:] accord. to most of the lexicologists, (Er-Rághib, TA,) primarily, (As, T, S, Msb,) AlZRulomu↓ signifies the putting a thing in a place not its own; putting it in a wrong place; misplacing it: (As, T, S, M, Er-Rághib, Msb, K:) and it is by exceeding or by falling short, or by deviating from the proper time and place: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the acting in whatsoever way one pleases in the disposal of the property of another: and the transgressing the proper limit: (El-Munáwee, TA:) [i. e.] the transgressing the proper limit much or little: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or, accord. to some, it primarily signifies AlnRaqoS [as meaning the making to suffer loss, or detriment]: (MF, TA:) and it is said to be of three kinds, between man and God, and between man and man, and between a man and himself; every one of which three is really lilnRafosi [i. e. a wrongdoing to oneself]: (Er-Rághib, TA:) [when it is used as a simple subst.,] the pl. of ZulomN, accord. to Kr. is ZilaAmN, as mentioned above, and ZulaAmN↓, with damm, is said to be syn. with ZulomN, or a pl. thereof, [of an extr. form, commonly regarded as that of a quasi-pl. n.,] like ruxaAlN. (TA.) One says, mani QsotaroEaI AlcRiYoba faqado Zalama [He who asks, or desires, the wolf to keep guard surely does wrong, or puts a thing in a wrong place]: a prov. (S, Msb.) And mano OaXobaha OabaAhu famaA Zalama, (As, T, S,) a prov., meaning [Whoso resembles his father in a quality, or an attribute,] he has not put the likeness in a wrong place. (As, T. [See art. Xbh.]) walamo taZolimo minohu XayoYFA, in the Kur [xviii. 31], means walamo tanoquSo [i. e. And made not aught thereof to suffer loss, or detriment]: (M, K:) and in like manner Fr explains the saying in the Kur [ii. 54 and vii. 160], wamaA ZalamuwnaA walekino kaAnuwA Oanofusahumo yaZolimuwna And they made not us to suffer loss, or detriment, by that which they did, but themselves they made to suffer loss, or detriment: (T, TA:) in which sense it seems to be indicated in the A that the verb is tropical. (TA.) ― -b2- It is also trans. by means of bi; as in the phrase in the Kur [vii. 101 and xvii. 61] faZalamuwA bihaA, because the meaning is kafaruwA [i. e. And they disbelieved in them], referring to the MyaAt [or signs]; (M, TA; *) the verb having this meaning tropically or by implication; or being thus made trans. because implying the meaning of AltRakociyb: or [the meaning is, and they wronged themselves, or the people, because of them; for], as some say, the b is causative, and the objective complement, i. e. Oanofusahumo, or AlnRaAsa, is suppressed. (TA.) ― -b3- And it is doubly trans. by itself: (TA:) one says, Zalamahu HaqRahu [He made him to suffer loss, or detriment, of his right, or due; or defrauded, or despoiled, or deprived, him of it]; and HaqRahu tZlRmhu↓: (M, K:) [and] you say, fulaAnN taZalRamaniI↓, [as well as tZlRmnI maAliI, occurring in a verse cited in the M,] meaning ZalamaniI maAliI [i. e. Such a one caused me to suffer loss, &c., of my property]. (S.) It is said in the Kur [iv. 44], UinRa QllReha laA yaZolimu mivoqaAla carRapK, for laA yaZolimuhumo mivoqaAla carRapi, and the verb is made doubly trans. because the meaning is laA yasolubuhumo [i. e. Verily God will not despoil them, or deprive them, of the weight of one of the smallest of ants, or a grub of an ant, &c.]: or mivoqaAla carRapK, may be put in the place of the inf. n., for ZalomFA HaqiyrFA kamivoqaAli carRapK [i. e. with a paltry spoliation or deprivation, such as the weight of one of the smallest of ants, &c.]. (M.) ― -b4- One says also, OaraAda ZilaAmahu and muZaAlamatahu, [these two nouns being inf. ns. of ZaAlamahu↓, or the former, as mentioned above, is, accord. to some, an inf. n. of Zalama,] meaning Zulomahu or Zalomahu [i. e. He desired the wronging, &c., of him]. (M, K.) ― -b5- Zalamahu, inf. n. ZulomN [or ZalomN?], also means He imposed upon him a thing that was above his power, or ability. (TA.) And yuZolamu He is asked for a thing that is above his power, or ability. (S.) ― -b6- And one says, Zalama AlbaEiyra (tropical:) He slaughtered the camel without disease. (S, K, TA.) And Zulimati AlnRaAqapu (assumed tropical:) The she-camel was slaughtered without disease: or was covered without her desiring the stallion. (M.) And Zalama AlHimaAru AlOataAna (tropical:) The he-ass leaped the she-ass (K, TA) before her time: (TA:) or when she was pregnant: (K, TA:) so in the A. (TA.) ― -b7- And Zalama AlwaToba, (S, K,) inf. n. ZulomN [or ZalomN?], (S,) (tropical:) He gave to drink of the milk of his skin before its becoming thick (S, K, TA) and its butter's coming forth. (TA. [And the like is said in the T and M.]) And Zalama Alqawoma (assumed tropical:) He gave to drink to the people, or party, (T, M, K,) milk before it had attained to maturity, (T, K,) as related on the authority of A 'Obeyd, (T,) or [milk such as is termed] Zaliymap: (M:) but this is a mistake: it is related on the authority of Ahmad Ibn-Yahyà [i. e. Th] and AHeyth that one says, Zalamotu AlsRiqaMCa, and AllRabana, meaning I drank, or gave to drink, what was in the skin, and the milk, before its attaining to maturity and the extracting of its butter: accord. to ISk, one says, Zalamotu waTobiIa Alqawoma, [but I think that it is correctly Zalamotu waTobiI liloqawmi, agreeably with a verse cited in the T and M,] meaning I gave to drink [to the people, or party,] the contents of my milk-skin before the thickening thereof. (T.) And Zalamotuhu is said of anything as meaning (assumed tropical:) I did it hastily, or hurriedly, before its proper time, or season. (M, TA.) ― -b8- Zalamotu AlHawoDa means (assumed tropical:) I made the watering-trough in a place in which watering-troughs should not be made. (ISk, T.) And Zalama AlOaroDa means (tropical:) He dug the ground in what was not the place of digging: (M, K, TA:) or when it had not been dug before. (M.) And, said of a torrent, (assumed tropical:) It furrowed the earth in a place that was not furrowed. (T.) And Zalama AlbiTaAHa, said of a torrent, (tropical:) It reached the bTAH [or wide water-courses containing fine, or broken, pebbles, &c.], not having reached them before. (A, TA.) And Zalama AlwaAdiI (tropical:) The water of the valley reached a place that it had not reached before. (Fr, T, S, K, TA.) ― -b9- When men have added upon the grave other than its own earth, laA taZolimuwA (tropical:) [Transgress not ye the proper limit] is said to them. (TA.) ― -b10- And one says, laA taZolimo waDaHa AlTRariyqi (assumed tropical:) Turn not thou from the main part, or the beaten track, of the road. (M.) And laA taZolimo Eanohu XayoYaA (assumed tropical:) Turn not thou from it at all. (T.) And lazima AlTRariyqa falamo yaZolimohu (assumed tropical:) [He kept to the road, and] did not turn from it to the right and left. (TA.) ― -b11- And maA Zalamaka Oano tafoEala (T, K, TA) (tropical:) What has prevented thy doing (K, TA) such a thing? (TA.) A man complained to Abu-l-Jarráh of his suffering indigestion from food that he had eaten, and he said to him, maA Zalamaka Oano taqiIoCa (assumed tropical:) [What has prevented thy vomiting?]. (Fr, T.) And one says, maA Zalamaka Eano kacaA (assumed tropical:) What has prevented thee from such a thing? (T.) Respecting the saying
qaAla balaI yaA maIRa waAlyawomu Zalamo
[addressed by a man to a woman who had invited him to visit her], Fr says, they say that the meaning is HaqRFA [Truly, or in truth; i. e. He said, Yes, O Meiya, truly, or in truth, I will visit thee]; and it is a prov.; (T;) or Alyawomu Zalama, or balaI waAlyawomu Zalama, is a prov.; (Meyd;) and thus it was expl. by IAar, as used in the manner of an oath: but Fr says, in my opinion the meaning is, and a day in which is a cause of prevention shall not prevent me: [so that the words of the hemistich above may be rendered, he said, Yes, O Meiya, though the day present an obstacle, for I will overcome every obstacle]: (T:)
accord. to Kr, qadima fulaAnN waAlyawomu Zalama means Such a one came truly, or in truth: [or it may be rendered such a one came though the day presented an obstacle:] but in the saying
UinRa AlfiraAqa Alyawoma waAlyawomu Zalamo
the meaning is said by some to be waAlyawomu ZalamanaA [i. e. Verily separation is to-day, and the day has wronged (us)]: or, as some say, Zlm here means, has put the thing in a wrong place: (M:) accord. to ISk, the phrase waAlyawomu Zalam means [And, or but, or though,] the day has put the affair in a wrong place. (T.) [See also Freytag's Arab. Prov. ii. 911.] ＝ -A2- Zalima, said of the night: see 4.

2 ZlRmhu c
2. ZlRmhu, inf. n. taZoliymN, (T, S, &c.,) He told him that he was ZaAlim [i. e. doing wrong or acting wrongfully &c., or a wrongdoer]: (T:) or he attributed, or imputed, to him Zulom [i. e. wrongdoing, &c.]. (S, M, Msb, K.) ― -b2- And He (a judge) exacted justice for him from his wronger, and aided him against him. (T.)

3 ZaAolama
3: see 1, in the middle of the paragraph.

4 AZlm c
4. AZlm, said of the night, (Fr, T, S, M, Msb, K,) and Zalima↓, (Fr, T, S, K,) the latter with kesr, (S,) like samiEa, (K,) [erroneously written in the TT as from the M Zalama,] It became dark; (S, K;) or it became black; (M;) or it came with its darkness. (Msb.) It is said in the Kur [ii. 19], waUicaA OaZolama Ealayohimo qaAmuwA [And when it becomes dark to them they stand still]; the verb being intrans.: or, accord. to the Ksh, and Bd follows it, it may be trans. [so that the meaning is, and when He makes their place dark &c.]; as is shown by another reading, which is OuZolimuwA: accord. to AHei, it is known by transmission as only intrans.; but Z makes it to be trans. by itself; Ibn-Es-Saláh affirms it to be trans. and intrans.: and Az [so in the TA, but correctly ISd, in the M,] mentions the saying, takalRama faOaZolama EalayonaA AlbayEta (assumed tropical:) [He spoke, and made dark to us the house, or chamber, or tent], meaning he made us to hear what we disliked, or hated, the verb being trans. (TA.) ― -b2- And OaZolamuwA They entered upon the ZalaAm [or darkness, or beginning of night]: (S, M, Msb, K:) or, as in the Mufradát [of Er-Rághib], they became in darkness. (TA.) ― -b3- And they said, maA OaZolamahu and mA OaDowaOahu [How dark is it! and How light, or bright, is it!]; which is anomalous. (S, TA.) ＝ -A2- And AZlm AlvRagoru The front teeth glistened. (T, K.) Hence the saying [of a poet],
UicaA maA QjotalaI AlrRaAYiI UilayohaA biTarofihi
guruwba vanaAyaAhaA OaDaMCa waOaZolamaA
[as though meaning, When the beholder of her with his eye looks at the fineness, or sharpness, (but guruwb is variously explained,) of her central teeth, it shines brightly, and glistens: but Az plainly indicates another meaning; i. e., he sees (lit. lights on, or finds,) brightness and lustre; for he immediately adds, without the intervention of wa or Oawo, evidently in relation to this verse,] OaDaMCa OaIo OaSaAba DawoCFA waOaZolama OaSaAba ZalomFA: (T:) [and ISd cites the verse above with the substitution of biEaynihi for biTarofihi and of OanaAra for OaDaMCa immediately after saying that] OaZolama signifies he looked at the teeth and saw lustre (AlZRaloma). (M.) [In the K, next after the explanation of AZlm AlvRagoru given above, it is added that AZlm said of a man signifies OaSaAba ZalomFA: thus, with fet-h, to the Z, accord. to the TA: in my MS. copy of the K and in the CK, ZulomFA, which is doubtless a mistranscription.]

5 taZalRama
5: tZlRm minohu (T, S, M, K, [but in some copies of the S, mnh is omitted,]) He complained of his Zulom [or wrongdoing, &c.], (S, M, K,) UilaI AlHaAkimi [to the judge]: (T:) in some copies of the S, tuZulRima. (TA.) ― -b2- And tZlRm signifies also He transferred the responsibility for the Zulom [or wrongdoing, &c.,] upon himself, (M, K,) accord. to IAar, who has cited as an ex.,
kaAnato UicaA gaDibato EalaIRa taZalRamato
[as though meaning She used, when she was angry with me, to transfer the responsibility for the wrongdoing upon herself; which may mean that she finally confessed the wrongdoing to be hers]; but [ISd says] I know not how that is: the taZalRum in this case is only the complaining of AlZRulom; for when she was angry with him, it was not allowable [to say] that she attributed the Zulom to herself. (M.) ― -b3- See also 1, former half, in two places.

6 tZAlm Alqawomu c
6. tZAlm Alqawomu (S, M, Msb) The people, or company of men, treated, or used, one another wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically (Zalama baEoDuhumo baEoDFA). (M, Msb.) ― -b2- And [hence] taZaAlamati AlmiEozaI (tropical:) The goats smote one another with their horns by reason of their being fat and having abundance of herbage. (IAar, M, TA.) One says, wajadonaA OaroDFA taZaAlama miEozaAhaA (tropical:) We found a land whereof the goats smote one another with their horns by reason of satiety and liveliness. (T, TA.)

7 UinoZalama
7: see the next paragraph.

8 AiZRalama c
8. AiZRalama (T, S, M, K) and AiZoTalama and AiTRalama, (S, M,) which last is [said to be] the most usual, (S,) [but I have mostly found the first to be used,] of the measure AifotaEala, (S, M,) He took upon himself [the bearing of] Zulom [or wrong, &c.,] in spite of difficulty, trouble, or inconvenience: (S, TA:) or he bore AlZRulom [or wrong, &c.,] (T, M, K, TA,) willingly, being able to resist; (T, TA;) and AinoZalama↓ signifies [thus likewise, or] he bore AlZRulom. (S, M, K.)

ZalomN c
ZalomN The lustre, and brightness, of gold. (Z, TA.) ― -b2- And hence, (Z, TA,) The lustre (lit. running water) upon the teeth; (Lth, T, Z, TA;) the lustre (maMC, S, M, K, and bariyq, S, K) of the teeth, (Lth, T, S, M, Z, K, TA,) from the clearness of the colour, not from the saliva, (Lth, * T, * M,) like blackness within the bone thereof, by reason of the intense whiteness, (S, K,) resembling the firinod [q. v.] of the sword, (S, K,) or appearing like the firinod [of the sword], so that one imagines that there is in it a blackness, by reason of the intense lustre and clearness: (M:) or, accord. to Sh, whiteness of the teeth, as though there were upon it [somewhat of] a blackness: or, as Abu-l-'Abbás ElAhwal says, in the Expos. of the “ Kaabeeyeh, ” lustre (lit. running water) of the teeth, such that one sees upon it, by reason of its intense clearness [app. meaning transparency], what resembles dustcolour and blackness: or, accord. to another explanation, fineness, or thinness, and intense whiteness, of the teeth: (TA:) pl. ZuluwmN. (S, M.) ― -b3- Also Snow: (M, K:) it is said to have this meaning: and the phrase muXorabapi AlvRanaAyaA bimaMCi AlZRalomi, used by a poet, may mean [Having the central teeth suffused with the lustre termed Zalom, as is indicated in the T and S, or] with the water of snow. (Lth, T.)

ZulomN c
ZulomN [as a simple subst. generally means Wrong, wrongdoing, injustice, injuriousness, or tyranny]: see 1, first sentence, in two places. ― -b2- [Zulomu AlArDi in the CK is a mistranscription for Zalama AlOaroDa. ― -b3- And AlZulomu in one place in the CK, as syn. with AlZRalomaMCu, is a mistake for AlZRulomapu.]

laqiytuhu OadonaI ZalamK c
laqiytuhu OadonaI ZalamK, (S, M, K,) or OadonaI ciI ZalamK, (K, TA, [in the CK AawRala ciI ZalamK,]) means (tropical:) I met him the first of everything: (S, K, TA:) or the first thing: (M:) or when the darkness was becoming confused: (M, K:) or OadonaI ZalamK means near; (El-Umawee, S, M, K;) or nearness: (M, K:) and one says, huwa minoka OadonaI ciI ZalamK [app. He is near thee], and raOayotuhu OadonaI ciI ZalamK [app. I saw him near]: (M:) and ZalamN is also syn. with XaxoSN [as meaning an object seen from a distance, or a person]; (K;) or, as some say, it has this meaning in the phrase OadonaI ZalamK [so that laqiytuhu OadonaI ZalamK may mean I met him the nearest object seen from a distance, or the nearest person]: (M:) and accord. to Kh, one says, laqiytuhu OadonaI ZulomapK↓, or OawRala ciI ZulomapK, (as in different copies of the S,) meaning I met him the first thing that obstructed my sight. (S.) ― -b2- ZalamN signifies also A mountain: and the pl. is ZuluwmN. (M, K.)

ZulamN c
ZulamN an appellation of Three nights (T, S, K) of the lunar month (T, S) next after the three called duraEN; (T, S, * K; *) so says A'Obeyd: (T:) thus called because of their darkness: (S:) the sing. is ZalomaMCu↓; (T, S;) so that it is anomalous; for by rule it should be ZulomN; (S;) and the sing. of duraEN is daroEaMCu: so says A'Obeyd: but accord. to AHeyth and Mbr, the sings. are ZulomapN↓ and
duroEapN, agreeably with rule; and this is the correct assertion. (T. [See more in art. drE, voce OadoraEu.])

ZilamN c
ZilamN: see ZilRaAmN.

ZulomapN c
ZulomapN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ZulumapN↓ (S, M, K) [accord. to the CK ZulomN and ZulumN, both of which are wrong,] and ZalomaMCu↓ (S, M, Msb, K) Darkness; contr. of nuwrN: (S, Msb:) or nonexistence of nuwr [or light]: or an accidental state that precludes the coëxistence therewith of nuwr: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or the departure of light; as also ZalaAmN↓; (M, K;) which last has no pl.; (T, TA;) or this last signifies the beginning, or first part, of night, (S, M, Msb,) even though it be one in which the moon shines; and is said by Sb to be used only adverbially; one says, Oatayotuhu ZalaAmFA, meaning I came to him at night, and maEa AlZRalaAmi i. e. at the time of the night: (M, TA:) the pl. of ZulomapN is ZulamN and ZulumaAtN and ZulamaAtN (T, S, Msb) and ZulomaAtN, (S, Msb,) or, accord. to IB, the first of these pls. is of ZulomapN and the second is of ZulumapN. (TA.) One says, huwa yaxobiTu AlZRalaAma↓ [or fiI AlZRalaAmi, expl. in art. xbT], and AlZRulomapa [which means the same] and AlZRalomaMCa↓ [which is also expl. in art. xbT]. (TA.) ― -b2- ZulomapN is also [tropically] used as a term for (assumed tropical:) Ignorance: and (assumed tropical:) belief in a plurality of gods: and (assumed tropical:) transgression, or unrighteousness: like as nuwrN is used as a term for their contraries: (Er-Rághib, TA:) and it is said in the A that AlZRulomu is ZulomapN, like as AlEadolu is nuwrN. (TA.) ZulumaAtu AlbaHori means (assumed tropical:) The troubles, afflictions, calamities, or hardships, of the sea. (M.) ＝ -A2- And one says layolapN ZulomapN, [using the latter word as an epithet, (in the CK, erroneously, ZalimapN,)] and layolapN ZalomaMCu↓, both meaning A night intensely dark; (M, K;) or the latter means muZolimapN [i. e. dark, or black]: (S:) and layolN ZalomaMCu↓ also, (M, K,) which is anomalous, (K,) mentioned by IAar, but [ISd says] this is strange, and in my opinion he has put layolN in the place of layolapN, as in his mentioning layolN qamoraMCu [q. v.]. (M.) ― -b2- See also ZulamN: ― -b3- and see the paragraph next preceding it.

ZilomapN c
ZilomapN sing. of ZilamN: see ZilRaAmN.

ZulumapN c
ZulumapN: see ZulomapN.

ZalomaMCu c
ZalomaMCu: see ZulomapN, in four places: and see also ZulamN.

ZalaAmN c
ZalaAmN: see ZulomapN, in two places.

ZulaAmN c
ZulaAmN: see 1, in the first quarter of the paragraph.

ZilaAmN c
ZilaAmN: see 1, near the beginning: ＝ -A2- see also ZilRaAmN. ＝ -A3- It signifies also Little, or small, in quantity: or mean, contemptible, paltry, or of no weight or worth: ― -b2- whence the saying, naZara UilaIRa ZilaAmFA, meaning XazorFA [i. e. He looked at me from the outer angle of the eye, with anger, or aversion]. (K.)

ZaluwmN c
ZaluwmN: see ZalRaAmN. ― -b2- [Hence,] one says AimoraOapN ZaluwmN lilsRiqaMCi (assumed tropical:) [A woman wont to give to drink the milk of the skin before its attaining to maturity and the extracting of its butter: see Zalama AlwaToba, and what follows it, in the first paragraph]. (M.)

ZaliymN c
ZaliymN [as syn. with maZoluwmN in the primary sense of the latter I have not found: but as an epithet in which the quality of a subst. predominates it signifies] (tropical:) Milk that is drunk before its becoming thick and its butter's coming forth or being extracted; (S, * M;) as also ZaliymapN↓, (T, S, M,) and maZoluwmN↓. (T, S.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) A place that is maZoluwm↓ [i. e. dug where it should not be dug]: (M, TA:) used in this sense by a poet describing a person slain in a desert, for whom a grave was dug in a place not proper for digging [it]. (M.) ― -b3- And (tropical:) The earth of land that is maZoluwmap↓ (S, K, TA) i. e. dug, (TA,) or dug for the first time. (S.) And (assumed tropical:) The earth of the laHod [or lateral hollow] of a grave; which is put back, over it, after the burial of the dead therein. (T, TA.) ＝ -A2- Also The male ostrich: (T, S, M, K:) said (by IDrd, TA) to be so called because he makes a place for the laying and hatching of the eggs (yudaHRiI, inf. n. tadoHiyapN,) where the doing so is not proper: (M, TA:) or, accord. to Er-Rághib and others, because he is believed to be deaf: (TA:) pl. ZilomaAnN (T, M, K) and ZulomaAnN (M, K) and OaZolimapN, (T, M,) which last is a pl. of pauc. (T.) ― -b2- And AlZRaliymaAni is an appellation of Two stars; (M, K, * TA;) the two stars of Alqawos [or Sagittarius] that are on the northern curved end of the bow [i. e. λ and μ, above the nine stars called AlnRaEaAYim, or “ the ostriches ”]. (Kzw in his descr. of Sagittarius.) And AlZRaliymu is the name of The bright star [ α] at the end of AlnRahor [i. e. Eridanus]: and A star upon the mouth of AlHuwt [i. e. Piscis Australis] (Kzw in his descr. of Eridanus.) [It seems to be implied in the K that AlZRaliymu is the name of two stars; or it may be there meant that each of two stars is thus called. Freytag represents the sing. as “ a name of stars, ” and the dual also as “ a name of stars; ” referring, in relation to the former, to Ideler's “ Untersuch, ” pp. 201, 228, and 233; and in relation to the latter, to the same work, pp. 106 and 184.]

ZulaAmapN c
ZulaAmapN: see maZolimapN.

ZaliymapN c
ZaliymapN: see maZolimapN: ― -b2- and see also ZaliymN.

ZalRaAmN c
ZalRaAmN (TA) and ZilRiymN↓ (S, TA) [and ZaluwmN↓, mentioned in the M and K with ZaAlimN, as though syn. therewith, but it is an intensive epithet,] One who acts wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically, much, or often; i. q. kaviyru AlZRulomi. (S, TA.) ― -b2- ZalRaAmuwna lilojuzuri occurs in a verse of Ibn-Mukbil [meaning (assumed tropical:) Men often slaughtering camels without disease]. (T, S.) ＝ -A2- See also what next follows.

ZilRaAmN c
ZilRaAmN (AHn, T, M, K) and ZalRaAmN↓ (T) and ZilaAmN↓ (K) and ZaAlimN↓ and ZilamN↓, (T, K,) the last mentioned by IAar, and its sing. is ZilomapN↓, (T,) accord. to AHn, A certain herb, (M, K, TA,) which is depastured; (M, TA;) accord. to IAar, a strange kind of tree; (T, TA;) accord. to As, a kind of tree (T, TA *) having long [shoots such as are termed] EasaAliyj [pl. of EusoluwjN q. v.], (T, K, TA,) which extend so that they exceed the limit of the OaSol [i. e. either root or stem] thereof; for which reason the tree is called ZalRaAm. (T, TA.)

ZilRiymN c
ZilRiymN: see ZalRaAmN.

ZaAlimN c
ZaAlimN [Acting wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: and wronging; or treating, or using, wrongfully, &c.:] part. n. of Zalama: (M, K:) and mutaZalRimN↓ signifies the same; as well as complaining of his wrongdoer: (T:) [the pl. of the former is ZaAlimuwna and ZalamapN:] and ZalamapN signifies those who debar men from, or refuse to them, their rights, or dues. (IAar, T, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ZilRaAmN.

OaZolamu c
OaZolamu [More, and most, wrongful, unjust, injurious, or tyrannical, in conduct]. El-Muärrij says, I heard an Arab of the desert say to his companion, OaZolamiI waOaZolamuka fafaEala QllRehu bihi, meaning The more wrongful in conduct of me and of thee [may God do to him what He will do; i. e. may God punish him]. (T.) [And] one says, laEana QllRehu OaZolamiI waOaZolamaka i. e. [May God curse] the more wrongful in conduct of us. (K. [But in the TA, a doubt is intimated as to the correctness of this latter saying.]) One says also, lahuwa OaZolamu mino HayRapK [i. e. Verily he is more wrongful in conduct than a serpent]: because it comes to a burrow which it has not excavated, and makes its abode in it: (Fr, T:) for it comes to the burrow of the [lizard called] DabR, and eats its young one, and takes up its abode in its burrow. (TA voce HayRapN.) ― -b2- And AlOaZolamu is an appellation of The DabR; because it eats its young ones. (TA.)

muZolimN c
muZolimN [Becoming dark, &c.: see its verb, 4]. ― -b2- [Hence,] XaEarN muZolimN (tropical:) Hair intensely black. (M, K, TA.) And nabotN muZolimN (tropical:) A plant intensely green, inclining to blackness by reason of its [deep] greenness. (M, K, TA.) And yawomN muZolimN (tropical:) A day of much evil: (K, TA:) or a very evil day: and a day in which one finds hardship, or difficulty. (M.) And OamorN muZolimN (tropical:) An affair such that one knows not how to enter upon it; (AZ, M, K;) and so OamorN miZolaAmN↓: (K:) [or,] accord. to Lh, one says yawomN miZolaAmN↓, meaning (assumed tropical:) a day such that one knows not how to enter upon it. (M.)

maZolimapN c
maZolimapN and maZolamapN: see 1, near the beginning. ― -b2- Also the former, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and the latter likewise, mentioned by Ibn-Málik and ISd and IKtt, and maZolumapN, which is disallowed
by several but mentioned on the authority of Fr, and all three are mentioned in the Towsheeh and in copies of the S, (MF, TA,) and ZulaAmapN↓, (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K,) and ZaliymapN↓, (S, TA,) A thing of which one has been defrauded; (M, K; [in the CK, taZalRamahu is erroneously put for tuZulRimahu;]) a thing of which thou hast been defrauded, (AalRatiI ZulimotahaA, T,) or a thing that thou demandest, (maA taTolubuhu, S, Msb,) in the possession of the wrongdoer; (T, S, Msb;) a term for a thing that has been taken from thee; (S; [thus, as is said in the M, the first is expl. by Sb;]) a right, or due, that has been taken from one wrongfully: (A, Mgh:) the pl. of mZlmp is maZaAlimu. (Mgh, TA.) In the phrase yawomu AlmaZaAlimi, [meaning The day of the demand of things wrongfully taken, and particularly applied to the great day of judgment,] the prefixed noun [i. e. Talabi] is suppressed. (Mgh.) [Respecting the office termed AlnRaZaru fiI AlmaZaAlimi The examination into wrongful exactions, see De Sacy's Chrest. Ar., see. ed., i. 132.]

muZalRamN c
muZalRamN (assumed tropical:) A house, or chamber, decorated with pictures; (M, TA;) as though the pictures were put therein where they should not be: it is related in a trad. that the Prophet, having been invited to a repast, saw the house, or chamber, to be muZalRam, and turned away, not entering: (M:) or adorned with gilding and silvering; an explanation disapproved by Az, but pronounced by Z to be correct, from AlZRalomu signifying “ the lustre, and brightness, of gold. ” (TA.) ― -b2- And (assumed tropical:) Herbage spreading (munobavRN [in the CK munobat]) upon the ground, not rained upon. (K, TA.) ― -b3- Also, of birds, (assumed tropical:) The raxam [or vultur percnopterus], and crows, or ravens. (IAar, M, K. *)

miZolaAmN c
miZolaAmN: see muZolimN, in two places.

maZoluwmN c
maZoluwmN [Wronged; treated, or used, wrongfully, unjustly, injuriously, or tyrannically: ― -b2- and hence used in other senses]: see ZaliymN, in three places. OaroDN maZoluwmapN is also expl. as meaning (tropical:) Land that is dug in a place not proper for digging: (TA:) or land in which a watering-trough has been dug, not being a proper place for digging it: (ISk, M:) or land in which a well, or a wateringtrough, has been dug, when there had not been any digging therein: (A, TA:) or hard land, when it is dug. (Ham p. 56.) Also (assumed tropical:) Land upon which rain has not fallen. (T.) And baladN maZoluwmN (assumed tropical:) A country upon which rain has not fallen, and wherein is no pasturage for the camels upon which people journey. (T.)

mutaZalRimN c
mutaZalRimN: see ZaAlimN.

5 tZlRI c
5. tZlRI: see 5 in art. Zl.

1 ZamiYa c
1. ZamiYa, (T, S, M, &c.,) aor.
ZamaAa
, (Msb, K,) inf. n. ZamaON (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ZamoCN (TA) and ZamaMCN (T, M, K) and ZamaMCapN, (M, K, TA,) in one copy of the K ZamoOap, (TA,) He thirsted, or was thirsty: (S, M, Msb, K:) or as some say, he thirsted in the slightest degree. (M, TA.) ― -b2- Hence, (M,) ZamiYa UilaI liqaAYihi (tropical:) He desired, or longed, [or, as we often say, thirsted,] to meet with him. (S, M, K, * TA.)

2 ZamRaAa
2: see the next paragraph.

4 AZmOhu c
4. AZmOhu, (T, * S, Msb, K,) inf. n. UiZomaMCN; (T;) and ZmROhu↓, (T, * Msb, K,) inf. n. taZomiYapN; (T, S;) He made him to thirst: (S, Msb, K:) [or to thirst most vehemently: or to thirst in the slightest degree: see 1.] ― -b2- And (K) (tropical:) He made him lean, or lank, namely, a horse, (T, * K, TA,) by sweating him. (TA.) [See also 4 in art. ZmI.]

5 tZmRO c
5. tZmRO He constrained himself to endure with patience a state of thirst. (A, TA.)

ZimoCN c
ZimoCN a subst. from ZamiYa (S, M, K) in both of its senses; (M, K;) [i. e.] it signifies Thirst: (MA:) [or most vehement thirst: or the slightest degree of thirst:] pl. OaZomaMCN. (MA.) ― -b2- [And (tropical:) Desire, or a longing, (or, as we often say, a thirsting,) to meet with a person. See 1.] ― -b3- And (S, M, K) The time, or interval, or period, between two drinkings, or waterings, (T, S, M, K,) in the coming of camels to water: (T:) and the keeping of camels from the water [during that interval, i. e.] until the extreme limit of the coming thereto: (S:) pl. OaZomaMCN. (T, S, M.) The shortest ZimoCN of camels is that termed gibRN, i. e., when they come to the water one day and return, and are in the place of pasture a day, and come to the water [again] on the third day; the interval between their two drinkings being termed a ZimoC: this is during the greatest heat: but when Suheyl [i. e. Canopus] rises [aurorally, which it did in Central Arabia, about the commencement of the era of the Flight, on the 4th of August, O. S.], they increase the ZimoC, so that the camels remain in the place of pasture two days, and come to the water on the fourth; and one says, waradato riboEFA: then follow the ximos and the sidos to the EiXor: and the interval between their two drinkings is termed ZimoCN, whether long or short. (T.) One says, maA baqiIa mino Eumurihi UilRaA ZimoCu AlHimaAri, (T, S, * K, * TA,) meaning There remained not of his life save a little; [lit., save the period between the two drinkings of the ass;] (S, K, * TA;) because there is no beast that bears thirst for a shorter time than the ass; (T, S, * K, * TA;) for he comes to the water in summer every day twice. (T, TA.) ― -b4- AlZRimoCu also signifies (assumed tropical:) The period from birth to death; (K;) or so ZimoCu AlHayaApi. (S, M, TA.) ― -b5- ZimowN is a dial. var. of ZimoCN. (T and M in art. Zmw.)

ZamiYN c
ZamiYN: see the next paragraph.

ZamoMnu c
ZamoMnu, (T, S, M, Msb, &c.,) fem. ZamoOaI, (T, S, M, A, L, Msb,) both imperfectly decl.; (T;) or ZamoMnN, fem. ZamoMnapN; (K; [but this requires consideration, for its correctness is extremely doubtful;]) and ZamiYN↓, (so in the K accord. to the TA, and so in my MS. copy of the K,) like katifN, [agreeably with analogy as part. n. of ZamiYa, and therefore probably correct,] (TA,) or ZamiIoCN↓, (so in a copy of the M and in the CK,) fem. [of the former] ZamiYapN, like fariHapN, mentioned by Ibn-Málik, but generally held to be disused; (MF, TA;) and ZaAmK, like raAmK; (TA; [app. for ZaAmiYN↓;]) Thirsty: (S, M, Msb, K:) or most vehemently thirsty: (T, M, K:) or thirsty in the slightest degree: (M, TA:) pl. (of the first, M, Msb, and of the second, M, or of all, mase. and fem., TA) ZimaMCN (T, S, M, Msb, K) and ZumaMCN, which is extr., (K, TA,) being of a form applying to only about ten words, (TA,) mentioned on the authority of Lh, (K, TA,) by ISd in the “ Mukhassas. ” (TA.) ― -b2- [Hence,] one says, OanaA ZamoMnu UilaI liqaAYika (tropical:) I am desirous, or longing, [or, as we often say, thirsting,] to meet with thee. (A, TA.) ― -b3- And wajohN ZamoMnu (tropical:) A face having little flesh, (T, TA,) the skin of which adheres to the bone, and the sap of which is little: (TA:) an expression of praise: contr. of wajohN rayRaAnu, which is [said to be] an expression of dispraise. (A, TA.) And farasN ZamoMnu AlXRawaI (assumed tropical:) A horse having little flesh upon the legs: (T in art. rwI:) and so OaZomaI AlXRawaI. (T in art. ZmI.) And saAqN ZamoOaI (assumed tropical:) A lean shank: (T, TA:) and so sAq ZamoyaMCu. (S and M and K in art. ZmI.) And EayonN ZamoOaI (assumed tropical:) An eye having a thin, or delicate, lid: (M, TA:) and so Eyn ZamoyaMCu. (S and M and K in art. ZmI.) And fuSuwSuhu ZimaMCN (said of a horse, T, S, TA) (tropical:) His joints are [firm,] not flabby, or lax, (T, S, K, TA,) nor fleshy; (S, K, TA;) and are well braced; an expression of commendation: (T:) and mafaASilu ZimaMCN (tropical:) Hard [or firm] joints, without flabbiness, or laxness: (A, TA:) accord, to IB, belonging to art. ZmI; but said in the T to be originally from ZmO. (TA.) ― -b4- And riyHN ZamoOaI (assumed tropical:) A wind that is hot, (As, T, K,) thirsty, not gentle, (K,) and without moisture. (As, T.)

ZamiIoCN c
ZamiIoCN: see ZamoMnu, first sentence.

ZamaMCapN c
ZamaMCapN (assumed tropical:) Evilness of nature, of a man, and meanness of disposition, and deficiency of equity to associates: (En-Nadr, T, K:) originating from the fact that he who is given to drink, if of an evil nature, does not act equitably to his associates. (T.)

ZaAmiYN c
ZaAmiYN: see ZamoMnu, first sentence.

maZomaON c
maZomaON A thirsty place of the earth or ground. (M, K.)

miZomaMCN c
miZomaMCN A very thirsty man. (K.)

miZomaYiIRN c
miZomaYiIRN Watered [only] by the rain: contr. of masoqawiIRN: (K:) and so maZomiIRN: applied to seedproduce. (S and K in art. ZmI.)

ZimaxN c
ZimaxN, (K,) or ZimoxN, (AA, TA,) A tree having the form of the dulob [or plane-tree], (AA, T, K,) from which is cut the wood of the beaters and washers and whiteners of clothes, which is buried, [and is used for tanning,] and which is also called EironN, n. un. EironapN, and the spathe, or spadix, (TaloE,) whereof is called safoEN: (AA, T:) and in the dial. of Teiyi, the fig-tree; n. un. with p: or the sing. is ZimoxapN, and the pl. is ZimaxN, sometimes contracted into ZimoxN: (K:) and some say that it is the tree called sumRaAq: (TA, and so in one of my copies of the S, in which it is written Zimax:) it is also called Znx and zmx and Tmx. (TA.)

ZimowN c
ZimowN, relating to the OaZomaMC of camels, is a dial. var. of ZimoCN, (M,) signifying The interval between two drinkings in the coming of camels to water. (T.) [See art. ZmO.]

1 ZamiIa c
1. ZamiIa, [and Zamiyato, aor.
ZamaIa
,] inf. n. ZamFI, He, or it, [and she, or it,] had any of the qualities denoted by the epithet OaZomaI [and its fem. ZamoyaMCu]. (M, TA. [See OaZomaI, and see also ZamFI expl. below.])

2 ZamRaIa
2: see the next paragraph.

4 OuZomiIa c
4. OuZomiIa, inf. n. UiZomaMCN, He (a horse) was made lean, or lank; as also ZumRiIa↓, inf. n. taZomiyapN. (T, TA. [See also 4 in art. ZmO.])

ZamFI c
ZamFI is the inf. n. of 1 [q. v.]: and [it is said that it] signifies The withering, or drying up, of the lip, from thirst: (M:) so says Lth: but it signifies paucity of the flesh and blood of the lip; not the withering, or drying-up, in consequence of thirst: it is a quality that is commended: (T:) or a tawny, or brownish, or dusky, colour, and a withering, or drying-up, in the lip. (S.) ― -b2- And Paucity of the blood of the gum: (Lth, T:) or paucity of the blood and flesh of the gum. (M.) [In the T is added wyEtryh AlHusonu: and in the M, whw yEtrI AlHubosa, in which AlHubosa seems to be evidently a mistranscription for AlHuboXa: I therefore think it most probable that in the T, as well as in the M, the right reading is wahuwa yaEotariI AlHuboXa, meaning and it is incidental to the Abyssinians.] ― -b3- And Tawniness of a spearshaft. (T.)

ZamK c
ZamK: see OaZomaI.

ZimaMCN c
ZimaMCN: see ZamoMnu, in art. ZmO.

ZaAmK c
ZaAmK: see ZamoMnu, in art. ZmO.

OaZomaI c
OaZomaI Anything withering, or withered; or becoming, or become, dried up; from heat; as also ZamK↓. (M.) ― -b2- [Hence,] XafapN ZamoyaMCu A lip that is not swollen, [not] having much blood; (T;) accord. to Lth, from thirst; but AZ says that it is not so: (TA: [see ZamFI:]) or a lip in which is a tawny, or brownish, or dusky, colour, and a withering, or lack of moisture: (S:) or a lip withering, or withered, or lacking moisture, inclining to a tawny, or brownish, or dusky, colour. (K.) ― -b3- And livapN ZamoyaMCu A gum having little blood: (S, K:) or, accord. to the M, having little blood and flesh. (TA.) ― -b4- And EayonN ZamoyaMCu An eye having a thin, or delicate, lid: (T, S, M, K:) and so Eyn ZamoOaI. (M and TA in art. ZmO.) ― -b5- And saAqN ZamoyaMCu A lean shank: (S, M, K:) and so sAq ZamoOaI. (T and TA in art. ZmO.) And OaZomaI AlXRawaI means A horse having little flesh upon the legs: (TA:) and so ZamoMnu AlXRawaI. (T in art. rwI.) ― -b6- OaZomaI is also applied to a man, as signifying Black in the lip: (M:) and so ZamoyaMCu applied to a woman. (T, M.) ― -b7- And the former applied to a man, and the latter to a woman, Having the quality of the gum termed ZamFI expl. above. (M.) ― -b8- Both also, accord. to Lh, signify Tawny, brownish, or dusky; the former as applied to a man, and the latter to a woman: (M:) and thus the former applied to a spear, (As, T, S, M,) and the latter to a spearshaft (qanaAp). (TA.) ― -b9- And OaZomaI signifies also Black: (T:) thus as applied to shade: (S:) and so the fem. applied to a she-camel: (K:) or the latter applied to a she-camel, and [the pl.] ZumoIN applied to camels, in the colour of which is a blackness. (T.) [See also OaZomaOu, in art. ZmO.]

maZomiIRN c
maZomiIRN Land, (M,) or [rather] seed-produce (zaroE), (S, K,) watered only by the rain: (S, M, K:) and so maZomiYiIRN: (K in art. ZmO:) such as is irrigated by running water is termed masoqawiIRN. (S.)

1 ZanRa c
1. ZanRa, aor.
Zanuna
, inf. n. ZanRN, (Msb,) [He thought, opined, supposed, or conjectured: and he doubted: and he knew, but not by ocular perception: see ZanRN below:] you say, Zananotu AlXRaIoCa, aor. OaZunRuhu, inf. n. ZanRN; and AiZRananotuhu↓ and AiZoTananotuhu; and taZanRanotuhu↓ and taZanRayotuhu, this last formed by changing the last n into I: [i. e. I thought the thing, &c.:] and Lh mentions, as heard from the Benoo-Suleym, Zanotu caAka i. e. Zananotu cAk [I thought that, &c.] like Zalotu and other instances of the dial. of Suleym. (M.) [In the first of the senses expl. above, it governs two objective complements, which are originally an inchoative and an enunciative:] you say, Zananotuka zayodFA [I thought thee Zeyd, originally I thought thou wast Zeyd], and Zananotu zayodFA UiyRaAka [I thought Zeyd thee, originally I thought Zeyd was thou], denoting by a pronoun what is originally an inchoative [in the former phrase] and what is originally an enunciative [in the latter phrase]. (S, TA.) It is also used [in this sense] in the same manner as a verb signifying an oath, the Arabs giving it the same kind of complement, saying, Zananotu laEabodu QllRehi xayorN minoka [I thought surely 'Abd-Allah was better than thou]. (S in art. drd.) [ZanRa bihi kacaA means I thought of him, or it, such a thing: and I thought such a thing to be in him, or it: and is used in relation to good and to evil.] It is said in the Kur [xxxiii. 10], wataTunRuwna biQllRehi QlZRunuwnaA [And ye were thinking, of God, various thoughts]. (M.) Accord. to Sb, Zananotu bihi means I made him, or it, the place [i. e. object] of my ZanR [or thought, &c.]. (M.) [In all these exs. the verb denotes a state of mind between doubt and certainty, but the latter is predominant: and hence ZanRa sometimes means He doubted: and sometimes, he knew, by considering with endeavour to understand, not by ocular perception; being more frequently used in this sense than as meaning “ he doubted, ” though not so frequently as it is in the sense of “ he thought, ” whence the meaning “ he knew ” is held by some to be tropical.] UinRaI, Zananotu OanRiI mulaAqK HisaAbiyaho, in the Kur [lxix. 20], means Verily I knew [that I should meet with my reckoning]. (T.) And QlRaciyna yaZunRuwna OanRahumo mulaAquw rabRihimo, in the same [ii. 43], means Who know [that they shall meet their Lord, lit., be meeters of their Lord]. (Msb.) And Zananotu maA qaAla, occurring in a trad., means I knew [what he meant to say by his making a sign with his hand]. (TA.) ― -b2- Zananotuhu, (M, Mgh, Msb,) aor. as above, (Msb,) and so the inf. n., (M,) signifies also I suspected him; thought evil of him; (M, Mgh, Msb;) and (M) so AiZRananotuhu↓ (S, M, Mgh, K) and AiZoTananotuhu (M, TA) and AiTRananotuhu. (TA.) [Thus, too, OaZonanotuhu↓ accord. to several copies of the S and accord. to the CK; but this is app. a mistranscription.] In the saying of Ibn-Seereen, lamo fiI qatoli EuvomaAna yakuno EaliIRN yuZRanRu↓, (T, S, K, but in the T maA kaAn,) meaning Alee was not suspected [in the case of the slaying of 'Othmán], (T,) yuZRanRu is of the measure yufotaEalu, originally yuZotanRu: (T, S, K:) so says A'Obeyd: (T:) or, as some relate it, the word is yuTRanRu. (TA.) One says, bikacaA huwa yuZRanRu↓ and yuTRanRu, meaning He is suspected of such a thing. (TA in art. Tn.) And Tananotu bizayodK and Zananotu zayodFA I suspected Zeyd: in
this sense the verb has a single objective complement. (TA.)

4 OaZonanotuhu AlXRaIoCa c
4. OaZonanotuhu AlXRaIoCa I made him to think the thing. (M, TA.) ― -b2- And OaZonanotu bihi AlnRaAsa [I made the people to suspect him: or] I exposed him to suspicion; (M, Msb, TA;) [and] so OaZnanotuhu [alone]. (K.) ― -b3- See also 1, last quarter.

5 AltRaZanRiI c
5. AltRaZanRiI means The exercising, employing, or using, of AlZRanR [i. e. thought, &c.]; originally AltRaZanRunu. (S, K.) A'Obeyd says, taZanRayotu is from Zananotu, and is originally taZanRanotu; the n being many, one of them is changed into I: it is like qaSRayotu, which is originally qaSRaSotu. (T.) ＝ -A2- See also 1, first sentence.

8 UiZotanana
8: see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and again, in the last quarter, in three places.

ZanRN c
ZanRN is a simple subst. as well as an inf. n.; (TA;) and signifies Thought, opinion, supposition, or conjecture: (Er-Rághib, Mgh, TA:) or a preponderant belief, with the admission that the contrary may be the case: (KT, El-Munáwee, TA:) or a preponderating wavering between the two extremes in indecisive belief: (K:) or an inference from a sign, or mark, or token; when strong, leading to knowledge; and when weak, not exceeding the limit of wahom: (Er-Rághib, TA:) or doubt or uncertainty; (T, M;) or it has this meaning also; (Er-Rághib, TA;) contr. of yaqiynN: (Msb:) and sometimes it is put in the place, (S, K,) or used in the sense, (Mgh, Msb,) of EilomN, (S, Mgh, K,) or yaqiynN, (Msb,) [i. e. knowledge, or certainty,] in which sense it is [held by some to be] tropical; (Mgh;) or it signifies also knowledge, or certainty, (yaqiynN, T, M,) such as is obtained by considering with endeavour to understand, not by ocular perception, (M,) or not such as relates to an object of sense: (MF:) and it also means suspicion, or evil opinion: (Er-Rághib, TA: [but in this last sense, ZinRapN is more common:]) as a subst., (TA,) its pl. is ZunuwnN and OaZaAniynu, (M, K, TA,) the latter anomalous, or (as ISd says, TA) it may be pl. of OuZonuwnapN↓, but this I do not know. (M, TA.) One says, huwa sayRiYu AlZRanRi bikulRi OaHadK [He is evil in opinion of everyone]. (M.) [And saMCa ZanRuhu bifulaAnK His opinion of such a one was evil.] And Eilomuhu biAlXRaIoCi ZunuwnN [His knowledge is but opinions]; meaning that no confidence is to be placed in him. (TA.)

ZinRapN c
ZinRapN Suspicion, or evil opinion; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) as also TinRapN; the Z being changed into T, though there is no UidogaAm in this case, because of their being accustomed to say AiTRanRa [for AiZRanRa, which is for AiZoTanRa]; an instance like AldRikoru, which is made to accord with AidRakara [for AicRakara, which is for Aicodakara], as mentioned by Sb; (M;) and ZanaAnapN↓, (so accord. to a copy of the M,) or ZinaAnapN↓, like kitaAbapN, (TA,) signifies the same: (M, TA:) the pl. of ZinRapN is ZinanN. (S, K.) One says, Einodahu ZinRatiI and huwa ZinRatiI, meaning He is the place [i. e. object] of my suspicion. (TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] (assumed tropical:) A little [like the French “ soupçon ”] of a thing. (TA.)

ZunanN c
ZunanN: see ZanRaAnN.

ZanuwnN c
ZanuwnN A man who thinks evil (S, M) of everyone. (M.) ― -b2- A man possessing little good or goodness: or, as some say, of whom one asks [a thing] thinking that he will refuse, and who is as he was thought to be: (M:) [or] ZaniynN↓ has this latter meaning. (TA.) ― -b3- A man in whose goodness no trust, or confidence, is to be placed. (M.) And Anything in which no trust, or confidence, is to be placed, (M, TA,) of water, and of other things; (TA;) as also ZaniynN↓. (M, TA.) A well (biYorN) having little water, (S, M, K,) in the water of which no trust, or confidence, is to be placed: (M:) or a well, (S, K,) or a drinkingplace, (M,) of which one knows not whether there be in it water or not: (S, M, K:) or water which one imagines, or supposes, to exist, but of which one is not sure. (TA.) kulRu maniyRapK ZanuwnN UilRaA Alqatola fiI sabiyli QllRehi is a saying mentioned, but not expl., by IAar; [app. meaning Every death is doubtful as to its consequence except slaughter in the way, or cause, of God; but ISd says,] in my opinion the meaning is that it is of little good and profit. (M.) dayonN ZanuwnN means A debt of which one knows not whether he who owes it will pay it or not: (A'Obeyd, T, S, M, * K:) it is said in a trad. of 'Omar that there is no poorrate in the case of such a debt. (TA.) ― -b4- Also A man suspected in relation to his intellect, or intelligence. (Aboo-Tálib, TA.) And A woman suspected in relation to her grounds of pretension to respect, or honour, on account of lineage &c. (TA.) And A woman of noble rank or quality, who is taken in marriage, (M, K,) from a desire of obtaining off spring by her, when she is advanced in age. (M.) ― -b5- Also A weak man. (K. [See also ZanynN.]) ― -b6- And A man having little artifice, cunning, ingenuity, or skill. (K.)

ZaniynN c
ZaniynN Suspected; (T, S, M, Mgh, Msb, K;) applied to a man; (S, M;) i. q. maZonuwnN↓, (Mbr, Msb,) in this sense: (Msb:) pl. OaZinRaMCu. (M, TA.) Thus in the saying in the Kur [lxxxi. 24], wamaA huwa EalaI Qlogayobi biZaniynK, (T, M, Msb,) meaning And he is not suspected as to what he makes known from God, of the knowledge of that which is undiscoverable, as is related on the authority of 'Alee: or, accord. to Fr, it may mean weak; for ZaniynN may have this meaning like as ZanuwnN has: (T:) some read biDanynK. (TA in art. Dn, q. v.) XahaAdapu ZaniynK, which is said in a trad. to be not allowable, is The testimony of one who is suspected as to his religion. (TA.) And nafosN ZanRaMCu↓ means [A soul, or person,] suspected. (TA.) ― -b2- Also One who treats or regards another, or others, with enmity, or hostility; (T, M;) because of his evil opinion and the evil opinion of which he is an object. (M.) ― -b3- See also ZanuwnN, in two places.

ZanaAnapN c
ZanaAnapN or ZinaAnapN: see ZinRapN.

ZanRaMCu c
ZanRaMCu: see ZaniynN.

ZanRaAnN c
ZanRaAnN One who opines, or conjectures, much [and] in an evil manner; as also ZunanN↓. (TA.)

OaZanRu c
OaZanRu [Such as is more, or most, fit that one should think of him to do a thing]. You say, naZarotu UilaI OaZanRihimo Oano yafoEala celika I looked towards him who was the most fit of them that I should think of him to do that. (M, TA.)

OuZonuwnapN c
OuZonuwnapN: see ZanRN, near the end.

maZinRapN c
maZinRapN, (M, Mgh, Msb, TA,) of which maZanRapN, mentioned by Ibn-Málik and others, and miZanRapN, are dial. vars., (TA,) or [rather] maZinRapu XaIoCK, (IF, S, Msb, K, TA,) signifies The place, (IF, S, Msb, K, TA,) and the accustomed place, (IF, S, Msb, TA,) in which is thought to be the existence, (S, K, TA,) of a thing; (IF, S, Msb, K, TA;) [a place] where a thing is thought to be: (M:) or it signifies, (Mgh, Msb,) or signifies also, (S,) a place where a thing is known to be: (S, Mgh, Msb:) [a thing, and a person, in which, or in whom, a thing, or quality, is thought, supposed, presumed, suspected, inferred, known, or accustomed, to be, or exist:] accord. to IAth, by rule it should be maZanRapN: (TA:) [it may therefore be properly rendered a cause of thinking, &c., the existence of a thing; and maZinRapN likacaA may be well expl. as meaning a thing, and a person, that occasions one's thinking, supposing, presuming suspecting, inferring, or knowing, the existence of such a thing or quality, in it, or in him: and hence, an indication, or evidence, or a symptom, diagnostic, characteristic, sign, mark, or token, of the existence of such a thing or quality:] the pl. is maZaAnRu. (M, Mgh, Msb, TA.) One says, mawoDiEu kacaA maZinRapN mino fulaAnK i. e. Such a place is a place in which such a one is known [&c.] to be. (S, TA.) And fulaAnN maZinRapN mino kacaA i. e. Such a one is one in whom such a thing, or quality, is known [&c.] to be. (Lh, T.) And fulaAnN maZinRapN liloxayori i. e. Such a one is one in whom good, or goodness, is thought [&c.] to be. (Ham p. 437.) And En-Nábighah says,
faUino yaku EaAmirN qado qaAla jaholFA
faUinRa maZinRapa Aljaholi AlXRabaAbu
[And if 'Ámir has spoken ignorantly, verily youthfulness is a state in which ignorance is usually found to exist]: (S, Msb: *) or, as some relate the verse, AlsRibaAbu [so that the meaning is, mutual reviling is an act in which &c.]: (S:) or, accord. to another relation, the latter hemistich is
faUinRa maTiyRapa Aljaholi AlXRabaAbu
(S, * TA;) because one finds it [i. e. youthfulness] to be easy like as he does the beast on which one rides. (TA.) And one says also, Talabahu maZaAnRahu [He sought him, or it, in the places where he, or it, was thought to be;] meaning, by night and by day. (TA.) And UinRahu lamaZinRapN Oano yafoEala celika i. e. Verily he is apt, meet, fitted, or suited, for one to think of his doing that: and in like manner one says of two, and of a pl. number, and of a female. (Lh, M.)

maZonuwnN c
maZonuwnN [Thought, opined, &c.: see its verb: and] see ZaniynN. Applied to a narrative, or story, it means [Doubted; or] of which one is not to be made to know the real state. (TA in art. rjm.) In lexicology, A word of the class termed MHaAdN [q. v.]. (Mz 3rd nwE.)

ZinobN c
ZinobN The root, or lower part, or stem, (OaSol,) of a tree. (IAar, T, K.)

ZunobapN c
ZunobapN A sinew (Eaqabap) that is wound over the extremities of the feathers of an arrow, next the notch. (AHn, M, K.)

ZunobuwbN c
ZunobuwbN The edge of the shin: (K:) or the tough edge of the shin: or the external part of the shank: (M, TA:) or the shin-bone: or the edge of the shin-bone: (M, K:) or the tough bone in the fore part of the shank: (S:) but accord. to AZ, this term is not used in relation to animals that have OawoZifap: [see waZiyfN:] (T, TA:) pl. ZanaAbiybu. (S, M, K.) EaAriI AlZRanaAbiybi Without flesh upon the shins (TA) is an epithet applied to a male ostrich. (S, TA.) qaraEa Zunobuwba AlbaEiyri means He knocked, or struck, the shin of the camel, that he might lie down, and he might mount him: or qaroEu AlZRunobuwbi signifies a man's knocking, or striking, the shin of his camel with his stick when he makes him lie down that he may mount him, as one in haste to betake himself to a thing: or striking the shin of his beast with his whip, [in the TA is here added lytrqh, which I can only suppose to be put for liyuborikahu, to make him lie down,] when he desires to mount him. (TA.) [See an ex. voce EuroquwbN. Hence,] qaraEa fulaAnN liOamorihi Zunobuwbahu (assumed tropical:) [Such a one struck his shin to betake himself to his affair] means such a one applied himself to his affair with diligence, or energy. (T, L, TA.) Selámeh Ibn-Jendel says,
kunRaA UicaA maA OataAnaA SaArixN faziEN
kaAna AlSRuraAxu lahu qaroEa AlZRanaAbiybi
[We were (such that), when there came to us one crying aloud, in terror, the clamour (returned) to him was the striking of the shins;] by which he is said to mean that a quick reply was given; calling the striking of the whip upon the leg of the boot, in urging on the horse, “ the striking of the shin. ” (S.) You also say, qaraEa licelika AlOamori Zunobuwbahu meaning (assumed tropical:) He prepared himself for that affair, or thing: and agreeably with this signification the verse of Selámeh cited above has been explained. (M, TA.) And qaraEa ZanaAbiyba AlOamori (tropical:) He made, or rendered, the affair manageable. (M, K, TA.) A poet, cited by IAar, says,
qaraEotu ZanaAbiyba AlohawaI yawoma EaAlijK
(tropical:) I subdued love, or subjected it to my will, on the day of 'Álij;. as though I struck it on the shins; as a camel's shin is struck when one desires him to lie down, that he may mount him. (M, TA.) ― -b2- ZunobuwbN also signifies A nail that is in the jubRap of a spear-head, [i. e., in the part into which the shaft enters,] (M, K,) where it is fixed upon the upper extremity of the shaft: and ZanaAbiyb has been said to be the pl. of the word in this sense in the verse of Selámeh cited above. (M, TA.)

5 tZnRI c
5. tZnRI; originally taZanRana: see the latter, in art. Zn.

1 Zahara c
1. Zahara, (S, Msb, K, &c.,) aor.
Zahara
, (Msb,) inf. n. ZuhuwrN, (S, Mgh, Msb, K, &c.,) [It was, or became, outward, exterior, external, extrinsic, or exoteric: and hence,] it appeared; became apparent, overt, open, perceptible or perceived, manifest, plain, or evident; (S, Mgh, Msb, K, TA;) after having been concealed, or latent: (Msb, TA:) and tZAhr↓ signifies the same. (Har p. 85.) Hence the phrase Zahara liI raOoIN (assumed tropical:) [An idea, or opinion, occurred to me], said when one knows what he did not know before. (Msb.) [And hecaA maA yaZoharu liI (assumed tropical:) This is what appears to me to be the case, or to be the right way or course; or this is my opinion.] Zahara AlHamolu, inf. n. as above, means Pregnancy became apparent, or manifest: it is said that this is not the case in less than three months. (Msb.) And it is said in a trad. of 'Áïsheh, kaAna yuSalRiI AlEaSora fiI HujoratiI qabola Oano taZohara i. e. [He used to perform the prayer of the afternoon in my chamber] before it (meaning the sun) became high and apparent: (TA:) or waAlXRamosu fiI HujoratiI lamo taZoharo baEodu i. e. [when the sun was in my chamber,] it not having risen high so as to be on the flat roof [thereof]: referring to the Prophet. (O. [But AlEaSora must be a mistranscription for Alfajora, i. e. the prayer of the dawn.]) The saying in the Kur [xxiv. 31], walaA yubodiyna ziynatahunRa UilRaA maA Zahara minohaA [which is app. best rendered And that they discover not their ornature except what is external thereof] has been expl. in seven different ways, most correctly as meaning the clothes: (O, TA:) accord. to 'Áïsheh, it means the bracelet (Alqulob) and the ring (Alfataxap): and accord. to I'Ab, the hand and the signet-ring and the face. (TA.) ― -b2- Also He went forth, or out, (Mgh, TA,) to the outside of a place. (O, TA.) ― -b3- And He (a bird) migrated, or went down, from one country or region to another: used in this sense by AHn in relation to the vulture, migrating to Nejd. (L.) ― -b4- Zahara Eanohu, said of a vice, or fault, (O, TA,) or a disgrace, (JK, A, O,) (tropical:) It did not cleave to him; (A, O, TA;) it was remote from him; (TA;) it quitted him, or departed from him. (JK.) ― -b5- Zaharotu bihi, (O, TA,) inf. n. ZahorN, (K,) (assumed tropical:) I gloried, or boasted, by reason of it. (O, K * TA.) [Respecting a meaning assigned to Zahara bifulaAnK in the K, see 4.] ― -b6- Oakala AlrRajulu OukolapF Zahara minohaA ZahorapF means (assumed tropical:) [The man ate some food] in consequence of which] he became fat. (TA.) ＝ -A2- Zaharahu He mounted it; went, or got, upon it, or upon the top of it; (S, A, * Mgh, O, Msb, K;) as also Zahara Ealayohi; (O;) namely, a house, (S,) or a house-top, (A, Mgh, O,) and a mountain, (A,) and a wall; (O, Msb;) properly, he became upon its back: (Mgh:) and [in like manner] one says, fulaAnN najodFA ZahRara↓, inf. n. taZohiyrN, Such a one mounted, or went up, upon the high region (Zahor) of Nejd. (O.) ― -b2- Hence, (Mgh, Msb,) Zahara Ealayohi (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K) and bihi, (K,) inf. n. ZuhuwrN (Bd in xxiv. 31) and ZahorN also, (Ham p. 301,) He overcame, conquered, subdued, overpowered, or mastered, him; gained the mastery or victory, or prevailed, over him; (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K;) namely, his enemy; (Msb;) and in like manner, [he conquered, won, achieved, or attained, it, i. e.] a thing. (O, TA.) [The saying fulaAnN laA yaZoharu Ealayohi OaHadN is expl. in the L and TA by the words AI lA yasolam, and said to be tropical: but Ibr D thinks that the correct reading is lA yusalRimu, from AltRasoliymu; and that it is said of one who will not give up, or resign, what is in his hand; so that the meaning is, (tropical:) Such a one is a person whom no one will overcome in respect of that which he holds in his possession.] ― -b3- And [hence also] Zahara Ealayohi, (Msb, TA,) inf. n. ZuhuwrN, (TA,) He knew, became acquainted with, or got knowledge of, him, or it. (Msb, TA.) So in the Kur xxiv. 31, waQlTRifolu QlRaciyna lamo yaZoharuwA EalaI EaworaAti QlnRisaMCi [And the young children] who have not attained knowledge of the EwrAt, (Bd, Jel,) meaning [pudenda, or] parts between the navel and the knee, (Jel,) of women, by reason of their want of discrimination: (Bd:) or (tropical:) who have not attained to the generative faculty; (O, Bd, * TA;) from AlZRuhuwru in the sense of Algalabapu. (Bd.) So too in the Kur [xviii. 19], Uino yaZoharuwA Ealayokumo If they get knowledge of you. (O, TA.) ― -b4- And [hence] Zahara Ealayohi, (Fr, A, O, TA,) and AstZhrhu↓, (S, A, O, K,) (tropical:) He knew it, or learned it, by heart; namely, the Kur-án; (A, O, TA;) and he recited it by heart: (A, * TA; and so in the S and O in explanation of the latter:) or [simply] he recited it by heart; namely, the Kur-án; as also AZhrhu↓: (O, K, TA:) in the copies of the K we find OaZoharotu EalaI AlquroMni and OaZoharotuhu; but the former is a mistake for Zaharotu, aor.
Zahara
. (TA.) ＝ -A3- For another signification of Zahara Ealayohi, see 3. ＝ -A4- Zahara biHaAjatiI, (S, A, K,)
aor.
Zahara
, (TA,) inf. n. ZahorN; (TK;) and ZhRrhA↓, (K, TA,) in some copies of the K ZaharahaA; (TA;) and AZhrhA↓, (K,) inf. n.
