UiZohaArN; (TA;) and AiZRaharahaA↓, (K,) of the measure AifotaEala; (TA;) (tropical:) He held the object of my want in little, or light, estimation, or in contempt; (S, A;) [lit.] he put it behind [his] back; (S, K;) as though he put it away, [out of his sight,] and paid no regard to it. (S, TA.) One says also, yaZoharuwna bihimo walaA yalotafituwna UilaI OaroHaAmihimo [They hold them in contempt, and do not pay any regard to their ties of relationship]. (S.) ― -b2- See also 10, in three places. ＝ -A5- Zaharahu, (O, K,) aor.
Zahara
, inf. n. ZahorN, (K,) He struck, or smote, (TA,) or hit, or hurt, (O, K,) his back. (O, K, TA.) ＝ -A6- Zahira, (S, O, K,) aor.
Zahara
, (K,) inf. n. ZaharN, (O, K,) He (a man, S, O) had a complaint of his back. (S, O, K.) ＝ -A7- Zahura, (JK, O, L,) or Zahara, (K, [but this is app. a mistranscription,]) inf. n. ZahaArapN, (S, O, L, K,) said of a camel, (JK, S, O,) He was, or became, strong (JK, S, O, L, K) in the back. (L, K.)

2 ZahRara
2: see 1, near the middle: ― -b2- and again, in the last quarter: ― -b3- and see also 3. ― -b4- ZhRr AlvRawoba [and AZhrhu↓, contr. of bTRnhu and AbTnhu,] He faced the garment, or piece of cloth; put a facing, or an outer covering, (ZihaArap,) to it. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also 4, last sentence.

3 ZAhrhu c
3. ZAhrhu, (A,) inf. n. muZaAharapN, (S, O, Msb,) He aided, or assisted, him; (S, A, O, Msb;) as also Ealayohi Zahara↓. (Th, K.) And ZAhr Ealayohi He aided, or assisted, against him. (TA.) ― -b2- ZAhr bihi: see 10. ― -b3- ZAhr bayonahumaA, (K,) i. e. (TA) bayona vawobayoni, (S, A, Mgh, TA,) and diroEayoni, (A, Mgh, TA,) and naEolayoni, (TA,) i. q. TaAraqa bayonahumaA, (S, TA,) or TaAbaqa, (A, K, TA,) i. e. (TA) He put them on, or attired himself with them, [namely, two garments, and two coats of mail, and two sandals or soles, or rather, when relating to two soles, he sewed them together,] one over, or outside, the other: (Mgh, TA:) app. from taZaAhurN in the sense of “ mutual aiding or assisting. ” (IAth.) The phrase ZAhr bidiroEayoni requires consideration; and the b in it should be regarded as meant to denote conjunction; not as a part of the necessary complement of the verb. (Mgh.) ZAhr AldRiroEa is said to signify laOama baEoDahaA EalaI baEoDK [app. meaning He folded over and fastened one part of the coat of mail upon another]. (TA.) And ZAhr Ealayohi jilaAlFA means He threw upon him (i. e. a horse) housings or coverings [one over another]. (TA in art. Hnc.) ＝ -A2- ZAhr mini QmoraOatihi, (S, Mgh, O, Msb, K,) inf. n. ZihaArN (S, Mgh, Msb, K) and muZaAharapN; (JK, TA;) and minohaA tZAhr↓, (A, Mgh, O, TA,) and AiZRaAhara↓; (Mgh;) and mnhA tZhRr↓, (S, Msb, K,) and AiZRahRara↓; (O, TA;) and mnhA ZhRr↓, (S, O, K,) inf. n. taZohiyrN; (S;) signify the same; (O;) He said to his wife Oanoti EalaIRa kaZahori OumRiI [Thou art to me like the back of my mother]; (S, Mgh, Msb, K;) [as though he said rukuwbuki HaraAmN EalaIRa;] meaning rukuwbuki lilnRikaAHi HaraAmN EalaIRa karukuwbi OumRiI lilnRikaAHi; the back being specified in preference to the baTon or faxic or faroj because the woman is likened to a beast that is ridden, and the act of nikaAH to that of rukuwb: the phrase being a form of divorce used by the Arabs in the Time of Ignorance. (Msb, * TA.) In the Kur lviii. 2 [and 4], some read yaZRahRaruwna↓; some yaZRaAharuwna↓; and 'Ásim read yuZaAhiruwna. (Bd.) The verb is made trans. by means of min because the man who uttered this sentence estranged himself from his wife. (IAth.)

4 AZhrhu c
4. AZhrhu He made it apparent, overt, open, perceptible or perceived, manifest, plain, or evident; he showed, exhibited, manifested, displayed, discovered, revealed, or evinced, it; or put it forth: (S, O, K:) [it is also used in relation to a saying, and an action, and the like, as meaning it showed, &c., as above, or it bespoke, it:] and Mtr relates his having heard from one worthy of reliance of the people of Baghdád, that they say tZAhrtu↓ bihi in the place of OaZoharotuhu, and scarcely ever employ AZhr in its usual sense. (Har p. 85.) [Hence, AZhr AltRaDoEiyfa He made the doubling of a letter distinct; as in laHiHato; which, accord. to a general rule, should be laHRato: opposed to Oadogama. And AZhr lahu kacaA He showed, &c., to him such a thing: and he made a show of, professed, pretended, or feigned, to him such a thing: as, for instance, love.] ― -b2- OaZoharotu bifulaAnK means OaEolayotu bihi [a phrase which I have not found except in this instance, app. I elevated, or exalted, such a one: like OaEolayotuhu, which has this meaning]: (S, IKtt, L, TA:) or OaEolanotu bihi [app. meaning I made such a one to be, or become, publicly known]: (So in the O:) [but the former explanation seems to be regarded by SM as the right; for he remarks that,] accord. to all the copies of the K, the explanation is OaEolana bihi, and refers to Zahara bifulaAnK [instead of OaZohara]; so that what its author says in this case differs in two points of view from what is found in the “ Kitáb el-Abniyeh ” of IKtt, in which the I in OaEolayotu has been marked as correct, and in the L [as well as in the S]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- AZhrhu QllRehu EalaI EaduwRihi means God made him to overcome, conquer, subdue, overpower, master, gain the victory over, or prevail over, his enemy. (S, A, O, TA.) ― -b2- And [hence] AZhrhu Ealayohi He (God) made him to know it, or become acquainted with it: you say, OaZoharaniI QllRehu EalaI maA suriqa minRiI God made me to know [or discover] what had been stolen from me. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also 1, last quarter, in two places. ＝ -A4- And see 2. ＝ -A5- AZhr signifies also He entered upon the time called the Zahiyrap: (A, Msb, K:) or the time called the Zuhor. (Msb.) And He went, or journeyed, in the time called the Zahiyrap; as also ZhRr↓, (K,) inf. n. taZohiyrN: (TA:) or the time called the Zuhor. (S, O.)

5 tZhRr c and AiZRahRara
5. tZhRr AiZRahRara: see 3, latter half, in three places.

6 taZaAohara
6: see 1, first sentence: ― -b2- and see also 4, first sentence. ― -b3- tZAhrwA They aided, or assisted, one another. (S, O, * K.) And tZAhrwA EalaI fulaAnK They leagued together, and aided one another, against such a one. (Ibn-Buzurj, TA in art. Dfr.) ― -b4- Also They regarded, or treated, one another with enmity, or hostility; or severed themselves, one from another: (S, Msb, K:) as though they turned their backs, one upon another: (S:) or, because they who do so turn their backs, one upon another. (Msb.) Thus the verb has two contr. meanings. (K.) ― -b5- tZAhr mini QmoraOatihi and AiZRaAhara: see 3, latter half, in three places.

8 AiZRahara c
8. AiZRahara: see 1, last quarter.

10 AstZhr bihi c
10. AstZhr bihi He sought aid, or assistance, in, or by means of, him, or it, (S, O, Msb, K, TA,) Ealayohi [against him, or it]; as also AstZhrhu. (TA.) [In the CK, after the explanation of AstZhr bh, is an omission, to be supplied by the insertion of waqaraOahu.] One says, AstZhr biQloginaI EalaI AlnRawaAYibi [He sought aid in wealth against calamities, or afflictions]. (Msb.) And bihi ZAhr↓ signifies the same as AstZhr [in this sense or in another of the senses expl. in what follows]. (TA.) ― -b2- And AstZhrtu biAlXRaIoCi, and bihi Zaharotu↓, and Zaharotuhu↓, I put the thing behind my back for protection, or security. (Har p. 265.) ― -b3- And AstZhr He prepared for himself a camel, or two camels, or more, for future need: (T:) and AstZhrhu, and bihi Zahara↓, He prepared him, namely, a camel, for future need: (K:) and AstZhr bibaEiyrayoni ZihoriyRayoni He prepared for himself two camels for future need. (T. [See ZihoriIRN.]) ― -b4- Hence, (T,) AstZhr signifies also He used precaution (T, Msb) with respect to anything: (T:) he secured himself, (Aisotawovaqa,) by using precaution; as, for instance, a woman does by remaining three days, before she performs the ablution termed gusol, and prays, after the usual period of the menses. (T, L.) One says, yusotaHabRu AlAisotiZohaAru bigasolapK vaAniyapK wavaAlivapK The using precaution by a second and a third washing, to make sure of being pure, is approved. (Er-Ráfi'ee, Msb.) And AstZhrtu fiI Talabi AlXRaIoCi I adopted the most fit, or proper, way, and used precaution, in seeking to attain the thing. (Msb.) ― -b5- See also 1, in the middle of the latter half.

ZahorN c
ZahorN The back; contr. of baTonN: (S, A, O, Msb, K:) in a man, from the hinder part of the kaAhil [or base of the neck] to the nearest part of the buttocks, where it terminates: (TA:) in a camel, the part containing six vertebræ on the right and left of which are [two portions of flesh and sinew called the] matonaAni: (AHeyth, T, O:) of the masc. gender: (Lh, A, K:) pl. [of pauc.] OaZohurN, and [of mult.] ZuhuwrN and ZuhoraAnN. (Msb, K.) ― -b2- rajulN xafiyfu AlZRahori (tropical:) A man having a small household to maintain: and vaqiylu AlZRahori (tropical:) having a large household to maintain. (K, * TA.) ― -b3- Oanot EalaIRa kaZahori
OumRiI Thou art to me like the back of my mother: said by a man to his wife. (S, Mgh, Msb, K.) [This has been expl. above: see 3.] ― -b4- EadaA fiI Zahorihi (tropical:) He stole what was behind him: (A:) [or he acted wrongfully in respect of what was behind him: for] liSRN EaAdiI ZahorK is expl. by the words EadaA fiI ZahorK fasaraqahu [so that it app. means (tropical:) A thief who has acted wrongfully in respect of what was behind one, and stolen it]. (O, K.) ― -b5- OaqoraAnu AlZRahori (S, O, K) and AlZRuhuwri (O, TA) Adversaries who come to one from behind his back, in war, or fight. (S, O, K, * TA.) In the copies of the K, yuHibRuwnaka is erroneously put for yajiyWuwnaka. (TA.) You say also, fulaAnN qironu AlZRahori Such a one is an adversary who comes to one from behind, unknown. (IAar, As.) ― -b6- qatalahu ZahorFA He slew him unexpectedly; he assassinated him; syn. giylapN. (IAar, TA.) ― -b7- jaEalaniI biZahorK (tropical:) He cast me off. (TA.) And jaEaltu HaAjatahu biZahorK (tropical:) I cast his want behind my back: (AO, K:) and jaEalahaA ZihoriyRapF↓ signifies the same: (S:) and AitRaxacahaA ZihoriyRFA↓, (K,) and ZihoriyRapF↓: (TA:) or the former of the last two phrases signifies he held it in contempt; as though ZhryRA were an irreg. rel. n. from ZahorN: (TA:) or AitRaxacahu ZihoriyRFA↓ signifies he neglected, or forgot, (S, O, * Msb,) him, as in the Kur xi. 94, (S, O,) or it, namely, what was said. (Msb.) And laA tajoEalo HaAjatiI biZahorK (tropical:) Forget not thou, or neglect not, my want: (S:) and jaEalahu ZihoriyRFA↓ signifies he forgot it; as well as jElh biZahorK. (A.) And jaEalotu hecaA AlOamora biZahorK, and ramayotuhu biZahorK, (tropical:) I cared not for this thing. (Th, O.) ― -b8- fulaAnN mino waladi AlZRahori (assumed tropical:) Such a one is of those who do not belong to us: or of those to whom no regard is paid: (TA:) or of those who are held in contempt, and to whose ties of relationship no regard is paid. (S, TA.) ― -b9- huwa Qbonu EamRihi ZahorFA (tropical:) [He is his cousin on the father's side,] distantly related: contr. of dinoyFA [and laHRFA]. (As, A, O, TA.) ― -b10- rajaEa EalaI Zahorihi [He receded, retired, or retreated]. (K in art. vbjr.) ― -b11- huwa naAzilN bayona Zahorayohimo, and byn ZahoraAnayohimo↓, (S, A, O, Msb, K, *) in which latter the A and n are said by some to be added for corroboration, (Msb,) and for which one should not say ZahoraAniyhimo, (IF, S, O, Msb, K,) and byn OaZohurihimo, (Msb, K,) (tropical:) He is making his abode in the midst of them; in the main body of them: (K, TA:) originally meaning he is making his abode among them for the purpose of seeking aid of them and staying himself upon them: as though it meant that the back of one of them was before him, and that of another behind him, so that he was defended in either direction: afterwards, by reason of frequency of usage, it came to be employed to signify abiding among a people absolutely. (IAth, Msb.) You say also huwa bayona Zahorayohi, and bayona ZahoraAnayohi↓, meaning It (anything) is in the midst, or main part, of it, namely, another thing. (TA.) ― -b12- laqiytuhu bayona AlZRahorayoni, and bayona AlZRahoraAnayoni↓, (S, O, Msb, K,) (tropical:) I met him during the day, (Msb,) or during the two days, (S, O, K,) or during the three days, (K,) or the days: (S, O, Msb:) from the next preceding phrase. (TA.) And Oatayotuhu marRapF bayona AlZRaharoyni (tropical:) I came to him one day: or, accord. to Aboo-Fak'as, on a day between two years. (Fr.) And AllRayoli raOayotuhu bayona ZahoraAnaIi↓ (tropical:) I saw him between nightfall and daybreak. (TA.) And AlnRahaAri jiYotuhu bayona ZahoraAnaIi↓ (tropical:) [I came to him between the beginning and end of the day]. (A.) ― -b13- taqalRaba ZahorFA libaTonK (assumed tropical:) It turned over and over, or upside down, (lit. back for belly,) as a serpent does upon ground heated by the sun. (S and TA in art. qlb.) [Hence,] qalabotu AlOaroDa ZahorFA libaTonK (tropical:) [I turned the earth over, upside-down]. (A.) And [hence,] qalRaba Oamorahu ZahorFA libaTonK, (O, * TA,) and Zahorahu libaTonK, and Zahorahu libaTonihi, and Zahorahu lilobaToni, which last form is preferred by El-Farezdak to the second, because [as in the third form] the second of the two words is determinate like the first word, (tropical:) He meditated, or managed, the affair with forecast, and well. (O, * TA.) ― -b14- The Arabs used to say, hecaA Zahoru AlsRamaMCi and hcA baTonu AlsRamaMCi, both meaning (tropical:) This is the apparent, visible, part of the sky. (Fr, Az.) And the like is said of the side of a wall, which is its baTon to a person on the same side, and its Zahor to one on the other side. (Az.) ― -b15- maA nazala mina AlquroMni MyapN UilRaA lahaA ZahorN wabaTonN, [part of] a saying of Mohammad, [of which see the rest voce muTRalaEN,] means (assumed tropical:) Not a verse of the Kur-án has come down but it has a verbal expression and an interpretation: (K, * TA:) or a verbal expression and a meaning: or that which has an apparent and a known [or an exoteric] interpretation and that which has an intrinsic [or esoteric] interpretation: (TA:) or narration (K, TA) and admonition: (TA:) or [it is to be read and to be understood and taught; for] by the Zhr is meant the reading; and by the bTn, the understanding and teaching. (TA.) [See also baTonN.] ― -b16- ZahorN signifies also (tropical:) Camels on which people ride, and which carry goods; (S, * A, * O, K, * TA;) camels that carry burdens upon their backs in journeying: (TA:) [or] a beast: or a camel for riding: (Mgh:) pl. ZuhoraAnN. (TA.) It is said in a trad. of 'Arfajeh, fatanaAwala AlsRayofa mina AlZRahori And he reached, or took in his hand, the sword from the camels for carrying burdens and for riding: and in another, OataOocanu lanaA fiI naHori ZahorinaA Dost thou permit us to slaughter our camels which we ride? (TA.) And one says also, huwa EalaI ZahorK (tropical:) He is determined upon travel: (K:) as though he had already mounted a beast for that purpose. (TA.) ― -b17- [Hence, app.,] (assumed tropical:) Property consisting of camels and sheep or goats: (TA:) or much property. (K, TA.) ― -b18- (assumed tropical:) The short side [or lateral half] of a feather: (S, O, K:) pl. ZuhoraAnN: (S, M, K, TA, &c.:) opposed to baTonN, sing. of buTonaAnN, (TA,) which latter signifies the “ long sides: ” (S, TA:) and ZuhaArN↓ signifies the same as ZahorN, (K,) or the same as ZuhoraAnN, being an irregular pl.; and this is meant by the saying AlZRuhaAru biAlDRami AljamaAEapu, mentioned in a later place in the K [in such a manner as to have led to the supposition that ZuhaArN is also syn. with jamaAEapN]: (TA:) AO says that among the feathers of arrows are the ZuhaAr, which are those that are put [upon an arrow] of the Zahor [or outer side] of the Easiyb [app. here meaning the shaft] of the feather; (S, TA;) i. e., the shorter side, which is the best kind of feather; as also ZuhoraAn: sing. ZahorN: (TA:) ISd says that the ZuhoraAn are those parts of the feathers of the wing that are exposed to the sun and rain: (TA:) Lth says that the ZuhaAr are those parts of the feathers of the wing that are apparent. (O, TA.) One says, riXo sahomaka biZuhoraAnK walaA tariXohu bibuTonaAnK [Feather thine arrow with short sides of feathers, and feather it not with long sides of feathers]. (S, TA.) [De Sacy supposes that ZuhuwrN and buTuwnN are also pls. of ZahorN and baTonN thus used: (see his “ Chrest. Arabe, ” sec. ed., tome ii., p. 374:) but his reasons do not appear to me to be conclusive.] ZuhaArN↓ and ZuhoraAnN are also used as epithets: you say, riyXN ZuhaArN and riyXN ZuhoraAnN. (TA.) ― -b19- [Zahoru AlkafRi and ZaAhiruhaA↓ mean (assumed tropical:) The back of the hand. And in like manner, Zahoru Alqadami and ZaAhiruhaA↓ mean (assumed tropical:) The upper, or convex, side, or back, of the human foot, corresponding to the back of the hand, including the instep: opposed to baTon and baATin. And Zahoru AllRisaAni means (assumed tropical:) The upper surface of the tongue.] ― -b20- And ZahorN also signifies (tropical:) A way by land. (S, M, O, Msb, K.) This expression is used when there is a way by land and a way by sea. (M.) You say, saAruwA fiI Tariyqi AlZRahori (tropical:) They journeyed by land. (A.) ― -b21- And (assumed tropical:) An elevated tract of land or ground; as also ZaAhirpN↓: (A:) or rugged and elevated land or ground; (JK, K;) as also ZaAhirapN↓: (JK:) opposed to baTonN, which signifies “ soft and plain and fine and low land or ground: ” (TA:) and ZawaAhiru↓ [pl. of. ZaAhirapN] signifies (assumed tropical:) elevated tracts of land or ground: (S, K:) you say, haAjato ZawaAhiru AlOaroDi, meaning, (assumed tropical:) the herbs, or leguminous plants, of the elevated tracts of land, or ground, dried up: (As, S, L:) and ZaAhirN↓ signifies (assumed tropical:) the higher, or highest, part of a mountain; (ISh, L, TA;) whether its exterior be plain or not: (TA:) and ZaAhirapN↓, the same, of anything: (L:) when you have ascended upon the Zahor of a mountain, you are upon its ZaAhirap. (TA.) ― -b22- saAla waAdiyhimo ZahorFA means (assumed tropical:) Their valley flowed with the rain of their own land: opposed to duroCFA, meaning, “ from other rain: ” (IAar, O, K: *) or the former signifies their valley flowed
with its own rain: and the latter, “ with other than its own rain: ” (TA:) and some say ZuhorFA↓, which Az thinks the better form. (O, TA.) ― -b23- [Hence, probably,] OaSabotu minohu maTara ZahorK (assumed tropical:) I obtained from him, or it, much good. (Sgh, O, K.) ― -b24- And another signification of ZahorN is What is absent, or hidden, or concealed, from one. (O, K.) ― -b25- It is sometimes prefixed to another noun to give plainness and force to the expression; as in Zahoru Algayobi and Zahoru Alqalobi, meaning nafosu Algayobi and nafosu Alqalobi: (Msb:) or it is redundant in these instances. (Mgh.) Lebeed says, describing a [wild] cow going about after a beast of prey that had eaten her young one,
watasamRaEato rizRa AlOaniysi faraAEahaA
Eano Zahori gayobK waAlOaniysu saqaAmuhaA
[And she heard the sound of man, and it frightened her, from a place that concealed what was in it; for man is her malady; i. e., a cause of pain and trouble and death to her]: (TA:) meaning, she heard the sound of the hunters, &c. (TA in art. gyb.) And you say, tanaAwalahu biZahori Algayobi bimaA yasuwWuhu He carped at him behind the back, or in absence, by saying what would grieve him. (TA in art. gyb.) And takalRamotu bihi Eano Zahori Algayobi (A, O) or En Zahori gayobK (TA) [app., (tropical:) I spoke it by memory; in the absence of a book or the like; as one says in modern Arabic, EalaI AlgaAYib. See also gayobN.] And qaraOahu Eano Zahori Alqalobi (tropical:) He recited it by heart, or memory; without book: (L, K: [in the latter, mino is put in the place of Eano; but the right reading is that in the L: and in the CK is an omission here, to be supplied by the insertion of waqaraOahu:]) and qrOh ZaAhirFA↓ and qrOh EalaI Zahori lisaAnihi [signify the same]. (K.) And Hamala AlquroMna EalaI Zahori lisaAnihi like HafiZahu EalaI Zahori qalobihi (tropical:) [He knew the Kur-án by heart]. (A, * O, TA.) ― -b26- One says also, fulaAnN yaOokulu EalaI Zahori yadi fulaAnK (tropical:) Such a one eats at the expense of such a one. (A, O, K. *) And in like manner, AlfuqaraMCu yaOokuluwna EalaI Zahori OayodiI AlnRaAsi (tropical:) The poor eat at the expense of the people. (A, TA.) And OaEoTaAhu Eano Zahori yadK (tropical:) He gave him originally; without compensation. (O, * K; but in some copies of the K we find mino in the place of Eano.) It is said [in a trad.], OafoDalu AlSRadaqapi maA kaAna Eano Zahori ginFI (tropical:) The most excellent of alms is that which is [derived] from competence; Zhr: (Msb:) or simply Eano ginFI, the word Zhr being here redundant: (Mgh:) or from manifest competence upon which one relies, and in which he seeks aid against calamities, or afflictions: or from what remains after fight: (Msb:) or from superfluous property. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ZahiyrN ＝ -A3- qidoru ZahorK means (assumed tropical:) An old cooking-pot: (O, K: *) pl. quduwru ZuhuwrK: (O:) as though, because of its oldness, it were thrown behind the back. (TA.)

ZuhorN c
ZuhorN Midday, or noon: (IAth, TA:) or the time when the sun declines from the meridian: (Msb, * K, * O, * TA:) or [the time immediately] after the declining of the sun: (S, Mgh:) masc. and fem.; unless when the word SalaAp is prefixed to it, in which case it is fem. only: (Msb:) [pl. OaZohaArN. See also ZahiyrapN.] SalaApu AlZRuhori means The prayer [i. e. the divinely-ordained prayer] of midday, or noon: (IAth, TA:) or of the time after the declining of the sun. (S, O.) In the phrases OaboriduwA biAlZRuhori [Defer ye the prayer of midday until the cooler time of day] and SalRaI AlZRuhora [He performed the prayer of midday], the prefixed noun (SalaAp) is suppressed. (Mgh.) ＝ -A2- saAla waAdiyhimo ZuhorFA: see ZahorN, last quarter.

ZahirN c
ZahirN, (S,) or ZahiyrN↓, (K,) [the former agreeable with analogy, being derived from Zahira,] A man (S,) having a complaint of the back: (S, K:) or having a pain in the back: as also maZohuwrN↓. (O, TA.)

ZuhorapN c
ZuhorapN: see ZahiyrN, in three places. ＝ -A2- Also The tortoise. (O, K.)

ZihorapN c
ZihorapN: see ZahiyrN, in six places.

ZaharapN c
ZaharapN The goods, or furniture and utensils, of a house or tent; (IAar, S, O, K, TA;) as also OaharapN: (IAar, TA:) or the former signifies the exterior of a house, or tent; and the latter, the “ interior thereof. ” (Th, TA.) ― -b2- And Abundance of maAl [i. e. property, or cattle]. (TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ZahiyrN.

ZihoriIRN c
ZihoriIRN A camel prepared for future need; (T, S, O, K;) taken, by way of precaution, to bear the burden of any camel that may happen to fail in a journey: sometimes two or more unladen camels are taken for this purpose: some say that such a camel is thus called because its owner puts it behind his back, not riding it nor putting any burden upon it: (T, TA:) the word appears to be an irreg. rel. n. from ZahorN: (ISd, TA:) pl. ZahaAriIRN, imperfectly decl., because the rel. I retains its place in the sing. [inseparably; there being no such word as Zihor: but if it be a rel. n., this pl. is irreg., like mahaAriIRN]. (S, O, K.) ― -b2- See ZahorN, first quarter, in five places, for examples of ZihoriIRN and ZihoriyRapN used tropically.

ZuhoraAn c
ZuhoraAn [app. ZuhoraAnN (which is also a pl. of ZahorN used in several senses), or, perhaps ZuhoraAni, as having a dual meaning,] The upper, thick, pair of wings of the locust. (AHn, TA.) ― -b2- [See also ZahorN.]

bayona ZahoraAnayohimo c
bayona ZahoraAnayohimo, and ZahoraAnayohi, and AlZRahoraAnayoni, &c.: see ZahorN, former half, in five places.

ZahaArN c
ZahaArN The exterior (K, TA) and elevated (TA) part of a [stony tract such as is called] HarRap. (K, TA.)

ZuhaArN c
ZuhaArN Pain in the back. (Az, O, TA.) ＝ -A2- See also ZahorN, third quarter, in two places.

ZahiyrN c
ZahiyrN: see ZaAhirN. ＝ -A2- Also An aider, or assistant; (S, A, O, Msb, K;) and so ZihorapN↓ (S, K) and ZuhorapN↓: (K:) [in one place, in the K, ZihorapN is expl. by Eawon; but by this is meant, as will be seen below, the same as is meant by muEiyn, by which all the three words are expl. in another place in the K, as well as in the S &c.:] and aiders, or assistants; (S, Msb;) as also ZihorapN↓ and ZuhorapN↓ and ZahorN↓: (TA:) the pl. of ZahiyrN is ZuharaMCu. (O.) It is said in the Kur [xxv. 57], wakaAna AlkaAfiru EalaI rabRihi ZahiyrFA And the unbeliever is an aider of the enemies of God [against his Lord]. (Ibn-'Arafeh.) You say also, fulaAnN EalaI fulaAnK ZihoratiI↓ Such a one is my aider (Eawon) against such a one: and EalaI hecaA OanaA Zihoratuka↓ AlOamori I am thine aider against this thing, or affair. (S, O.) And it is also said in the Kur [lxvi. 4], waQlomalaAYikapu baEoda celika ZahiyrN [And the angels after that will be his aiders]: and instance of Zhyr in a pl. sense: (S, O, Msb:) for words of the measures faEuwlN and faEiylN are sometimes masc. and fem. [and sing.] and pl. (S.) You also say, jaMCa fulaAnN fiI Zihoratihi↓, (S, A, K,) and Zuhoratihi↓, (A, K,) and Zaharatihi↓, and ZaAhiratihi↓, (K,) Such a one came among his people, (S,) or kinsfolk, (K,) and those who performed his affairs for him, (S, A,) i. e., his aiders, or assistants. (A.) And waAHidapK humo fiI ZihorapK↓ They aid one another against the enemies. (TA.) ― -b2- Also Strong in the back; (K;) sound therein: (Lth:) and so muZahRarN↓: (S, O, K:) applied to a man: (S:) or hard and strong; whether in the back or any other part is not said: (TA:) in this sense, (TA,) or as signifying strong, (S, O,) applied to a camel: fem. with p. (S, O, TA.) ― -b3- Also A camel whose back is not used, on account of galls, or sores, upon it: or unsound in the back by reason of galls, or sores, or from some other cause. (Th.) Thus it has two contr. significations. (TA.) ＝ -A3- See also ZahirN.

ZihaArapN c
ZihaArapN [The facing, or outer covering, or] what is uppermost, (TA,) what is apparent (Msb, TA) to the eye, (Msb,) not next the body, of a garment; (TA;) and in like manner, what is uppermost and apparent, not next the ground, of a carpet; (TA;) as also ZaAhirapN↓: (JK:) contr. of biTaAnapN: (S, O, Msb, K:) pl. ZahaAYiru. (TA.)

ZahiyrapN c
ZahiyrapN The point of midday: (M, A, K:) or only in summer: (M, K:) or i. q. haAjirapN [i. e. midday in summer or when the heat is vehement: or the period from a little before, to a little after, midday in summer: or midday, when the sun declines from the meridian, at the Zuhor: or from its declining until the EaSor]: (S, O, TA:) or the haAjirap, which is when the sun declines from the meridian: (Msb:) or the vehement heat of midday: (IAth, TA:) or i. q. ZuhorN [q. v.]: (Az, TA:)
pl. ZahaAYiru. (TA.) You say, Oatoyotuhu HadRa AlZRahiyrapi [I came to him at the point of midday in summer; &c.]: and Hiyna qaAma qaAYimu AlZRahiyrapi [when the sun had become high, and the shade had almost disappeared: so expl. in art. qwm]. (S, O.) And Oaborido Eanoka mina AlZRahiyrapi Stay thou until the middayheat shall have become assuaged, and the air be cool. (L in art. fyH.) And hence, in a trad. of 'Omar, when a man came to him complaining of gout in the feet, he said, kacabatoka AlZRahaAYiru, meaning Take thou to walking during the heat of the middays in summer. (TA.)

ZuhaAriyRapN c
ZuhaAriyRapN One of the modes of seizing [and throwing down] in wrestling: or i. q. XagozabiyRapN: (K:) the twisting one's leg with the leg of another in the manner that is termed XagozabiyRap, and so throwing him down: one says, Oaxacahu AlZRuhaAriyRapa and AlXRagozabiyRapa [He seized him and threw him down by the trick above described]: both signify the same: (ISh, O:) or ZuhaAriyRapN signifies the throwing one down upon the back. (Ibn-'Abbád, O, K.) ― -b2- And (hence, as being likened thereto, TA) (tropical:) A certain mode, or manner, of compressing, or coïtus. (O, K, TA.) ― -b3- And Oawovaqahu AlZRuhaAriyRapa He bound his hands behind his back. (Ibn-Buzurj, O, K, TA.)

ZaAhirN c
ZaAhirN [Outward, exterior, external, extrinsic, or exoteric: and hence, appearing, apparent, overt, open, perceptible or perceived, manifest, conspicuous, ostensible, plain, or evident: in all these senses] contr. of baATinN: (S, K, TA:) and so ZahiyrN↓. (TA.) [Hence, ZaAhirFA Outwardly, &c.: and apparently; &c.: and fiI AlZRaAhiri in appearance. And AlZRaAhiru OanRahu kacaA It appears, or it seems, or what seems to be the case is, that it is so, or thus. And ZaAhiru kacaA for ZaAhirN fiyhi kacaA, meaning A person, or thing, in whom, or in which, such a quality is apparent, or manifest, &c.: see an ex. in a verse cited in the first paragraph of art. TEn.] See also muZoharN. ― -b2- [Hence also,] EayonN ZaAhirapN A prominent eye; (S, O, K, TA;) that fills its cavity. (TA.) ― -b3- And hecaA OamorN ZaAhirN Eanoka EaAruhu (tropical:) This is a thing, or an affair, of which the disgrace is remote from thee: (S, TA:) or does not cleave to thee. (TA.) And hecaA EayobN ZaAhirN Eanoka (tropical:) This is a vice, or fault, that does not cleave to thee. (A.) A poet says, (namely, Kutheiyir, accord. to a copy of the S, or Aboo-Dhu-eyb, TA,)
waEayRarahaA AlwaAXuwna OanRiI OuHibRuhaA
watiloka XakaApN ZaAhirN Eanoka EaAruhaA
(tropical:) [And the slanderers taunted her with the fact of my loving her; but that is a fault of which the disgrace is remote from thee]. (S, TA.) ― -b4- [AlZRaAhiru also signifies The outside, or exterior, of a thing. You say, nazala ZaAhira Almadiynapi He alighted, or took up his abode, outside the city: comp. ZaAhirapN. Hence,] ZaAhiru AlkafRi and ZaAhiru Alqadami; and another signification of ZaAhirN: for all of which see ZahorN, third quarter. ― -b5- [Also The external, outward, or extrinsic, state, condition, or circumstances, of a man: and the outward, or apparent, character, or disposition of the mind: opposed to AlbaATinu.] ― -b6- One says also, fulaAnN ZaAhirN EalaI fulaAnK Such a one has the ascendancy, or mastery, over such a one; is conqueror of him, or victorious over him. (TA.) And hecaA OamorN ZaAhirN bika This is a thing, or an affair, that overcomes, or overpowers, thee. (TA.) And hecaA OamorN Oanota bihi ZaAhirN This is an affair which thou hast power to do. (TA.) [And huwa ZaAhirN EalaI kacaA He is a conqueror, a winner, an achiever, or an attainer, of such a thing: see an ex. voce garabN, near the end.] And AlZRaAhiru is one of the names of God, meaning The Ascendant, or Predominant, over all things: or, as some say, He who is known -by inference of the mind from what appears to mankind of the effects of his actions and his attributes. (IAth, TA.) ― -b7- HaAjatuhu Einodaka ZaAhirapN means (tropical:) His want is in thine estimation [an object of contempt, or neglect, as though] cast behind the back. (O, * TA.) ― -b8- qaraOahu ZaAhirFA: see ZahorN, towards the end of the paragraph. ＝ -A2- XaMCN ZawaAhiru Sheep, or goats, that come to the water every day at noon. (TA.)

[Hence,] qurayoXu AlZRawaAhiri Those, of Kureysh, that dwell in the exterior of Mekkeh, (O,) upon the mountains thereof, (K, * TA,) or upon the higher parts of Mekkeh: (TA:) those who dwell in the lower parts are called qurayoXu AlbiTaAHi; (O, * TA;) and these are the more honourable, (O, TA, *) because they are neighbours of the House of God. (O.) ― -b2- See also ZihaArapN. ＝ -A2- And see ZahiyrN. ＝ -A3- Also The coming of camels, (S, O, K, TA,) and of sheep or goats, (TA,) to the water every day, at noon. (S, O, K, TA.) One says, of camels, [and of sheep or goats,] taridu AlZRaAhirapa [They come to the water every day, at noon]: and Sh says that they return from the water at the EaSor. (TA.) And Xariba Alfarasu ZaAhirapF The horse drank every day, at noon. (TA.) ZaAhirapu AlgibRi [The coming to the water at noon on alternate days] is for sheep or goats; scarcely ever, or never, for camels; and is a little shorter [in the interval] than what is called [simply] AlgibRu.
